SOFTWARE REQUIREMENTS SPECIFICATION (SRS)

Multi-Vendor E-commerce Platform

Document Version: 2.0 (Revised & Complete)

Date: February 6, 2026

Status: Final - Ready for Development

1. INTRODUCTION

1.1 Purpose

This Software Requirements Specification document provides a comprehensive description of the Multi-Vendor E-commerce Platform. The document is intended for the development team, project stakeholders, quality assurance personnel, and system administrators who will be involved in the design, development, testing, deployment, and maintenance of the system.

The platform will enable multiple independent vendors to sell their products through a unified marketplace while providing customers with a seamless shopping experience. Administrative staff will have complete oversight and control over vendor activities, product listings, order processing, and commission management.

1.2 Scope

The Multi-Vendor E-commerce Platform is a web-based application that will facilitate online commerce between multiple vendors and customers through a centralized marketplace. The system will manage the complete lifecycle of e-commerce operations including product catalog management, inventory tracking, order processing, payment handling, and commission distribution.

The platform consists of three primary user interfaces. The customer-facing storefront will provide product browsing, searching, comparison, cart management, and checkout capabilities. The vendor dashboard will enable sellers to manage their product listings, inventory, orders, and earnings. The administrative panel will provide platform operators with comprehensive tools for vendor management, product approval, order oversight, commission calculation, and system configuration.

The system will support both simple products with single pricing and inventory, as well as variable products with multiple variants based on attributes such as size, color, or material. Integration with major payment gateways including Stripe and PayPal will enable secure transaction processing. A sophisticated commission system will automatically calculate and track platform earnings from each transaction.

The platform explicitly excludes certain functionalities that may be considered for future phases. It will not include a mobile application, though the web interface will be fully responsive. International multi-currency support is not included in this version, with the platform operating in a single currency. Subscription-based products and recurring billing are not supported. Vendor-to-vendor messaging is not included, though vendors can respond to customer reviews. Affiliate marketing programs and multi-level commission structures are excluded from this version.

1.3 Definitions, Acronyms, and Abbreviations

Throughout this document, the following terms are used with specific meanings that are critical to understanding the system requirements.

A vendor refers to a registered seller who lists and sells products on the platform. Vendors must be approved by administrators before they can begin selling. Each vendor operates independently with their own inventory, pricing, and fulfillment processes.

A customer is any user who browses and purchases products from the platform. Customers can make purchases as guests or create accounts for order tracking and faster checkout. Customer accounts persist across purchases and enable features such as wishlists and order history.

A product represents an item listed for sale by a vendor. Products can be either simple, with a single price and inventory count, or variable, with multiple variants based on attributes. Each product belongs to a single category and is associated with one vendor.

A variant is a specific configuration of a variable product, defined by a unique combination of attribute values. For example, a t-shirt product might have variants for "Small/Red," "Medium/Blue," etc. Each variant maintains its own SKU, price, and inventory count.

An order is a customer's purchase request containing one or more products from one or more vendors. Orders are automatically split by vendor for fulfillment purposes, though the customer sees a single order with a unified order number. Each order tracks payment status, fulfillment status, and commission calculations.

Commission refers to the platform's fee charged on each sale, calculated as a percentage of the order total. Commission rates can be set globally or customized per vendor. The system tracks commission in three states: pending when an order is placed, released when an order is delivered, and paid when the vendor receives payout.

A payout is the process of transferring accumulated earnings from the platform to a vendor's bank account. Payouts can be initiated manually by administrators or requested by vendors once their balance reaches a minimum threshold. The system maintains complete payout history and transaction records.

Stock reservation is a temporary hold placed on inventory when items are added to a shopping cart. Reservations prevent overselling by ensuring that products in active carts are not available for other customers to purchase. Reservations automatically expire after twenty-four hours if checkout is not completed.

1.4 References

This document references and builds upon industry standards and best practices including the ISO/IEC 25010 Software Quality Model for quality attributes, PCI DSS v4.0 for payment card security requirements, OWASP Top 10 for web application security considerations, GDPR and applicable data protection regulations, and REST API design principles as documented by the OpenAPI Specification.

1.5 Document Overview

The remainder of this document is organized to provide progressively detailed information about the system. Section 2 provides a high-level system overview including user roles and major features. Section 3 details functional requirements organized by user role and feature area. Section 4 specifies non-functional requirements including performance, security, and reliability criteria. Section 5 describes the technical architecture and technology stack. Section 6 provides comprehensive database design including all tables, relationships, and constraints. Section 7 outlines user interface requirements and design principles. Section 8 details security requirements and implementation approaches. Section 9 describes external integrations with payment gateways and other services.

2. SYSTEM OVERVIEW

2.1 System Perspective

The Multi-Vendor E-commerce Platform is a standalone web-based system that operates as a marketplace facilitator between vendors and customers. The system integrates with external services for payment processing, email delivery, and cloud storage, but maintains complete control over core business logic, data management, and transaction processing.

The platform architecture follows a three-tier model with clear separation between presentation, business logic, and data layers. The presentation layer consists of three separate user interfaces: a customer-facing storefront built with Next.js for optimal SEO and performance, a vendor dashboard built with React for rich interactivity, and an administrative panel built with Vue.js for comprehensive management capabilities. These interfaces communicate with the backend through a RESTful API.

The business logic layer is implemented using Laravel PHP framework and encapsulates all core functionality including product catalog management, order processing, inventory control, commission calculation, and payment handling. This layer enforces business rules, maintains data integrity, and orchestrates interactions between different system components.

The data layer utilizes PostgreSQL as the primary relational database for transactional data, Redis for caching and session management, and Meilisearch for fast product search capabilities. File storage for product images and documents is handled by AWS S3 or compatible object storage services.

2.2 User Roles and Characteristics

The system supports four distinct user roles, each with specific capabilities and access levels tailored to their needs and responsibilities within the platform.

2.2.1 Customers

Customers are the end users who browse and purchase products from the marketplace. They may be either registered users with accounts or guests who checkout without creating an account. Registered customers benefit from order history tracking, saved addresses, wishlists, and faster checkout processes. Customers are expected to have basic familiarity with online shopping interfaces but should not require technical knowledge to use the platform effectively.

Customers can browse products by category, search using keywords, filter by attributes and price ranges, view detailed product information including images and specifications, add items to a shopping cart, apply coupon codes for discounts, proceed through a multi-step checkout process including address entry and payment, track their orders from placement through delivery, write reviews and ratings for purchased products, and manage their account information including addresses and payment methods.

2.2.2 Vendors

Vendors are approved sellers who list and sell products on the platform. They operate as independent businesses using the platform's infrastructure for reaching customers. Vendors are expected to have moderate technical proficiency for managing product listings and inventory, though the system should minimize complexity where possible. They must also have business knowledge regarding pricing, inventory management, and order fulfillment processes.

Vendors can create and manage their business profile including company information and banking details, create and edit product listings with images, descriptions, pricing, and inventory, manage simple products and variable products with multiple variants, track inventory levels with automatic low-stock alerts, view and process orders assigned to their products, update order status as items progress through fulfillment, communicate with customers through order notes, view earnings broken down by orders and commission deductions, request payouts when their available balance meets the minimum threshold, and generate sales reports for business analysis.

2.2.3 Administrators

Administrators are platform operators with full access to all system features and data. They are responsible for maintaining platform integrity, approving vendors and categories, configuring system settings, and resolving disputes. Administrators are expected to have strong technical proficiency with web-based administration tools and comprehensive understanding of e-commerce business processes.

Administrators can review and approve or reject vendor registration requests, review and approve or reject category creation requests from vendors, configure global platform settings including commission rates and tax percentages, view comprehensive analytics including revenue, order volume, vendor performance, and customer metrics, manage all orders with ability to process refunds and cancellations, oversee dispute resolution between vendors and customers, manage customer accounts including password resets and account suspension, process vendor payout requests and maintain payout records, configure payment gateway settings and API credentials, manage email templates and notification settings, view detailed activity logs of all user actions, and generate comprehensive reports for business analysis.

2.2.4 Super Administrators

Super Administrators possess all capabilities of regular administrators plus additional privileges for critical system operations. This role is typically held by senior technical staff or business owners. Super Administrators can create and manage other administrator accounts, modify system-critical settings that affect platform behavior, access direct database management tools for troubleshooting, configure server and infrastructure settings, and access comprehensive system logs including security audit trails.

2.3 Operating Environment

The platform operates in a cloud-based infrastructure environment utilizing containerized services orchestrated through Docker. The production environment runs on Linux servers (Ubuntu 22.04 LTS or later) with Nginx as the web server and PHP-FPM for application processing. PostgreSQL 15 or later serves as the database management system with Redis 7 or later providing caching and session storage.

Client-side operation requires modern web browsers including Google Chrome version 90 or later, Mozilla Firefox version 88 or later, Safari version 14 or later, or Microsoft Edge version 90 or later. The customer-facing interface is fully responsive and supports mobile devices running iOS 14 or later or Android 10 or later. JavaScript must be enabled for full functionality.

The system integrates with several external services that must be available for complete platform operation. Stripe and PayPal APIs handle payment processing with fallback to Cash on Delivery when online payment is unavailable. AWS S3 or compatible object storage provides file storage for product images and documents. SMTP email service (SendGrid, Mailgun, or similar) handles transactional emails. Twilio or equivalent SMS service enables order notifications via text message when configured.

2.4 Design and Implementation Constraints

Several constraints shape the design and implementation of the platform. The backend must be developed using Laravel PHP framework version 10 or later with PHP 8.1 minimum. The frontend customer interface uses Next.js 14 with React 18, the vendor dashboard uses React 18, and the admin panel uses Vue.js 3. PostgreSQL serves as the exclusive database system with no support for other databases in this version.

All payment processing must comply with PCI DSS requirements, which is achieved by never storing credit card information on platform servers and using only PCI-compliant payment gateway APIs. User passwords must be hashed using bcrypt with a minimum cost factor of 12. Sensitive vendor information including bank account numbers and tax identification must be encrypted at rest using AES-256 encryption.

The platform must maintain compatibility with GDPR and local data protection regulations. This requires implementing user consent mechanisms for data collection, providing data export functionality for user requests, supporting data deletion requests within legally required timeframes, and maintaining audit logs of data access and modifications.

API rate limiting must be implemented to prevent abuse, with limits of 1000 requests per hour per IP address for public endpoints and 100 requests per minute per authenticated user for protected endpoints. Image uploads are limited to 5MB per file with maximum dimensions of 5000 by 5000 pixels. Document uploads for vendor verification are limited to 10MB per file.

2.5 Assumptions and Dependencies

This specification assumes several conditions that are necessary for successful platform operation. Vendors are assumed to have valid business registrations and necessary legal documentation to operate as sellers. Internet connectivity is required for all users to access the platform, with minimum connection speeds of 1 Mbps recommended for customers and 5 Mbps recommended for vendors uploading product images.

The platform depends on the continued availability and compatibility of several external services. Payment gateways (Stripe, PayPal) must maintain their current API structures or provide adequate migration paths for any changes. Email service providers must maintain delivery rates above 95 percent to ensure critical transactional emails reach recipients. Cloud storage services must maintain 99.9 percent uptime as per standard SLAs. SMS providers, when utilized, must support delivery to the primary geographic markets served by the platform.

Browser vendors are expected to maintain backward compatibility with current web standards. Major browsers should not introduce breaking changes to JavaScript, CSS, or HTML standards without adequate transition periods. The platform will target current browser versions and one previous major version, requiring updates only when security vulnerabilities or critical bugs necessitate newer browser features.

Third-party libraries and frameworks used in development will be kept current with security patches but major version upgrades will be evaluated carefully for breaking changes. The platform will maintain compatibility with Long-Term Support (LTS) versions of major dependencies to ensure stability.

3. FUNCTIONAL REQUIREMENTS

3.1 User Management

3.1.1 Customer Registration and Authentication

Customers must be able to create accounts using email and password credentials. The registration process requires customers to provide an email address, which must be validated for proper format and uniqueness within the system, a password meeting minimum security requirements of eight characters including at least one uppercase letter, one lowercase letter, and one number, and a full name for account identification and order processing.

Upon successful registration, the system sends an email verification message to the provided address containing a unique verification link. The customer account remains in an unverified state until the link is accessed. Unverified accounts can browse products but cannot place orders. The verification link expires after 24 hours, after which customers can request a new verification email through the login interface.

Customers can log in using their registered email and password. The system validates credentials against stored hashed passwords and returns a session token or JWT for maintaining authenticated state across requests. Failed login attempts are tracked, and after five consecutive failures from the same IP address within a 15-minute window, that IP is temporarily blocked for one hour to prevent brute force attacks.

Password reset functionality allows customers who have forgotten their passwords to initiate a recovery process. The system sends a password reset email containing a unique token valid for one hour. Customers access the link and provide a new password meeting security requirements. The old password is immediately invalidated and cannot be reused.

The system supports optional two-factor authentication for customers who wish to enhance account security. When enabled, login requires both password and a time-based one-time password generated by an authenticator app. Setup involves displaying a QR code that customers scan with their authenticator app, after which they must provide a valid code to confirm activation.

Social authentication through Google and Facebook OAuth is supported as an alternative to email/password registration. When a customer authenticates through a social provider, the system creates an account using their social profile information and links it to the social identity. Customers can later add a password to enable traditional login alongside social login.

3.1.2 Vendor Registration and Approval

Vendor registration follows a two-stage process beginning with application submission and concluding with administrative approval. The initial registration form collects comprehensive business information to enable informed approval decisions and facilitate proper platform operation once approved.

Prospective vendors provide personal identification including full name and personal email address that will serve as the primary contact for platform communications. They create login credentials consisting of email and password meeting the same security requirements as customer accounts. Business information includes the legal business name exactly as registered with governmental authorities, the type of business entity such as sole proprietorship, partnership, or corporation, tax identification number for compliance and reporting purposes, business registration number or license number, and a comprehensive business description explaining the types of products they intend to sell.

Contact information encompasses business physical address including street, city, state, postal code, and country, business phone number with country code, and an optional website URL if the vendor maintains an existing online presence. Banking details for receiving payouts include bank name, account holder name exactly as it appears on the bank account, account number, routing number or SWIFT code for international transactions, and account type whether checking or savings.

Document uploads provide verification of vendor legitimacy. Required documents include business registration certificate or license scanned and uploaded in PDF, JPEG, or PNG format not exceeding 10MB, tax identification certificate proving tax registration status, and proof of business address such as utility bill or bank statement dated within the last three months. Optional documents include product liability insurance certificate if applicable to the product category and any relevant product certifications or quality standards documentation.

Upon form submission, the system validates all required fields, verifies document uploads are readable and meet size requirements, encrypts sensitive banking information before storage, and creates a vendor account in pending status. The vendor receives confirmation email acknowledging receipt of their application with an estimated review timeframe of 3-5 business days.

Administrators review pending vendor applications through a dedicated queue in the admin panel. The review interface displays all submitted information, uploaded documents with preview capability, and provides options to approve or reject the application with mandatory reason text if rejecting. When an administrator approves a vendor, the system updates the vendor status to active, sends an approval email containing login credentials and instructions for completing profile setup, creates initial commission rate record at the platform default or custom rate specified by administrator, and logs the approval action with administrator identity and timestamp.

If an administrator rejects the application, the system updates vendor status to rejected, stores the rejection reason provided by administrator, sends rejection email to vendor including the specific reason for rejection and guidance for reapplication if applicable, and logs the rejection action. Rejected vendors can reapply after addressing the stated concerns, creating a new application that is reviewed independently.

3.1.3 Administrator Account Management

Administrator accounts are created exclusively by Super Administrators through the admin panel interface. This restricted creation process ensures proper authorization and accountability. The Super Administrator provides the new administrator's full name, email address that will serve as their username, and assigns an initial temporary password that must be changed upon first login.

Administrator accounts can be assigned different permission levels beyond the standard admin role. Super Administrators can designate certain administrators as having restricted permissions limited to specific functions such as vendor approval only, product moderation only, or customer support only. This granular permission system enables appropriate delegation while maintaining security.

All administrator actions are logged in the activity log table with entries capturing the admin user ID, action type such as vendor approved or payout processed, affected entity type and ID, IP address from which the action originated, timestamp, and any relevant notes or reasons provided. This audit trail enables accountability and security monitoring.

Administrators can change their own passwords through account settings but cannot modify their permission levels. Password changes require entry of current password for verification before accepting the new password. Super Administrators can force password resets for administrator accounts if necessary for security purposes.

3.2 Product Catalog Management

3.2.1 Category Management

The category system provides hierarchical organization of products with support for nested subcategories up to three levels deep. Categories facilitate browsing, filtering, and product discovery while ensuring logical organization of the marketplace.

Category Creation by Vendors

Vendors can create new categories directly from their dashboard when no existing category appropriately fits their products. This capability reduces time-to-market and enables the platform to adapt quickly to new product types and markets. When a vendor creates a category, they provide a category name that must be unique within the category hierarchy and clearly describe the product type, an optional parent category if this is a subcategory rather than a top-level category, a detailed description explaining what products belong in this category, and optional metadata including keywords for search and a category image representing products in this category.

Upon submission, the system creates the category record with status set to pending and created_by field storing the vendor's ID. The category immediately becomes usable by the creating vendor for their own product listings but remains invisible to other vendors and customers until approved. This allows the vendor to continue their workflow without interruption while giving administrators time for review.

The system sends notification to administrators that a new category is pending review, including the category name, description, requesting vendor identity, and link to review interface. Administrators receive these notifications both as email and as in-app notification count displayed prominently in the admin panel header.

Category Review and Approval

Administrators access pending category requests through a dedicated queue displaying all pending categories with relevant metadata. For each pending category, administrators can view the proposed category name and description, the vendor who requested it, how many products the vendor has already listed in this pending category, whether similar or duplicate categories already exist, and the proposed position in the category hierarchy.

Administrators can take one of three actions on each pending category. They can approve the category, which changes its status to active, makes it visible and usable by all vendors platform-wide, preserves all products already listed in this category by the requesting vendor, and sends notification email to the requesting vendor confirming approval. They can reject the category with reason, which changes status to rejected, stores the administrator's rejection reason in category_requests history table, automatically moves all products from the rejected category to a recommended alternative category suggested by the administrator, and sends notification to vendor explaining rejection with guidance on correct category to use. They can modify and approve, which allows the administrator to edit the category name or description before approval if only minor adjustments are needed, changes status to active with modified details, and notifies the requesting vendor of the approval with note about modifications made.

All category actions are logged in the activity_logs table capturing which administrator performed the action, what action was taken, the category details, and timestamp. This maintains accountability and enables later review of category management decisions.

Category Organization and Management

Approved categories can be organized hierarchically by administrators assigning parent-child relationships. Top-level categories have no parent, while subcategories reference a parent category ID. The system enforces a maximum depth of three levels to prevent overly complex navigation structures that confuse customers.

Each category maintains attributes including name, slug for URL-friendly representation automatically generated from name, description for customer understanding, parent category ID if this is a subcategory, display order determining sort order in navigation menus, status whether active or inactive, and metadata including image URL, SEO title and description, and created/updated timestamps.

Categories track usage statistics including product count showing how many products are currently listed in this category, which is updated automatically by database triggers when products are added or removed, and vendor count showing how many different vendors have products in this category. These statistics help administrators identify popular categories and detect unused categories that might be candidates for merger or removal.

Administrators can deactivate categories that are no longer relevant or need temporary removal. Deactivating a category makes it invisible to customers but does not delete it or affect existing products. Products in deactivated categories remain associated with that category but are hidden from customer browsing. Vendors can still view and manage these products but cannot create new products in deactivated categories.

Category deletion is restricted and requires moving all products to alternative categories before deletion can proceed. This prevents orphaned products and ensures data integrity. The system prevents deletion of categories containing products, requiring the administrator to first reassign those products to appropriate alternative categories.

3.2.2 Product Attribute Templates

Product attribute templates provide standardized, reusable definitions for product attributes that ensure consistency across products within the same category. These templates significantly reduce vendor workload when listing products and enable reliable filtering and comparison for customers.

Template Creation and Management

Administrators create attribute templates at the category level through the admin panel. Each template defines a standardized attribute that products in that category can use. Templates are not global but are associated with specific categories, allowing different product types to have relevant attributes. For example, the Electronics category might have attributes for "Screen Size" and "Battery Life" while the Clothing category has "Size" and "Material."

Creating an attribute template requires specifying the attribute name such as "Brand," "Color," "Size," or "Material," the data type which determines how data is stored and displayed including text for free-form text entry, number for numeric values with optional unit, select for single-choice dropdown with predefined options, multiselect for multiple-choice with predefined options, and boolean for yes/no or true/false values. Additional configuration includes whether this attribute is required, meaning vendors must provide a value when listing products in this category, whether it is filterable so customers can filter products by this attribute value on category pages, whether it creates variants meaning this attribute defines product variants requiring separate SKU and inventory for each value combination, validation rules such as minimum and maximum values for numbers or regular expression patterns for text, and display order determining the sequence in which attributes appear in product listings and filters.

For select and multiselect type attributes, administrators define predefined options that vendors can choose from. Each option has a value, display label that may differ from the stored value, whether the option is active or deprecated, and display order within the dropdown. For example, a "Color" attribute might have options of "Red," "Blue," "Green," "Black," and "White" rather than allowing vendors to enter arbitrary color names that might vary in spelling or naming conventions.

Administrators can designate certain attributes as variant-defining, which indicates that different values of this attribute represent distinct purchasable versions of a product. For example, in the Clothing category, "Size" and "Color" are typically variant attributes because customers purchase a specific size and color combination. When vendors create products using variant-defining attributes, the system automatically generates all possible variant combinations and requires the vendor to set inventory and pricing for each.

Template Assignment to Categories

Each category can have multiple attribute templates assigned to it, creating a comprehensive set of standardized attributes for that product type. When administrators assign templates to a category, those templates become available to all vendors creating products in that category. Subcategories inherit attribute templates from their parent categories, allowing consistent attributes across related category families, though administrators can add category-specific templates to subcategories for additional granularity.

Template assignment creates a relationship between the category and the template with an inheritance mode of either inheriting all parent templates plus any category-specific additions or replacing parent templates entirely with category-specific templates only. This flexibility accommodates both refinement of parent attributes and complete overhaul for significantly different subcategory product types.

Vendor Usage of Templates

When vendors create products, the system presents all attribute templates assigned to the selected category. Required attributes are marked prominently and must be filled before the product can be saved. The interface adapts based on attribute type, showing appropriate input controls such as text fields for text attributes, number spinners for numeric attributes, dropdowns for select attributes, or checkboxes for multiselect attributes.

For select and multiselect attributes, vendors choose from the predefined options rather than entering free-form text. This ensures consistency and reliable filtering. If a vendor needs an option not present in the predefined list, they can request addition of that option through a feedback mechanism, but cannot add it themselves to maintain data quality.

Variant-defining attributes trigger the variant generation interface when vendors assign values. If a product has two variant attributes such as "Size" with values "Small," "Medium," "Large" and "Color" with values "Red," "Blue," the system generates all combinations including "Small/Red," "Small/Blue," "Medium/Red," "Medium/Blue," "Large/Red," and "Large/Blue" as separate variants. Each variant requires its own SKU, price, and inventory quantity.

3.2.3 Product Listing

Vendors create product listings through a comprehensive form in the vendor dashboard that guides them through all required information. The process differs slightly between simple products with single pricing and inventory versus variable products with multiple variants.

Simple Product Creation

Simple products represent items with no variations in attributes that affect purchasing decisions. A simple product might be a specific book title, a unique piece of artwork, or a non-configurable electronic device. Creating a simple product requires the vendor to provide basic information including product name that clearly identifies the item, product category selected from approved categories or categories pending approval that the vendor created, detailed description explaining features, benefits, specifications, and any other relevant information, brand name if applicable, and SKU (Stock Keeping Unit) that must be unique within the vendor's inventory.

Pricing information includes regular price as the standard selling price, optional sale price if the product is currently discounted with sale price being less than regular price, and optional sale period defining start and end dates for the sale price. If sale period is specified, the system automatically switches between regular and sale prices based on current date.

Inventory management requires stock quantity representing the number of units available for sale, low stock threshold at which the vendor receives alert notification, and stock status manually set by vendor as in stock, out of stock, or discontinued. The system automatically updates stock status to out of stock when quantity reaches zero.

Product images can be uploaded with support for multiple images per product. The vendor uploads images in JPEG, PNG, or WebP format with maximum 5MB per image and maximum dimensions of 5000 by 5000 pixels. The first image becomes the primary image displayed in product listings, while additional images appear in the product detail page gallery. Vendors can reorder images by dragging and dropping.

Additional options include product weight and dimensions for shipping calculation purposes, whether the product is featured which may be set only by administrators, whether reviews are enabled for this product with default being enabled, SEO metadata including meta title, meta description, and keywords, and tags for additional categorization and search.

Upon saving a simple product, the system validates all required fields, generates URL-friendly slug from product name if not provided, processes uploaded images creating multiple sizes including thumbnail, small, medium, and large versions, updates search index with product information for fast searching, and makes the product immediately available to customers without requiring approval.

Variable Product Creation

Variable products represent items that come in multiple configurations based on attributes such as size, color, or material. Each configuration is a separate variant with its own SKU, price, and inventory. Examples include clothing available in different sizes and colors, electronics with different storage capacities, or furniture available in different materials and colors.

Creating a variable product begins with the same basic information as simple products including name, category, description, brand, and images. However, instead of setting a single price and inventory, the vendor defines the variant-creating attributes and their possible values.

The system presents all variant-defining attributes assigned to the product's category through attribute templates. The vendor selects which attributes apply to their specific product and specifies the values offered. For example, if the "Clothing" category has "Size" and "Color" as variant attributes, the vendor might select sizes "Small," "Medium," "Large" and colors "Red," "Blue," "Black."

Once attributes and values are defined, the system generates all possible variant combinations automatically. For the example above, this creates nine variants: "Small/Red," "Small/Blue," "Small/Black," "Medium/Red," "Medium/Blue," "Medium/Black," "Large/Red," "Large/Blue," "Large/Black." The vendor must then provide specific information for each variant including unique SKU, price which can differ between variants, stock quantity for this specific variant, and optionally variant-specific images showing the actual color or style of this variant.

Vendors can bulk-edit certain fields across all variants to reduce repetitive data entry. For example, they might set the same price for all size/color combinations, then adjust individual variants as needed for size-based pricing differences. Similarly, inventory can be set in bulk and then adjusted for variants with different availability.

The variant table displays all combinations with editable fields for each, allowing efficient management. Vendors can disable specific variants if certain combinations are not actually available, for example if "Large/Red" is not offered even though both Large sizes and Red colors exist separately.

3.3 Inventory Management

3.3.1 Stock Tracking

The system maintains real-time inventory levels for all products and variants, tracking available stock, reserved stock, and pending order stock separately to prevent overselling while providing accurate availability information to customers.

Each product or variant has a total stock quantity representing the raw number of units the vendor has physically available. This quantity is managed directly by the vendor through their dashboard where they can adjust stock levels as shipments arrive or inventory is corrected.

Available stock, which is what customers see when viewing products, is calculated dynamically as total stock minus reserved stock from active cart reservations minus pending stock from paid orders not yet fulfilled. This calculation is implemented as a database function that runs on each query, ensuring availability reflects current system state.

The system creates stock reservations automatically when customers add items to their cart. A reservation locks a specified quantity of a product or variant for 24 hours, preventing other customers from purchasing that inventory while the first customer completes checkout. If checkout is not completed within 24 hours, the reservation expires automatically and the stock becomes available again.

Reserved stock is visible to vendors in their inventory dashboard with details showing how many units are in active carts and when those reservations expire. This visibility helps vendors understand why available stock may be less than total stock even without confirmed orders.

When a customer completes payment for an order, the system moves stock from reserved state to pending state. Pending stock represents orders that are paid but not yet shipped or completed. This stock is definitively committed to an order and will not return to available inventory unless the order is cancelled.

Vendors update order status through their dashboard, marking orders as processing, shipped, delivered, or completed. As orders progress through these states, the stock tracking evolves but the physical quantity does not return to available stock since it has been sold.

3.3.2 Low Stock Alerts

Vendors configure low stock thresholds for each product or variant to receive notifications when inventory drops below specified levels. These alerts enable proactive restocking and prevent stockouts that result in lost sales.

The low stock threshold is set as a numeric quantity such as 5 or 10 units. When available stock drops to or below this threshold, the system generates a low stock alert. Alerts are delivered through multiple channels including email to the vendor's registered email address, in-app notification displayed prominently in the vendor dashboard, and optionally SMS if the vendor has configured SMS notifications and provided a mobile number.

Low stock alerts are generated once when the threshold is crossed and again if stock continues to drop significantly. The system does not send repeated alerts for the same stock level to avoid notification fatigue. Once the vendor restocks and available quantity rises above the threshold, the alert is cleared and the system is ready to generate a new alert if stock drops again.

Vendors can adjust thresholds at any time based on their restocking patterns and sales velocity. Different products can have different thresholds reflecting different importance levels or different supplier lead times. High-volume fast-moving products might have higher thresholds of 50 units while slower items might have thresholds of 5 units.

The vendor dashboard displays a prominent low stock widget showing all products currently below threshold sorted by severity, with products at zero stock shown first followed by products below threshold in ascending order of available quantity. This provides quick visibility into inventory requiring attention.

3.3.3 Inventory Adjustments

Vendors need the ability to adjust inventory quantities for various operational reasons including receiving shipments, identifying damaged or missing units, and correcting data entry errors. The system provides manual adjustment functionality with full audit trailing.

When a vendor needs to adjust inventory, they navigate to the specific product or variant in their dashboard and select the inventory adjustment function. They specify the adjustment type such as addition for receiving stock, subtraction for removing damaged units, or absolute set to directly set the quantity to a specific number regardless of current value.

For addition and subtraction adjustments, the vendor enters the quantity to add or remove along with a mandatory reason code selected from predefined options including restock from supplier, customer return, damaged goods, lost or stolen, correction, and other with free-text note required. These reason codes enable later analysis of inventory changes and identify patterns.

The system records every adjustment in the inventory_movements table capturing the product or variant ID, adjustment type whether addition, subtraction, or set, quantity changed, previous quantity before adjustment, new quantity after adjustment, reason code and notes, vendor user who performed adjustment, and timestamp of adjustment. This complete audit trail enables vendors to track inventory changes over time and identify issues.

Bulk adjustment functionality allows vendors to upload CSV files containing adjustment data for multiple products simultaneously. This is particularly useful after physical inventory counts where many products need quantity corrections. The CSV format includes columns for SKU, adjustment type, quantity, and reason. The system validates the file, processes all adjustments, and provides a summary report of successful adjustments and any errors encountered.

Inventory adjustments trigger related system behavior including updating available stock calculation immediately, canceling stock reservations if the adjustment reduces quantity below reserved levels with notifications sent to affected customers, and generating low stock alerts if adjustments cause quantity to drop below threshold.

3.4 Order Management

3.4.1 Shopping Cart

The shopping cart provides customers with a temporary holding area for products they intend to purchase before proceeding to checkout. Carts support guest users and registered customers with different persistence behaviors.

When a customer adds a product to their cart, they specify the quantity desired for simple products or select a specific variant before adding for variable products. The system validates that requested quantity does not exceed available stock before allowing the addition. If insufficient stock exists, the customer sees an error message indicating maximum available quantity.

Upon successful addition, the system creates a cart record for the customer if one does not already exist and adds a cart item record linking to the product or variant with specified quantity. The system simultaneously creates a stock reservation holding that quantity for 24 hours to prevent overselling.

Registered customers have persistent carts that survive logout and can be accessed from any device where they log in. The cart ID is associated with the customer's user account. Guest customers have session-based carts tied to a browser cookie. If the guest converts to a registered customer by creating an account or logging in during checkout, their guest cart is migrated to their customer account.

Customers can modify cart contents at any time before checkout. They can increase quantity for an item, which validates sufficient stock and extends the stock reservation, decrease quantity which reduces the stock reservation by the corresponding amount, remove items entirely which cancels the associated stock reservation, or clear the entire cart which removes all items and cancels all reservations.

The cart display shows each item with product image, name, selected variant attributes if applicable, unit price, quantity selector, subtotal for that item calculated as unit price times quantity, and remove button. The cart footer displays cart subtotal summing all item subtotals, estimated tax if applicable, estimated shipping if calculable based on current information, and estimated total. These values update dynamically as customers modify quantities.

Cart items that have become unavailable due to other customers purchasing the stock, vendors adjusting inventory, or products being removed from the platform are clearly marked as unavailable in the cart. Customers cannot proceed to checkout with unavailable items and must remove them from cart first. This prevents order placement for products that cannot be fulfilled.

Stock reservations expire automatically after 24 hours if the customer does not complete checkout. The system runs a scheduled task every hour that identifies expired reservations, marks them as expired, and releases the stock back to available inventory. Customers whose reservations have expired see updated availability when they return to their cart and may find items no longer available if other customers have since purchased that stock.

3.4.2 Checkout Process

The checkout process guides customers through finalizing their purchase with a multi-step interface ensuring all necessary information is collected before payment. The process accommodates both guest checkout and registered customer checkout with appropriate information collection for each scenario.

Customer Information

Registered customers who are logged in proceed directly to address selection as their account information is already available. Guest customers must provide contact information including email address for order confirmation and updates and full name for shipping purposes. The system validates email format and checks for existing account with that email, prompting the guest to log in if an account exists or offering to create an account with entered information during checkout.

Shipping Address

Customers select a shipping address for the order. Registered customers can choose from previously saved addresses or add a new address that will be saved to their account for future use. Guest customers enter address information for this order without saving capability.

Address entry requires full name of recipient, address line 1 with street number and name, optional address line 2 for apartment or suite number, city or locality, state or province or region, postal code, country selected from dropdown, and phone number for delivery contact purposes.

Customers can mark an address as default, which automatically selects it for future orders. The system allows only one default address per customer and unsets previous default when a new one is designated.

Shipping Method

After address entry, the system calculates available shipping methods and costs based on the shipping address, products in cart, and configured shipping options. Shipping methods might include standard shipping with estimated delivery in 5-7 business days, expedited shipping with delivery in 2-3 business days, and overnight shipping with next business day delivery.

Each shipping method displays the cost and estimated delivery timeframe. Customers select their preferred method, which updates the order total to include the shipping cost.

Order Review

The order review step presents a comprehensive summary of the complete order before payment. Customers see each ordered item with image, name, variant attributes, quantity, and price; the selected shipping address; the selected shipping method and cost; the calculated tax amount; any applied coupon discount; and the final order total.

Customers can return to previous steps to modify address, shipping method, or cart contents before proceeding. Once satisfied with the order details, they proceed to payment.

Payment

The payment step offers available payment methods based on platform configuration. Stripe integration provides credit and debit card payment through embedded Stripe Elements, which captures card information securely without the platform storing any card data. PayPal integration enables payment through PayPal account with redirect to PayPal login and payment approval before returning to complete order. Cash on Delivery option allows customers to pay in cash when receiving the order, available only if enabled by platform administrators and may be restricted based on order total or customer history.

For card payments through Stripe, customers enter card number, expiration date, CVC code, and billing postal code directly into Stripe-hosted form elements. The system creates a payment intent with Stripe, submits the payment method for authorization, and handles 3D Secure authentication if required by the card issuer.

Upon successful payment authorization, the system creates the order record, creates order items for each cart product with quantities and prices captured from cart at the time of order, marks the payment as authorized or paid, sends order confirmation email to customer, sends new order notification emails to each vendor with items in the order, and clears the customer's cart and cancels all stock reservations as they are now converted to confirmed orders.

If payment fails due to insufficient funds, declined card, or other payment errors, the system displays the error message from the payment gateway, retains the cart and stock reservations, and allows the customer to try again with the same or different payment method. The cart items remain reserved throughout payment attempts within the reservation timeout period.

3.4.3 Order Processing

Once an order is placed, it enters the order processing workflow managed collaboratively by vendors and platform administrators. Each order progresses through defined status states from placement through completion or cancellation.

Order States

Orders begin in pending status immediately after successful payment authorization. This status indicates the order is confirmed but not yet being actively fulfilled. Vendors see pending orders in their dashboard and can begin preparing items for shipment.

When a vendor begins working on an order, they update its status to processing. This status communicates to the customer that their order is being prepared and indicates to administrators that the vendor is actively fulfilling the order. Processing status is typically used while picking items from inventory and packaging them for shipment.

Once items are packaged and handed to shipping carrier, vendors update status to shipped and provide tracking information including carrier name and tracking number. The system sends email to customer notifying them of shipment with tracking details and estimated delivery date if provided.

When the carrier confirms delivery, vendors can update status to delivered indicating the customer has received the order. Some platforms may receive automatic delivery confirmation from shipping carrier integrations, while others rely on vendor manual updates.

After delivery and when any return period has passed without issues, orders can be marked completed. This status indicates the transaction is final and triggers commission release from pending to released status, making vendor earnings available for payout.

Vendor Order Management

Vendors access their assigned orders through the vendor dashboard, which displays all orders containing their products. Since orders may contain products from multiple vendors, each vendor sees only the items they need to fulfill along with relevant customer information.

The order detail view shows customer shipping address, customer contact email and phone, ordered items from this vendor with quantities and prices, payment status confirming payment received, current order status, and order timeline showing status change history.

Vendors can update order status through dropdown selection or dedicated action buttons. When marking an order as shipped, they must provide shipping carrier name and tracking number to enable customer tracking. The system validates tracking number format if known patterns exist for common carriers.

Vendors can add notes to orders for internal reference or customer communication. Notes marked as customer-visible appear in the customer's order tracking page, enabling vendors to provide updates or request information from customers. Internal notes remain visible only to the vendor and platform administrators.

If a vendor determines they cannot fulfill an order due to stock discrepancies, product damage, or other issues, they can request cancellation through the platform. The request notifies administrators who review the situation, approve cancellation if justified, and process refund to the customer. This workflow ensures accountability and prevents vendors from arbitrarily cancelling orders.

Multi-Vendor Order Splitting

When a customer's order contains products from multiple vendors, the system automatically splits the order for fulfillment purposes while maintaining a single unified order from the customer's perspective. The customer receives one order number and sees one order total, but behind the scenes the system creates vendor-specific order records.

Each vendor receives notification only about their portion of the order with items they need to fulfill, the appropriate shipping address, and their portion of shipping cost if shipping is split proportionally. Vendors fulfill their items independently and update status for their portion without affecting other vendors' portions.

From the customer perspective, the order detail page shows all items together grouped by vendor. Each vendor group displays current fulfillment status, tracking information when available, and option to contact the specific vendor. The overall order status reflects the least progressed vendor, meaning the order shows as processing until all vendors have shipped, and shows as shipped only when all vendors have shipped their portions.

Shipping costs and tax are calculated and displayed as single amounts to the customer but are attributed to vendors proportionally based on their items' share of the order subtotal. This ensures transparent accounting while presenting a clean interface to customers.

3.4.4 Order Cancellation

Order cancellation allows orders to be stopped and reversed before shipping occurs, with automatic refund processing and inventory restoration. Cancellation can be initiated by customers, vendors, or administrators depending on order status and reason.

Customer-Initiated Cancellation

Customers can cancel their own orders through the order detail page in their account dashboard, but only while the order is in pending or processing status. Once an order reaches shipped status, customer-initiated cancellation is no longer available and customers must instead initiate a return if they no longer want the items.

To cancel an order, the customer clicks the cancel order button and confirms their intent through a dialog warning them that this action cannot be undone. Upon confirmation, the system validates that order status allows cancellation, updates order status to cancelled, processes full refund through the original payment method, restores inventory for all order items back to available stock, records cancellation in order history with timestamp and reason "cancelled by customer," and sends cancellation confirmation email to customer with refund details and sends notification to affected vendors that their order has been cancelled.

If the order payment has not yet been captured, such as with payment authorization that is captured upon shipping, the cancellation simply releases the authorization without any funds having transferred. If payment has been captured, the system processes refund through the payment gateway, which typically takes 3-5 business days to reflect in the customer's account depending on their financial institution.

Vendor-Initiated Cancellation

Vendors can request cancellation of orders assigned to them when they discover they cannot fulfill the order due to inventory discrepancies, damaged product, or other fulfillment issues. Vendor-requested cancellations require administrator approval to prevent abuse.

The vendor navigates to the order detail page and selects request cancellation, providing a mandatory reason from predefined options including product out of stock, product damaged, customer unresponsive when information needed, pricing error, or other with text explanation required. The system creates a cancellation request record visible to administrators and sends notification to administrators for review.

Administrators review cancellation requests in their admin panel, seeing the order details, vendor's stated reason, customer information, and payment status. They can approve the cancellation, which processes it similar to customer cancellation with full refund and inventory restoration, reject the cancellation request if the reason is not justified and require the vendor to fulfill the order, or contact the vendor for more information before making a decision.

Approved vendor cancellations trigger the same workflow as customer cancellations including order status update to cancelled, full refund processing, inventory restoration, and notification emails. The order history records "cancelled by vendor" as the reason along with the administrator who approved the request.

Rejected cancellation requests return the order to its previous status with notification to the vendor that they must fulfill the order or risk account penalties. Repeated unjustified cancellation requests may result in vendor account suspension.

Administrator-Initiated Cancellation

Administrators can cancel any order at any time regardless of current status. This capability is used for resolving disputes, handling fraudulent orders, or addressing system errors. Administrator cancellations bypass approval workflows since administrators have ultimate authority.

When an administrator cancels an order, they provide a mandatory reason and optional notes explaining the decision. The system processes the cancellation with full refund if payment was collected, inventory restoration, status update to cancelled, recording of admin identity and reason in order history, and notification to both customer and affected vendors explaining the cancellation.

Administrator cancellations may occur even after orders are shipped in cases of payment fraud or dispute resolution. In such cases, the administrator may handle refund differently, potentially issuing partial refund or coordinating return of items before refund. The system provides flexibility for administrators to manage these complex scenarios.

3.4.5 Returns and Refunds

The return and refund system handles post-delivery situations where customers are not satisfied with received items. This system operates separately from cancellation since items have already been shipped and possibly delivered.

Return Initiation

Customers can initiate returns through their order detail page for orders in delivered or completed status within a specified return window, typically 30 days from delivery date though vendors can configure different windows for their products. To start a return, the customer selects which items from the order they wish to return, specifies quantity if returning less than the full ordered quantity, and provides a reason from predefined options including item defective or damaged, item not as described, ordered wrong item by mistake, found better price elsewhere, or no longer needed.

For defective or not-as-described returns, customers can upload photos documenting the issue to support their claim. These images are visible to the vendor and administrator during return review. The system creates a return request record containing order and item references, requested items and quantities, customer's stated reason and uploaded evidence, status set to pending review, and timestamps.

The system sends notification to the vendor whose products are being returned, alerting them to review the request in their dashboard. Vendors typically have 48 hours to respond to return requests before they are automatically approved.

Return Review

Vendors review return requests through their dashboard interface showing all pending return requests with relevant details. For each request, vendors can approve the return, which authorizes the customer to ship items back and commits to processing refund upon receipt, reject the return if they believe it is not valid, providing mandatory reason and justification, or request more information from the customer such as additional photos or clarification of the issue, placing the return on hold pending customer response.

Approved returns generate a return authorization number (RMA) displayed to the customer along with return shipping instructions including vendor's return address and how to ship items. The return status updates to approved pending return shipment.

Rejected returns update to status rejected with vendor's reason stored and displayed to customer. Customers who disagree with rejection can escalate to administrators for dispute resolution. The system provides clear escalation path so customers do not feel trapped by vendor rejections.

Return Shipment

Once a return is approved, customers ship the items back to the vendor following provided instructions. Customers are responsible for return shipping costs unless the return reason indicates vendor error such as defective or wrong item, in which case vendors should provide prepaid return labels.

When the customer ships the return, they enter tracking information into the return request interface so the vendor can monitor return transit. The system updates return status to in transit and sends notification to vendor that return is on its way.

Upon receiving returned items, vendors inspect them to verify they match the return request, are in acceptable condition, and meet any restocking conditions specified in return policies. Vendors then update the return status to received and mark whether items are in acceptable condition.

Refund Processing

If returned items are in acceptable condition, vendors process the refund through the platform interface. The refund can be full amount if entire order value is being returned or partial amount for partial returns or restocking fees. The system processes the refund through the original payment method, typically taking 3-5 business days to appear in customer's account.

Processing a refund triggers several system actions including updating return status to refunded, restoring the returned quantity to vendor's inventory making it available for sale again, reversing the commission on the returned items so the platform does not keep commission on refunded sales, recording the refund in payment history, and sending confirmation to customer with refund amount and expected timeline.

If returned items are not in acceptable condition, such as showing signs of use beyond trying on or testing, missing original packaging, or differing from what was shipped, vendors can reject the refund. This requires uploading photos of received items and detailed explanation of why condition is unacceptable. The return status updates to refund denied and the system notifies the customer.

Customers who disagree with refund denial can escalate to administrators who review the vendor's photos and reasoning, customer's original photos if provided, return policies and whether they were clearly communicated, and make final decision on whether refund should be processed. Administrator decisions are final and binding on vendors.

Restocking and Inventory Handling

Returned items require careful inventory management to maintain accuracy. When a return is initiated and approved, the system does not immediately restore inventory because items are not yet physically back in vendor's possession. Only when the vendor marks the return as received and items as acceptable does the system restore inventory.

Vendors can designate returned items for different inventory dispositions. Items in perfect condition can be returned to regular stock with full quantity restoration. Items with minor issues like missing original packaging can be returned to stock with a note or added to a separate discounted inventory. Items too damaged to resell can be written off without inventory restoration.

This granular control ensures vendors maintain accurate inventory levels that reflect only actually sellable units while properly accounting for returns.

Administrator Oversight

Administrators have visibility into all return requests and can intervene at any point in the process. They can review return request details including customer's reason and evidence, vendor's response or lack thereof, and communications between customer and vendor. Administrators can override vendor decisions approving returns that vendors rejected or rejecting returns that vendors approved if review indicates improper decision, force refund processing if vendors are unresponsive or non-compliant, and adjust refund amounts if partial refunds are more appropriate than vendor's proposed amount.

All administrator actions on returns are logged with reasoning recorded for accountability. Patterns of problematic behavior by vendors such as systematic rejection of valid returns, failure to respond to return requests, or processing refunds slowly can be identified through reporting and addressed through account warnings or suspension.

3.5 Commission and Payout System

3.5.1 Commission Calculation

The platform generates revenue by charging commission on vendor sales. Commission is calculated as a percentage of the order value and is determined at the time of order placement based on the vendor's commission rate.

Commission Structure

Each vendor has an assigned commission rate stored in their vendor record. This rate is expressed as a percentage such as 10.00 for ten percent. Commission rates can be customized per vendor by administrators or default to the platform-wide rate configured in system settings.

When an order is placed, the system calculates commission for each order item using the formula commission equals item total price minus item discount times commission rate divided by 100. This calculation applies to the actual amount the customer paid, not the original price if discounts were applied.

For example, if a customer purchases an item with regular price $100 and applied a $10 coupon, the item total is $90. With a 10 percent commission rate, the commission would be $90 times 0.10 equals $9. The vendor receives $90 minus $9 equals $81, not considering payment gateway fees.

Gateway Fees

Payment gateway fees are also deducted from the vendor's payout. These fees vary by gateway and are typically a percentage plus fixed amount per transaction. For instance, Stripe charges 2.9 percent plus $0.30 per transaction. Gateway fees are calculated based on the full order total that was charged to the customer, not the vendor's portion if the order contains items from multiple vendors.

For orders containing multiple vendors, gateway fees are split proportionally based on each vendor's share of the order subtotal. The system calculates each vendor's proportion of the order, then applies that proportion to the gateway fee. This ensures fair distribution of transaction costs.

Commission States

Commission records progress through three states tracking payment status. When an order is first placed and payment is received, commission status is pending. Pending commission represents amounts that are committed but not yet available for payout because the order might still be returned or cancelled. Pending commission does not count toward vendor's available balance for payout requests.

When an order reaches delivered status and the return window passes without any return being initiated, commission status changes to released. Released commission is available for payout and appears in the vendor's available balance. This transition typically occurs 30 days after delivery to account for standard return windows.

When a vendor receives a payout that includes certain commission amounts, those commission records are marked as paid and associated with the payout record. Paid commission is final and cannot be reversed except through manual administrator intervention in case of disputes.

Commission Reporting

Vendors can view detailed commission reports through their dashboard showing commission breakdown by order with order number, date, customer name, order total, commission amount, gateway fee, net payout amount, and current commission status. Summary statistics include total pending commission, total released commission available for payout, total paid commission already received, and lifetime earnings across all time.

Administrators access comprehensive commission reports across all vendors showing total commission earned by the platform, commission by vendor to identify top revenue contributors, commission trends over time to track platform growth, and commission by category to understand which product types are most profitable.

3.5.2 Vendor Payouts

Payouts transfer accumulated vendor earnings from the platform to vendor bank accounts. The payout system ensures vendors are paid regularly for their sales while protecting the platform from paying out funds that may need to be refunded.

Payout Eligibility

Vendors become eligible for payout when their available balance, the sum of all released commission minus any previously paid amounts, reaches the minimum payout threshold configured by administrators typically set at $50 or $100 to minimize transaction costs. Vendors can view their available balance in real-time through their dashboard.

The system displays a prominent indicator when a vendor reaches payout eligibility, such as a notification banner and highlighted balance display. Vendors can then initiate a payout request or wait until their balance grows further to reduce payout frequency and associated processing fees.

Payout Request

Vendors initiate payout requests through their dashboard by navigating to the earnings or payouts section and clicking request payout. The system displays their current available balance, previously configured banking information obscuring sensitive details like showing only last four digits of account number, and confirms the payout amount they will receive.

The vendor confirms the request which creates a payout request record with status pending and amount set to available balance at time of request. The payout request is queued for administrator review and processing. Vendors receive confirmation that their request has been received and are given an estimated processing timeframe typically 3-5 business days.

Administrator Payout Processing

Administrators review pending payout requests in a dedicated queue within the admin panel. Each request displays vendor business name, requested amount, vendor's bank account details fully visible to admin but properly encrypted in storage, vendor's commission history showing source of the payout amount, and any notes or flags that might indicate issues.

Administrators can process payouts individually or in batches for efficiency. When processing a payout, administrators have several options. They can approve and mark as processing, which updates the payout status indicating funds are being transferred, or they can reject with reason if there are issues with bank account information, suspected fraud, or policy violations, returning the commission back to the vendor's available balance.

For actual fund transfer, the platform typically uses bank transfer or ACH for domestic transactions or wire transfer for international payments. Some platforms may integrate with payment facilitation services like Stripe Connect or PayPal Payouts for automated payout processing.

When funds are successfully transferred, administrators mark the payout as completed, providing the transaction reference number from the bank or payment service. The system updates payout status to paid, marks all included commission records as paid status and associates them with this payout ID, generates a payout receipt PDF that vendors can download for their records, and sends confirmation email to vendor with payout details and transaction reference.

If the transfer fails due to invalid account details or other banking issues, the payout status updates to failed with error details captured. The commission amounts are returned to the vendor's available balance, and the vendor is notified to update their banking information.

Payout History

Vendors can view complete payout history showing all past payouts with payout ID and reference number, date requested and date paid, amount paid, transfer method used, and status whether paid or failed. Each payout entry links to a detailed breakdown showing which specific orders and commission amounts were included in that payout.

Administrators maintain comprehensive payout records across all vendors including total amount paid out, average payout processing time to monitor efficiency, success rate of payout transfers to identify systematic issues, and payout distribution by vendor to understand payment patterns.

3.5.3 Commission Adjustments

Occasionally, commission amounts need adjustment after initial calculation due to returns, refunds, cancellations, or errors. The system provides mechanisms for automatic adjustments in routine scenarios and manual adjustments for exceptional cases.

Automatic Adjustments for Returns and Refunds

When an order is cancelled before shipping, all associated commission records are automatically deleted or marked as void since no sale occurred. If the commission was in pending status, this does not affect any payouts. If somehow the commission had been released, the system creates a reversal record subtracting that amount from the vendor's available balance.

For returns processed after delivery, the system creates negative commission records offsetting the original commission amounts. If a customer returns $50 worth of products from an order that had $5 commission, the system creates a negative $5 commission adjustment. This adjustment immediately reduces the vendor's available balance if the original commission was released, or simply offsets the pending commission if not yet released.

If the vendor already received payout including that commission, the negative adjustment puts their account into negative balance for future payouts. Their next payout will include this negative amount, effectively recovering the commission. Administrators can monitor vendors with negative balances and may pursue recovery through platform fees or account restrictions if necessary.

Manual Adjustments

Administrators can create manual commission adjustments for special circumstances such as correcting calculation errors, applying penalties or bonuses, handling disputes, or compensating for platform issues that affected sales.

To create a manual adjustment, administrators navigate to the vendor's commission page and select create manual adjustment. They specify adjustment type whether credit adding to balance or debit subtracting from balance, amount, reason selected from predefined categories or custom reason, detailed notes explaining the adjustment, and whether the adjustment is immediately applied to available balance or to pending balance.

Manual adjustments create commission records just like order-based commission but with special markers indicating they are administrator-created. These adjustments appear in the vendor's commission history with clear indication of their origin and reasoning.
