All manual adjustments are logged in the activity log with the administrator's identity for accountability.

Administrators should use manual adjustments sparingly and document them thoroughly since they directly impact vendor earnings and trust. Patterns of frequent manual adjustments may indicate systemic issues requiring investigation.

3.6 Review and Rating System

3.6.1 Writing Reviews

Customers who have purchased and received products can write reviews sharing their experience with future buyers. Reviews include star ratings and optional written feedback, helping customers make informed purchasing decisions.

Review Eligibility

Only customers who have actually purchased a product can review it, verified through order history. This verified purchase requirement prevents fake reviews and ensures reviews come from actual product users. Customers can write one review per product they have purchased, though they can edit their review after posting.

Customers become eligible to review a product once their order containing that product reaches delivered status. The system does not require waiting until the order is completed, allowing timely reviews while product experience is fresh. Customers can review products from their order history page, where each delivered order displays a review button next to products not yet reviewed.

Review Creation

The review form prompts customers for a rating from one to five stars, where one star represents very dissatisfied and five stars represents very satisfied. This rating is mandatory and represents the customer's overall satisfaction. Optional components include a review title serving as a short summary, detailed review text with a maximum of 5000 characters explaining their experience, and photos showing the received product, how they use it, or any issues encountered, with up to five images at 5MB each.

The review is initially saved in pending status and undergoes review by the vendor or administrators depending on platform policy. Customers receive confirmation that their review was submitted and will be published after moderation. The moderation process typically completes within 24-48 hours.

Review Moderation

Reviews must be moderated before publication to prevent spam, profanity, or inappropriate content while protecting vendor reputation from unfair attacks. The moderation workflow can be configured to allow either vendor moderation where vendors can approve or reject reviews of their products, administrator moderation where only admins moderate all reviews, or automatic publication with post-publication reporting where reviews publish immediately but can be reported and removed.

Most platforms use vendor moderation as it distributes workload while giving vendors control over their product pages. However, to prevent abuse where vendors might reject all negative reviews, the system tracks rejection patterns and escalates concerning patterns to administrators. Administrators can also review any moderated review if customers contest vendor decisions.

When moderating reviews, vendors see the full review content including rating, title, text, and images. They can approve the review making it publicly visible on the product page, or reject the review with a mandatory reason from predefined categories such as inappropriate language, spam or promotional content, review is about shipping or service not product itself, review violates platform policies, or other with text explanation.

Approved reviews appear immediately on the product page. Rejected reviews notify the customer of the rejection reason and give them the option to edit and resubmit. If customers believe their review was unfairly rejected, they can flag it for administrator review.

Product Rating Calculation

The system automatically calculates and displays aggregate product ratings based on all approved reviews. When a review is approved, added, updated, or removed, a database trigger recalculates the product's average rating as the mean of all approved review ratings, and total review count as the count of approved reviews.

These values are stored directly in the products table for fast display without requiring join queries. Product listings and search results show the average rating and review count, formatted as "4.5 stars (23 reviews)" for example.

3.6.2 Managing Reviews

Vendors can view and manage reviews of their products through their dashboard. The reviews section displays all reviews for the vendor's products with filtering by product, rating, status, or date range.

Vendor Responses

Vendors can respond to reviews, which displays below the customer's review as official vendor response. This capability allows vendors to thank customers for positive reviews, address concerns raised in negative reviews, correct misinformation, and demonstrate customer service.

Vendor responses are limited to 1000 characters and are publicly visible. Multiple responses are not allowed; vendors can only post one response per review but can edit their response after posting. Vendor responses cannot be deleted once posted, though they can be edited. This prevents vendors from posting inappropriate responses then removing evidence.

Administrators can moderate vendor responses if reported by customers or if automatic filters detect potentially inappropriate content. Patterns of unprofessional responses may result in restrictions on vendor's ability to respond or other account penalties.

Review Reporting

Customers can report reviews they believe violate platform policies by clicking a report button and specifying the violation type such as spam or promotional content, abusive or inappropriate language, review appears fake or not based on actual purchase, review is about shipping or service not product, or other with explanation.

Reports are queued for administrator review. Administrators see the reported review, original reporter's reason, review author's purchase verification status, and any vendor response. They can take no action if review is acceptable, hide review from public display pending investigation, request changes from review author, permanently delete review if it clearly violates policies, or warn review author if behavior is problematic.

Customers whose reviews are hidden or deleted receive notification explaining why and how to avoid similar issues in future reviews. Repeated policy violations may result in loss of review privileges.

3.6.3 Review Incentives and Gamification

To encourage customers to write reviews, the platform can implement incentive programs such as offering discount coupons to customers who write reviews, displaying badges for customers who have written many helpful reviews, featuring top reviewers on product pages or vendor stores, or awarding points in loyalty program for each review written.

These incentives must be balanced carefully to encourage genuine reviews without creating incentive to write fake positive reviews. Platforms should not offer incentives that vary based on review rating, such as larger rewards for five-star reviews, as this biases the review system.

Administrators configure review incentive programs through system settings, specifying whether incentives are enabled, what rewards are offered, any eligibility criteria such as requiring photo uploads or minimum text length, and limits such as maximum number of incentivized reviews per customer per month.

3.7 Search and Filtering

3.7.1 Product Search

The search system enables customers to find products by entering keywords describing what they seek. Search must be fast, relevant, and tolerant of typos and variations in terminology.

Search Implementation

The platform uses Meilisearch, a specialized search engine, to provide fast and relevant product search. When vendors create or update products, the system automatically indexes the product information in Meilisearch including product name, description, brand, category name, SKU, and attribute values.

When customers enter search queries, the system sends the query to Meilisearch which returns matching products ranked by relevance. The search results page displays products with their primary image, name, price, average rating, and vendor name. Customers can click through to view full product details.

Search Features

The search engine supports several advanced features enhancing search quality. Typo tolerance handles misspellings with automatic correction, so searching for "labtop" finds "laptop" products. Synonym support maps equivalent terms, such as "TV" finding "television" products. Faceted search allows filtering results by category, price range, brand, attributes, rating, or availability without performing new searches. Sorting enables ordering results by relevance, price low to high, price high to low, newest products, highest rated, or most reviews.

Search is scoped to active products from active vendors in active categories. Deactivated, out-of-stock, or removed products do not appear in search results. This ensures customers only see purchasable products.

Search Autocomplete

As customers type in the search box, the system displays autocomplete suggestions based on partial input. These suggestions include popular search terms, product names matching the input, and category names containing the input. Autocomplete improves user experience by helping customers formulate effective queries and reducing typing.

Autocomplete suggestions are generated by Meilisearch and cached briefly to reduce query load. The system tracks search queries to identify popular terms and improve suggestion relevance over time.

3.7.2 Product Filtering

Product category and search result pages provide filtering controls allowing customers to narrow results based on product attributes, price, brand, rating, and availability.

Filter Types

Available filters depend on the products being displayed and their attributes. Common filters include price range with a slider or min/max inputs allowing selection of price boundaries, brand selection showing checkboxes for all brands represented in current results, category navigation enabling drilling down into subcategories from category pages, rating filter showing options for 4 stars and above, 3 stars and above, etc., availability showing checkboxes for in stock only or including out of stock, and attribute filters for variant attributes like size or color with checkboxes for each value.

Filters apply cumulatively, meaning multiple filters narrow results progressively. If a customer selects the "Blue" color filter and "$50-$100" price filter, results show only blue products priced between $50 and $100. The system displays the count of products matching each filter option before selection, helping customers understand filter impact.

Filter Persistence

Selected filters persist as customers navigate between pages of results or click through to product details then return. This is achieved through URL parameters encoding filter state. Each filter selection updates the URL query string, allowing bookmarking of filtered views and sharing links to specific filter combinations.

Customers can clear individual filters by clicking remove icons next to active filters, or clear all filters at once with a dedicated clear button. The interface clearly indicates which filters are currently active.

3.7.3 Category Navigation

The category system provides hierarchical navigation enabling customers to browse products by category without using search.

Category Display

The main navigation or homepage features top-level categories, presented as clickable cards or menu items with category name, representative icon or image, and optionally product count. Clicking a top-level category loads the category page showing products in that category and any subcategories.

Category pages display the category name and description, product count for this category, subcategory tiles if subcategories exist, product listing with filtering and sorting controls, and breadcrumb navigation showing the current position in category hierarchy.

Subcategory Navigation

Categories can have subcategories up to three levels deep. The category page shows subcategory tiles prominently above product listings, each displaying subcategory name, representative image, and product count. Clicking a subcategory navigates deeper into the hierarchy, showing products specifically in that subcategory and any further nested subcategories.

Breadcrumb navigation at the top of the page shows the full path such as "Home > Electronics > Computers > Laptops" with each segment clickable to navigate back up the hierarchy. This helps customers understand their location and easily backtrack.

Category Product Listings

Category pages list products belonging to that category including products directly in the selected category and products in any subcategories if viewing a parent category. For instance, viewing the "Electronics" category shows products from "Computers," "Phones," "Tablets," and all other Electronics subcategories.

Category listings support the same filtering, sorting, and pagination as search results. Customers can narrow category products using attribute filters or price ranges without leaving the category context.

3.8 Coupon and Discount System

3.8.1 Coupon Creation

Administrators create coupon codes that customers can apply during checkout to receive discounts. Coupons support various discount types and restriction rules enabling flexible promotional campaigns.

Coupon Configuration

Creating a coupon requires specifying coupon code as a unique alphanumeric string customers will enter such as "SAVE20" or "SUMMER2026", discount type selecting between percentage discount such as 20% off order total, fixed amount discount such as $10 off order total, or free shipping removing shipping charges. For percentage and fixed discounts, the discount value is set such as 20 for 20% or 10.00 for $10.

Usage restrictions include usage limit defining how many total times the coupon can be used across all customers, uses per customer limiting how many times one customer can use this coupon, minimum order amount requiring order subtotal to meet threshold before coupon applies, maximum discount amount capping the discount for percentage coupons such as "20% off, maximum $50 discount," and customer eligibility specifying whether coupon is available to all customers, new customers only, or specific customer list.

Time restrictions define validity period with start date and time when coupon becomes active and expiration date and time when coupon becomes inactive. Coupons can be activated immediately or scheduled for future activation.

Product Restrictions

Coupons can apply to entire orders or be restricted to specific categories, products, or vendors. Administrators select included categories meaning discount applies only to products in these categories, excluded categories where discount applies to all products except those in these categories, included products specifying a list of products eligible for discount, excluded products listing products ineligible for discount, or included vendors restricting discount to products from specific vendors.

These restrictions enable targeted promotions such as "20% off all Electronics," "$5 off your first purchase from vendor XYZ," or "Free shipping on Clothing and Accessories."

Combining Coupons

Platform settings control whether multiple coupons can be applied to a single order. If allowed, administrators configure stacking rules such as only one coupon per order preventing stacking, allow multiple coupons but set maximum total discount percentage or amount, or allow unlimited coupon stacking for maximum customer benefit.

Most platforms limit to one coupon per order to maintain discount predictability and prevent excessive discounting that impacts vendor revenue.

3.8.2 Coupon Usage

Customers apply coupons during checkout by entering the coupon code in a designated input field and clicking apply. The system validates the coupon against all restrictions and calculates the discount if valid.

Coupon Validation

The validation process checks that the coupon code exists in the system, the current date and time falls within the coupon's validity period, the usage limit has not been reached if specified, the customer has not exceeded their per-customer usage limit if specified, the order subtotal meets the minimum order amount if specified, and at least one product in the cart meets the category, product, or vendor restrictions if specified.

If validation fails, the system displays a clear error message explaining why such as "This coupon has expired," "Minimum order amount is $50," or "This coupon does not apply to items in your cart." If validation succeeds, the system calculates and applies the discount, updates the order total, displays the discount amount prominently in the order summary, and stores the coupon association with the cart.

Discount Calculation

For percentage discounts, the system calculates eligible item total from cart items matching coupon restrictions, applies the percentage to that total, caps at maximum discount amount if specified, and subtracts the discount from order total. For fixed amount discounts, it subtracts the fixed amount directly from order total but ensures total does not go negative. For free shipping coupons, it sets shipping charge to zero in the order total.

If a customer removes items from their cart such that the remaining items no longer meet coupon requirements, the system automatically removes the coupon and discount, prompting the customer to reapply if they wish after resolving the issue.

3.8.3 Coupon Reporting

Administrators can track coupon effectiveness through reporting interfaces showing total redemptions for each coupon, revenue impact calculating total discount amount given, customer acquisition or retention if coupon was targeted to new or lapsed customers, and popular products identifying which products are frequently purchased with specific coupons.

These analytics inform future promotional strategies and help administrators optimize discount levels and restrictions.

3.9 Notifications

3.9.1 Email Notifications

The system sends automated email notifications to users for important events, keeping them informed of account, order, and platform activities.

Transactional Emails

Transactional emails are triggered by user actions and provide necessary information for completing transactions or account management. Key transactional emails include email verification sent upon registration with verification link to activate account, password reset sent when user requests password recovery with secure reset link, order confirmation sent immediately after order placement with order number, items, total, and estimated delivery, order status updates sent when order status changes to processing, shipped, or delivered with relevant tracking information, review confirmation sent when customer writes review confirming receipt and moderation status, payout confirmation sent to vendors when payout is processed with transaction details, and vendor approval or rejection sent when administrator reviews vendor application with outcome and next steps.

Transactional emails are sent regardless of user notification preferences since they contain essential information for completing processes users initiated.

Promotional Emails

Promotional emails are sent for marketing purposes and can be opted out of by recipients. Examples include new product announcements from vendors to customers who have purchased from them, special offers or coupons sent by administrators for promotional campaigns, and low stock alerts sent to customers who have items in their wishlist that are running low.

Promotional emails must include clear unsubscribe links in compliance with anti-spam regulations. The system maintains email preference settings for each user allowing opt-out of promotional categories while continuing to receive transactional emails.

Email Design and Deliverability

All emails use responsive HTML templates that render properly across email clients and devices. Templates maintain consistent branding with platform logo, colors, and typography. Emails are sent through a reputable email service provider like SendGrid or Mailgun to ensure high deliverability rates and comply with SPF, DKIM, and DMARC authentication standards.

The system tracks email sends in the database logging recipient, email type, send timestamp, and delivery status. Bounced or failed emails are logged for administrator review to identify potential issues with email addresses or deliverability configuration.

3.9.2 In-App Notifications

In-app notifications display within the platform interface alerting users to important events without requiring email.

Notification Display

Authenticated users see a notification icon in the top navigation bar with a badge showing unread notification count. Clicking the icon opens a notification panel listing recent notifications with notification message briefly describing the event, timestamp showing when the event occurred, read or unread status indicated by styling, and link to relevant page such as order details or product page.

Notifications automatically mark as read when viewed in the panel or when the user navigates to the linked page. Users can manually dismiss notifications they no longer need to see, clearing them from the list.

Notification Types

Different user roles receive different notification types. Customers receive order status updates when their orders progress, review responses when vendors reply to their reviews, and wishlist stock alerts when wishlisted items come back in stock. Vendors receive new order notifications when customers purchase their products, low stock alerts when inventory drops below threshold, review notifications when customers write reviews of their products, and return requests when customers initiate returns. Administrators receive vendor application pending review when new vendors register, category requests when vendors create new categories, and dispute escalations when customers escalate return disputes.

3.9.3 SMS Notifications

For critical, time-sensitive events, the system optionally sends SMS text messages to users who have provided mobile phone numbers and opted into SMS notifications.

SMS Events

SMS notifications are reserved for high-priority events such as order shipped when items are dispatched with tracking number, order delivered when items are confirmed delivered, security alerts for suspicious account activity like login from new device or location, and payment issues when payment fails or requires action.

SMS messages are brief, typically under 160 characters, and include essential information with a link to view full details in the platform. For example: "Your order #ORD-123 has shipped! Track it here: [link] - Platform Name"

SMS Configuration

The system integrates with an SMS provider like Twilio for message delivery. Administrators configure SMS settings in the platform including provider credentials, sender phone number or shortcode, and cost per message if tracking SMS expenses.

Users opt into SMS notifications through their account settings by providing a mobile number, verifying it with a confirmation code, and selecting which events should trigger SMS. Users can opt out at any time, and every SMS includes unsubscribe instructions as required by regulations.

3.10 Analytics and Reporting

3.10.1 Dashboard Analytics

Each user role has a dashboard displaying relevant metrics and visualizations for quick insights into their platform activities.

Customer Dashboard

Customers see a simple dashboard upon login showing recent orders with status, saved items in wishlist, order history summary, and recommended products based on browsing or purchase history.

Vendor Dashboard

Vendors see comprehensive sales analytics including total sales revenue for current month, total orders count for current month, active products count, pending orders requiring attention, and available balance eligible for payout. Visual charts display sales trend over the last 30 days as a line graph, top selling products by quantity or revenue, order status distribution showing how many orders are pending, processing, shipped, and delivered, and customer rating distribution.

Quick links provide access to pending orders list, low stock products requiring restocking, pending reviews requiring moderation, and payout request form if balance is sufficient.

Administrator Dashboard

Administrators see platform-wide metrics including total platform revenue, total commission earned, active vendors count, total orders count, and total customers count. Charts visualize revenue trend over time, orders by status, top vendors by sales, and top categories by product count or revenue.

Pending actions list shows counts requiring attention such as vendor applications pending approval, category requests pending review, flagged reviews requiring moderation, and payout requests awaiting processing. Each count links to the relevant admin queue.

3.10.2 Sales Reports

Detailed sales reports provide deeper analysis of revenue, orders, and product performance for vendors and administrators.

Vendor Sales Reports

Vendors generate sales reports for specified date ranges through their dashboard. Reports display order-level details including order number and date, customer name, product names and quantities, order total, commission deducted, net payout amount, and order status. Summary statistics include total revenue in date range, total commission charged, total net payout, average order value, and order count.

Vendors can filter reports by order status to see completed orders only, product to analyze performance of specific items, or date range using predefined ranges like last 7 days, last 30 days, this month, or custom start and end dates. Reports can be exported to CSV for further analysis in spreadsheet software.

Administrator Sales Reports

Administrators access comprehensive sales reports across all vendors with ability to filter by vendor to analyze specific seller performance, product or category to identify top categories, date range, or order status. Reports include all order details plus vendor information, commission amounts by vendor, and aggregate totals across filtered set.

Additional administrator reports include commission summary showing total commission earned by platform with breakdown by vendor, payout history listing all processed payouts with dates, amounts, and vendors, vendor performance ranking vendors by metrics like revenue, order count, average rating, or cancellation rate, and product performance identifying top products by sales across all vendors.

3.10.3 Customer Insights

Understanding customer behavior helps optimize the platform and informs marketing strategies.

Customer Metrics

Administrators track customer metrics including total registered customers, new customer registrations per day or month, active customers defined as those who have made a purchase in the last 90 days, customer lifetime value calculating average total spending per customer, repeat purchase rate measuring percentage of customers who make multiple purchases, and average order value across all orders.

Customer cohort analysis groups customers by registration month and tracks their purchasing behavior over time, identifying which customer cohorts have highest retention and lifetime value.

Traffic and Conversion

The platform tracks traffic and conversion metrics including total page views, unique visitors, product page views and which products attract most attention, add to cart rate showing percentage of product views resulting in cart additions, checkout initiation rate showing percentage of carts proceeding to checkout, and conversion rate showing percentage of checkouts completing purchase.

These metrics identify conversion bottlenecks and inform improvements to product pages, cart experience, or checkout process.

4. NON-FUNCTIONAL REQUIREMENTS

4.1 Performance Requirements

The platform must maintain responsive performance under normal and peak load conditions to ensure positive user experience.

Response Time

Page load times must not exceed two seconds for the homepage, category pages, and product listing pages under normal load conditions. Product detail pages must load within two seconds including primary image and key information with additional images lazy-loaded. API response times for standard queries like product search or cart operations must return within 500 milliseconds for 95% of requests under normal load.

Checkout process must remain responsive with each step loading within 1.5 seconds to prevent cart abandonment. Administrative panel operations including report generation must complete within five seconds for standard reports, with longer-running reports providing progress indicators and running asynchronously.

Scalability

The system must support at least 1000 concurrent users browsing and shopping without performance degradation. During peak traffic events like promotional sales, the system should scale to handle 5000 concurrent users through horizontal scaling of application servers and proper caching strategies.

Database queries must be optimized with appropriate indexes to handle large data volumes. The system should perform adequately with databases containing one million products, 10,000 vendors, 100,000 orders, and one million registered customers.

Caching Strategy

The platform implements multi-layer caching to improve performance. Application-level caching uses Redis to cache frequently accessed data including product information, category structures, vendor details, and user sessions with cache invalidation triggered by data updates. Database query caching stores common query results such as category product counts and popular search queries with TTL of five to fifteen minutes. Content Delivery Network (CDN) caching serves static assets including product images, CSS files, JavaScript bundles, and public pages with long cache headers allowing browser caching.

4.2 Security Requirements

Security is paramount given the platform handles sensitive customer information, payment data, and vendor financial details.

Authentication and Authorization

User passwords must be hashed using bcrypt with a cost factor of at least 12, making brute force attacks computationally expensive. JWT tokens for API authentication must use strong secrets with at least 256 bits of entropy and should expire after reasonable periods such as 15 minutes for access tokens with refresh token rotation.

Session management must use secure, httpOnly cookies with SameSite attribute set to Lax or Strict to prevent CSRF attacks. Sessions must expire after 30 minutes of inactivity and force re-authentication for sensitive operations like changing passwords or banking information.

Role-based access control (RBAC) must be enforced at both application and API layers, ensuring users can only access resources and perform actions appropriate to their role. Every API endpoint must validate user permissions before executing requests.

Data Encryption

Sensitive data must be encrypted at rest including vendor bank account numbers, tax identification numbers, and customer addresses. Encryption uses AES-256 with properly managed keys stored separately from the database using key management services.

All communications between clients and servers must use HTTPS with TLS 1.3 or 1.2, with HTTP requests automatically redirected to HTTPS. The platform must use valid SSL certificates from trusted certificate authorities.

Payment Security

The platform must comply with PCI DSS requirements for handling payment information. This is primarily achieved by never storing credit card numbers, CVV codes, or full card details on platform servers. All payment processing must use tokenization through integrated payment gateways like Stripe or PayPal where card data is captured and processed entirely within the gateway's PCI-compliant environment.

Payment webhooks receiving order status updates from gateways must validate webhook signatures to prevent forged requests. Payment intent IDs and tokens must be one-time use and properly validated before processing orders.

Input Validation and Sanitization

All user inputs must be validated both client-side for user experience and server-side for security. Validation includes format checking for email addresses, phone numbers, and postal codes, length limits preventing buffer overflow or excessive data storage, type checking ensuring numeric fields receive numbers not strings, and range validation for quantities, prices, and percentages.

SQL injection must be prevented by using parameterized queries and ORM query builders that escape inputs. Never construct SQL queries by concatenating user input. Cross-site scripting (XSS) must be prevented by HTML-encoding all user-generated content before display and implementing Content Security Policy headers that restrict script execution.

Rate Limiting

API endpoints must implement rate limiting to prevent abuse and denial of service attacks. Limits include 1000 requests per hour per IP address for unauthenticated requests, 100 requests per minute per authenticated user for standard operations, and 5 requests per 15 minutes for authentication endpoints like login and password reset to prevent brute force attacks.

When rate limits are exceeded, the API returns HTTP 429 Too Many Requests with Retry-After header indicating when requests can resume.

Security Headers

All HTTP responses must include security headers including X-Frame-Options set to SAMEORIGIN preventing clickjacking, X-Content-Type-Options set to nosniff preventing MIME sniffing attacks, X-XSS-Protection set to "1; mode=block" enabling browser XSS filtering, Strict-Transport-Security enforcing HTTPS for all future requests, and Content-Security-Policy restricting resource loading to trusted sources.

Audit Logging

Critical actions must be logged for security auditing including authentication attempts both successful and failed, authorization failures indicating potential unauthorized access attempts, data modifications for sensitive records like banking details, administrator actions including approvals, rejections, and setting changes, and payment transactions with full details.

Logs must include timestamp, user identity, IP address, action performed, affected resources, and outcome. Logs must be stored securely with restricted access and retained for at least one year for compliance and investigation purposes.

4.3 Reliability and Availability

The platform must maintain high availability to minimize downtime and revenue loss.

Uptime Requirements

The platform should target 99.9% uptime, allowing approximately 8.76 hours of downtime per year. Planned maintenance windows should occur during lowest traffic periods, typically late night in the primary market timezone, and should be announced to vendors and administrators at least 48 hours in advance.

Fault Tolerance

The system must gracefully handle component failures. If the search service becomes unavailable, the platform should fall back to database-based search with warning to users that results may be limited. If the email service fails, emails should be queued for retry when service recovers. If the cache layer fails, the application should continue operating directly against the database albeit with reduced performance.

Critical errors should never expose sensitive information or technical details to users. Instead, generic error messages should display while detailed errors are logged for administrator review.

Data Backup

Database backups must be performed automatically daily during low-traffic periods with backups stored in geographically separate locations from the primary database. Backup retention should keep daily backups for 30 days, weekly backups for three months, and monthly backups for one year.

Backup restoration procedures must be documented and tested quarterly to ensure data can be recovered if needed. Recovery Time Objective (RTO) should be under four hours and Recovery Point Objective (RPO) should be under 24 hours for database restoration.

File storage backups for product images and documents should be maintained separately with similar retention policies.

Monitoring and Alerting

The platform must implement comprehensive monitoring for application health, database performance, API response times, error rates, and resource utilization including CPU, memory, and disk space.

Alerts must trigger when thresholds are exceeded including error rate exceeding 1% of requests, API response times exceeding 2 seconds for 90th percentile, database connections nearing pool limit, or disk space usage exceeding 80% capacity. Alerts should be sent to on-call technical staff through multiple channels including email, SMS, and incident management platforms like PagerDuty.

4.4 Usability Requirements

The platform must provide intuitive, accessible interfaces requiring minimal training for users to accomplish their goals.

Interface Design

User interfaces must follow consistent design patterns across all pages with recognizable navigation elements, clear calls to action, and logical workflow progression. Color schemes must provide sufficient contrast for readability with text meeting WCAG AA standards for contrast ratios.

Forms must provide inline validation with clear error messages indicating what is wrong and how to fix it. Error messages should appear near the relevant input field and use plain language avoiding technical jargon.

Responsive Design

All customer-facing interfaces must be fully responsive, adapting gracefully to different screen sizes and devices. Mobile devices with screens as small as 360px wide must have functional, touch-friendly interfaces with appropriate touch target sizes of at least 44x44 pixels and adequate spacing between interactive elements.

Vendor and administrator dashboards should be primarily designed for desktop use given their complexity and data density, but should still be accessible from tablets with screens 768px wide or larger.

Accessibility

The platform should follow Web Content Accessibility Guidelines (WCAG) 2.1 Level AA standards to ensure accessibility for users with disabilities. This includes providing semantic HTML structure for screen reader compatibility, keyboard navigation support for all interactive elements without requiring mouse, alt text for all meaningful images describing their content or purpose, and proper form labels associated with input fields.

Color should not be the only means of conveying information. For example, error states should use both red color and icon indicators.

Help and Documentation

The platform should provide contextual help throughout the interface with tooltip information available for complex features, inline help text explaining non-obvious fields or options, and comprehensive help documentation accessible from all pages covering common tasks and questions.

Vendors and administrators should have access to user guides and video tutorials explaining how to perform key tasks like listing products, processing orders, or generating reports.

4.5 Maintainability Requirements

The codebase must be structured and documented to facilitate ongoing maintenance, bug fixes, and feature additions.

Code Quality

Code must follow established coding standards for each language and framework including PSR-12 for PHP code, Airbnb JavaScript style guide for JavaScript, and Vue.js style guide for Vue components. Code must be properly commented with docblock comments explaining function purposes, parameters, and return values.

Code should be modular and follow SOLID principles with single responsibility, dependency injection, and interface-based design enabling testability and future modifications without cascading changes.

Testing

The codebase must include automated tests at multiple levels. Unit tests should cover business logic and utility functions with target coverage of 70% for backend code. Feature tests should verify API endpoints return expected responses for various inputs and edge cases. End-to-end tests should validate critical user flows like registration, product purchase, and vendor onboarding.

Continuous integration pipelines must run tests automatically on every code commit, preventing broken code from being deployed to production.

Version Control

All code must be maintained in Git repositories with clear commit messages explaining changes. The project should follow Git flow branching model with main branch representing production-ready code, develop branch for integration of features, feature branches for developing new capabilities, and hotfix branches for urgent production fixes.

Deployment Process

Deployments must follow documented procedures with staging environment that mirrors production for pre-deployment testing, automated deployment scripts reducing human error, database migrations that are reversible allowing rollback if needed, and zero-downtime deployment strategies like blue-green deployment.

Deployment must include verification steps confirming key functionality works after deployment before declaring deployment successful.

Documentation

Technical documentation must be maintained covering system architecture diagrams explaining component relationships, API documentation describing all endpoints, parameters, and responses, database schema documentation including table purposes and relationships, and deployment and infrastructure documentation for server configuration and management.

Documentation should be stored in the code repository alongside code and updated as part of feature development to prevent documentation drift.

4.6 Compatibility Requirements

The platform must operate correctly across commonly used browsers, devices, and operating systems.

Browser Compatibility

The customer-facing storefront must fully support Google Chrome version 90 and later, Mozilla Firefox version 88 and later, Safari version 14 and later, and Microsoft Edge version 90 and later. Partial support may be provided for older browser versions with graceful degradation where advanced features may not work but core shopping functionality remains accessible.

Vendor and administrator interfaces target recent browser versions and may not support browsers more than one major version behind current.

Device Compatibility

Mobile device support must include iOS devices running iOS 14 or later and Android devices running Android 10 or later. The platform should function on both phones and tablets with screen sizes ranging from 360px to 1024px wide.

Desktop support should accommodate screen resolutions from 1280x720 up to 4K displays ensuring interfaces scale appropriately without breaking layouts.

Email Client Compatibility

Email templates must render properly in common email clients including Gmail web and mobile apps, Outlook web and desktop, iOS Mail, and Android Gmail app. Emails should use table-based layouts for maximum compatibility and be tested across clients before deployment.

4.7 Legal and Compliance Requirements

The platform must comply with relevant laws and regulations in its operating jurisdictions.

Data Protection

The platform must comply with GDPR for European users and similar regulations in other jurisdictions. This requires obtaining explicit consent for data collection and processing, providing privacy policy clearly explaining data usage, enabling users to access their stored data upon request, allowing users to request data deletion with specific data being deleted within 30 days, maintaining data processing records, and reporting data breaches to authorities and affected users within required timeframes.

Consumer Protection

The platform must comply with consumer protection laws including clearly displaying product prices and fees before checkout, providing fair return and refund policies, not engaging in deceptive marketing practices, and honoring consumer rights regarding defective products and warranty claims.

Tax Compliance

The platform must support tax calculation and collection according to jurisdiction requirements. This may include collecting sales tax in applicable US states, VAT in European countries, or GST in other regions. Tax calculations should be accurate and automatically updated when tax rates change.

The platform must provide tax reports for vendors and administrators facilitating compliance with reporting obligations.

Accessibility Compliance

In jurisdictions with accessibility mandates such as ADA in the US, the platform must meet applicable requirements. This is primarily achieved through WCAG 2.1 Level AA compliance described in usability requirements.

Payment Regulations

The platform must comply with financial regulations including PCI DSS for payment card data security and anti-money laundering (AML) regulations requiring customer verification for high-value transactions and suspicious activity reporting.

5. SYSTEM ARCHITECTURE

5.1 Technology Stack (Continued)

Email Service

Email delivery utilizes transactional email services such as SendGrid, Mailgun, or Amazon SES for high deliverability rates, bounce handling, and email tracking capabilities. These services maintain sender reputation and handle technical aspects of email delivery including SPF, DKIM, and DMARC authentication, ensuring emails reach recipient inboxes rather than spam folders.

Payment Gateways

Stripe and PayPal are integrated as primary payment processors. Stripe handles credit and debit card payments through its secure payment elements that collect card information directly without it touching platform servers. PayPal enables customers to pay through their PayPal accounts with redirect-based authentication. Both gateways provide webhooks for asynchronous payment status updates and comprehensive APIs for refund processing.

Message Queue

Laravel Queue with Redis as the queue driver handles background job processing. Jobs are dispatched to queues for asynchronous execution of time-consuming tasks such as sending emails, processing image uploads, updating search indexes, and generating reports. Queue workers run continuously to process jobs, with supervisor ensuring workers restart if they fail.

Task Scheduling

Laravel Scheduler manages periodic tasks that need to run on fixed schedules. Tasks include expiring stock reservations every hour to release inventory from abandoned carts, releasing commission status from pending to released for orders past their return window executed daily, sending low stock alerts to vendors when inventory drops below thresholds checked twice daily, generating and caching dashboard statistics during low-traffic periods for improved performance, and cleaning up expired sessions and temporary data weekly.

The scheduler runs through a single cron job that executes Laravel's schedule runner every minute, which then determines which scheduled tasks need execution at that time.

Logging and Monitoring

Application logging uses Laravel's built-in logging that supports multiple channels including daily log files that rotate automatically preventing unlimited growth, Sentry integration for error tracking and alerting with stack traces and context, and Slack notifications for critical errors requiring immediate attention.

Infrastructure monitoring can be implemented through services such as New Relic or Datadog for application performance monitoring, tracking response times, throughput, and error rates. Server monitoring through tools like Prometheus and Grafana tracks resource utilization including CPU, memory, disk space, and network traffic.

Development Tools

Docker and Docker Compose provide containerized development environments ensuring consistency between developer machines and production infrastructure. The development stack includes containers for Nginx web server, PHP-FPM application server, PostgreSQL database, Redis cache, Meilisearch search engine, and Mailhog for email testing.

Version control through Git with repositories hosted on GitHub or GitLab enables collaborative development, code review through pull requests, and automated testing through CI/CD pipelines.

5.2 System Components

The platform architecture consists of several interconnected components, each responsible for specific functionality.

Web Server Layer

Nginx serves as the reverse proxy and web server, handling SSL termination, static file serving, and request routing to the application server. Nginx is configured with upstream load balancing to distribute requests across multiple PHP-FPM instances when horizontally scaled. Static assets including images, CSS, and JavaScript are served directly by Nginx without touching the application layer, reducing unnecessary processing overhead.

Application Layer

The Laravel application implements all business logic and API endpoints. This layer processes incoming requests, validates input, enforces authorization rules, executes business operations through service classes, interacts with the database through Eloquent ORM, and returns formatted responses. The application follows the repository pattern for data access, separating database queries from business logic to improve testability and maintainability.

Key application components include controllers that handle HTTP requests and route them to appropriate services, service classes containing business logic such as OrderService for order processing, CommissionService for commission calculations, and InventoryService for stock management, repositories that abstract database access providing interfaces for data retrieval and persistence, models representing database entities with relationships and attribute casting, and middleware for request filtering, authentication, rate limiting, and logging.

Database Layer

PostgreSQL stores all persistent application data in normalized relational tables. The database design emphasizes referential integrity through foreign key constraints, preventing orphaned records and maintaining data consistency. Indexes are strategically placed on frequently queried columns to optimize read performance without excessive overhead on write operations.

Database transactions wrap operations that must complete atomically, such as order creation which involves updating multiple tables including orders, order items, stock reservations, and commission records. If any step fails, the entire transaction rolls back ensuring data integrity.

Database views provide convenient access to commonly needed aggregated data such as product details with stock availability calculated dynamically and order summaries with item counts and vendor information. Functions encapsulate reusable calculation logic like available stock computation and order number generation. Triggers automate maintenance tasks such as updating product rating averages when reviews are added or removed and maintaining category product counts when products are created or deleted.

Cache Layer

Redis provides high-performance caching that significantly reduces database load and improves response times. Cached data includes product information with short time-to-live for frequently viewed products, category trees that change infrequently cached with longer TTL, user sessions enabling fast authentication without database queries on every request, and application configuration cached at startup to avoid repeated database reads.

Cache invalidation occurs automatically when data changes. For example, when a vendor updates a product, the application explicitly deletes that product from cache forcing fresh data to be fetched and re-cached on next request. For data with eventual consistency tolerance, cache entries can use time-based expiration without explicit invalidation.

Search Layer

Meilisearch indexes product data enabling fast full-text search with features like typo tolerance and synonym support. When products are created or updated, the application dispatches jobs to update the search index asynchronously. This ensures the main request completes quickly without waiting for index updates which can take several hundred milliseconds.

Search queries execute against Meilisearch and return matching product IDs along with relevance scores. The application then fetches full product details from cache or database for matched products, combining search speed with complete data access.

File Storage Layer

AWS S3 or compatible object storage stores all uploaded files including product images, vendor verification documents, and generated PDFs like invoices. Files are organized in logical folder structures such as products for product images and vendor documents for business registration files.

When vendors upload images, the application processes them through the ImageService which creates multiple sizes for different display contexts. Thumbnails at 150x150 pixels are used in product listings, medium images at 600x600 pixels display on product detail pages, and large images at 1200x1200 pixels are available for zoomed views. The original uploaded image is preserved for potential future reprocessing needs.

Image URLs use the object storage's CDN capabilities for fast global delivery. URLs include cache-busting parameters when images change to ensure customers see updated images rather than stale cached versions.

Queue Worker Layer

Background job processing occurs through dedicated queue worker processes that monitor the Redis queue for pending jobs. Workers execute jobs sequentially from the queue, with multiple workers running in parallel to handle high job volumes.

Jobs are implemented as PHP classes with a handle method containing the job logic. Failed jobs are automatically retried up to a configured maximum attempts, with exponential backoff between attempts. Jobs that fail all retry attempts are moved to a failed jobs table for manual review and potential reprocessing.

Critical jobs like sending order confirmation emails have higher priority than less critical jobs like updating search indexes, ensuring important user-facing operations complete promptly even under heavy load.

Scheduled Task Layer

The Laravel scheduler runs background tasks on fixed schedules without user interaction. The implementation uses a single cron job on the server that executes Laravel's schedule runner every minute. The scheduler evaluates all registered scheduled tasks and runs those whose schedule matches the current time.

Tasks can be scheduled with various frequencies including every minute, hourly at specific minute offsets, daily at specific times, weekly on specific days, or custom cron expressions for complex schedules. The scheduler prevents overlapping task executions to avoid resource contention and data corruption.

5.3 Data Flow

Understanding how data flows through the system clarifies component interactions and processing sequences.

Customer Product Search Flow

When a customer enters a search query in the storefront, the Next.js frontend sends an API request to the Laravel backend with the search terms and any applied filters. The backend forwards the query to Meilisearch which returns matching product IDs and relevance scores. The backend fetches full product details for matched IDs from Redis cache if available or from PostgreSQL if not cached, applying any additional filters that cannot be handled by the search engine. Products are formatted through ProductResource transformation classes that shape the data for frontend consumption, including URLs for product images from object storage and calculated fields like discount percentages. The formatted response returns to the frontend which renders the product grid and provides filtering and sorting controls.

Order Placement Flow

During checkout, when a customer clicks the final payment button, the frontend sends the complete order data to the checkout API endpoint including cart items, shipping address, payment method selection, and applied coupon if any. The backend validates the request checking that all cart items are still in stock with sufficient quantity, that the shipping address is complete and valid, and that any coupon codes are valid and applicable.

The backend initiates payment processing by creating a payment intent with Stripe or redirecting to PayPal based on the selected method. For Stripe, the frontend handles secure card collection and sends the payment method ID to the backend which confirms the payment intent. Upon successful payment authorization, the backend begins a database transaction.

Within the transaction, the system creates the order record with a generated order number and all order details. Order item records are created for each cart item capturing product information, quantities, and prices at the time of purchase. Stock reservations from the cart are converted to committed order stock, preventing the inventory from being sold again. Commission records are created for each order item calculating the platform fee and vendor payout. The payment record is created referencing the external gateway transaction ID.

If any step in the transaction fails, the entire transaction rolls back and payment authorization is voided. Upon successful transaction commit, the backend dispatches background jobs to send order confirmation email to the customer, send new order notifications to each vendor whose products are in the order, update the search index if any product stock statuses changed to out of stock, and clear the customer's cart.

The API returns success to the frontend which displays an order confirmation page with the order number and provides a link to view order details.

Product Creation Flow

When a vendor fills out the product creation form and submits it, the frontend sends product data to the product creation API endpoint including basic product information, selected category, attributes with values from templates, pricing and inventory, and uploaded product images.

The backend validates all fields ensuring required information is present and properly formatted. If the product is variable based on variant attributes, the backend generates all possible variant combinations and returns them to the frontend for the vendor to complete with variant-specific pricing and inventory.

Once the vendor provides complete information, the backend creates the product record in the database, creates product attribute records linking attribute templates to their values for this product, creates variant records for variable products with their specific details, and dispatches a background job to process uploaded images.

The image processing job downloads the uploaded images from temporary storage, creates multiple sized versions through image manipulation, uploads all versions to permanent object storage with organized naming conventions, and updates the product images table with the URLs for all versions.

Another background job updates the search index by sending the new product information to Meilisearch for indexing. The product becomes immediately searchable once this completes.

The API returns success to the frontend which redirects the vendor to their product list or the newly created product's detail page.

5.4 Security Architecture

Security is implemented through multiple layers of protection ensuring comprehensive coverage against various threat vectors.

Network Security

All client-to-server communications occur over HTTPS enforced through automatic HTTP to HTTPS redirects. TLS certificates from trusted certificate authorities like Let's Encrypt provide encryption in transit. The web server is configured with strong cipher suites supporting TLS 1.3 and 1.2 while rejecting older insecure protocols.

The database server is not exposed to the public internet and accepts connections only from the application server layer through private networking. Redis and Meilisearch are similarly restricted to internal access.

Application Security

Request authentication requires valid session tokens or JWT tokens for protected endpoints. The authentication middleware validates tokens on every request before allowing access to protected resources. Tokens include expiration timestamps and are rejected if expired.

Authorization checks occur after authentication, verifying that the authenticated user has permission to perform the requested action on the specified resource. For example, a vendor can only edit their own products, not products from other vendors. These checks are implemented through Laravel policies that centralize authorization logic.

Input validation happens at multiple levels. Client-side validation provides immediate feedback to users about invalid inputs before submission. Server-side validation is the authoritative check that cannot be bypassed, validating all inputs against defined rules and rejecting invalid requests with detailed error messages.

SQL injection is prevented through consistent use of parameterized queries and ORM query builders that automatically escape inputs. Raw SQL queries are avoided except where necessary and are carefully reviewed for injection vulnerabilities.

Cross-site scripting protection involves escaping all user-generated content before display using Blade template engine's automatic escaping. Content Security Policy headers restrict script execution to trusted sources preventing injection of malicious scripts.

Cross-site request forgery protection uses CSRF tokens included in forms and AJAX requests. The backend validates that tokens match expected values before processing state-changing operations.

Data Security

Sensitive data encryption uses AES-256 encryption for fields containing vendor bank account numbers, tax identification information, and customer personally identifiable information that requires heightened protection. Encryption keys are stored separately from the database using environment variables or key management services.

Password hashing uses bcrypt with a cost factor of 12 providing strong protection against brute force attacks even if password hashes are compromised. Passwords are never stored in plain text or reversible encryption.

Database backups are encrypted before storage ensuring that backup media does not expose sensitive data if stolen or lost. Backup encryption uses strong algorithms and keys managed through secure key management practices.

Payment Security

The platform achieves PCI DSS compliance primarily through never storing credit card information on platform servers. Card details are collected by Stripe using hosted payment elements that submit directly to Stripe's servers. The platform only stores Stripe customer IDs and payment method IDs which are tokenized references that cannot be used for fraudulent charges.

Payment webhooks from Stripe are verified using signature validation ensuring that webhook requests actually come from Stripe and have not been tampered with. This prevents attackers from sending fake payment confirmations.

For PayPal transactions, customers are redirected to PayPal's secure login and payment approval flow. The platform receives only payment confirmation and transaction IDs after PayPal processes payment, never handling PayPal credentials.

Session Security

User sessions are stored in Redis with secure random session IDs that are cryptographically strong and unpredictable. Session cookies are marked as httpOnly preventing JavaScript access that could leak session IDs through XSS attacks. The secure flag ensures cookies are only transmitted over HTTPS.

Session fixation attacks are prevented by regenerating session IDs after authentication, ensuring that pre-authentication session IDs cannot be reused after login. Sessions expire after thirty minutes of inactivity and are destroyed on logout.

Audit Logging

Security-relevant events are logged to the activity log table providing an audit trail for investigation and compliance. Logged events include all authentication attempts with timestamps, IP addresses, and success or failure status, authorization failures indicating attempts to access unauthorized resources, sensitive data access such as viewing or modifying bank account information, payment transactions with full details except sensitive card information, and administrator actions including approvals, rejections, and configuration changes.

Logs include sufficient context to reconstruct events including user identities, affected resources, IP addresses, user agents, and timestamps. Log retention policies keep security logs for at least one year with older logs archived for long-term retention.

5.5 Scalability Strategy

The architecture is designed to scale horizontally to handle increasing traffic and data volumes as the platform grows.

Application Scaling

The stateless nature of the Laravel application allows running multiple application server instances behind a load balancer. Each instance can handle requests independently without requiring session affinity since sessions are stored in Redis rather than application memory.

Horizontal scaling involves launching additional server instances with identical application code and configuration. The load balancer distributes incoming requests across available instances using round-robin or least-connections algorithms. As instances are added, the system's total throughput increases proportionally.

Auto-scaling can be implemented through cloud provider features that monitor resource utilization and automatically add or remove instances based on demand. For example, when CPU utilization exceeds seventy percent across all instances for five minutes, a new instance is launched. When utilization drops below thirty percent for ten minutes, excess instances are terminated.

Database Scaling

PostgreSQL can be scaled vertically by increasing server resources such as CPU, memory, and disk speed up to the limits of available hardware. For many workloads, vertical scaling provides sufficient capacity and is simpler to manage than horizontal scaling.

Read replicas provide horizontal scaling for read-heavy workloads by replicating data from the primary database to one or more replica servers. Read queries can be directed to replicas while write queries continue to the primary. The application uses database connections configured for read and write separately, with Laravel supporting this through read-write connection splitting.

Database connection pooling through pgBouncer or similar tools allows many application connections to share a smaller number of database connections, reducing resource overhead on the database server and allowing more concurrent application instances.

Cache Scaling

Redis can be scaled by deploying Redis clusters that shard data across multiple Redis nodes. Each node stores a portion of the keyspace determined by consistent hashing. The application connects to the cluster through a Redis client that automatically routes requests to the appropriate node.

For high availability, Redis Sentinel or Redis Cluster provides automatic failover when the primary Redis node fails. Replica nodes are promoted to primary ensuring continued cache availability with minimal disruption.

Search Scaling

Meilisearch supports horizontal scaling through index replication across multiple nodes. Queries can be distributed across replicas for higher throughput. For very large product catalogs, the index can be sharded across multiple Meilisearch instances though this adds deployment complexity.

File Storage Scaling

Object storage services like S3 scale automatically without requiring manual intervention. As the number of uploaded files grows, the storage service handles distribution across its infrastructure transparently. Content delivery networks integrate with object storage to provide globally distributed edge caching of frequently accessed files.

Queue Processing Scaling

Background job processing scales by running additional queue worker processes. Each worker independently polls the Redis queue for jobs to process. The number of workers can be adjusted based on queue depth and job processing times.

For very high job volumes, queue workers can be distributed across multiple servers each running its own set of workers. The Redis queue acts as a centralized job store that all workers access.

5.6 Deployment Architecture

The production deployment utilizes cloud infrastructure for reliability, scalability, and ease of management.

Infrastructure Components

The deployment consists of several server types, each serving a specific purpose. Web application servers run Nginx and PHP-FPM handling HTTP requests and executing application code. These servers are horizontally scalable with multiple instances running behind a load balancer. Database servers run PostgreSQL as the primary database with at least one read replica for high availability and read scaling. Cache and queue servers run Redis for caching, session storage, and job queues, deployed in a high-availability configuration with automatic failover. Search servers run Meilisearch for product search with replication for fault tolerance. Worker servers run Laravel queue workers processing background jobs with supervisord managing worker processes.

Load balancers distribute traffic across web application servers, performing health checks to remove failing instances from rotation automatically. Load balancers also terminate SSL connections offloading cryptographic processing from application servers.

Object storage through services like AWS S3 stores uploaded files with unlimited capacity scaling. A content delivery network integrates with object storage for global edge caching of static assets and images.

Deployment Process

Code deployment follows a structured process minimizing downtime and risk. Developers push code to Git repositories with feature branches merged to the develop branch after review. When ready for release, the develop branch is merged to main representing production-ready code.

Continuous integration pipelines run on every commit executing automated tests to catch regressions, running code quality checks using static analysis tools, and building deployable artifacts including Docker images or compiled assets.

Deployment to staging environment occurs automatically when code is merged to develop, allowing testing in an environment that mirrors production. Manual testing validates that features work correctly and no regressions were introduced.

Deployment to production is manually triggered after staging validation. The deployment process pulls the latest code from the repository, runs database migrations to update schema if needed, clears application cache forcing fresh data to be cached, restarts queue workers to load new job classes, and optionally performs rolling restarts of application servers to avoid downtime.

Blue-green deployment can be used for zero-downtime updates by maintaining two production environments. The new version deploys to the idle environment which is tested, then traffic is switched from the old version to the new version atomically. If issues arise, traffic can be switched back to the old version instantly.

Monitoring and Logging

Production infrastructure includes comprehensive monitoring of application performance through APM tools, server resource utilization with alerts for high CPU, memory, or disk usage, application logs aggregated in a centralized logging system, error tracking with Sentry or similar capturing and reporting application exceptions, and uptime monitoring with external services checking that the application responds correctly.

Alerts are configured for critical conditions that require immediate attention including application error rate exceeding one percent, API response times exceeding thresholds, database connection pool exhaustion, disk space usage above eighty percent, and backup failure. On-call engineers receive alerts through multiple channels ensuring rapid response to incidents.

6. DATABASE DESIGN

6.1 Entity Relationship Overview

The database schema represents the core data model of the multi-vendor e-commerce platform through a normalized relational design. The schema consists of twenty-nine primary tables organized around key business entities including users and authentication, vendors and vendor management, product catalog and attributes, inventory and stock management, shopping cart and orders, payments and commissions, reviews and ratings, notifications and activity logs, and platform configuration.

Tables maintain referential integrity through foreign key constraints ensuring that related records remain consistent. Cascade deletion rules are configured where appropriate to automatically clean up dependent records when parent records are deleted, such as removing order items when their parent order is deleted.

Indexes are strategically placed on frequently queried columns to optimize read performance, with composite indexes covering multi-column queries. Unique constraints enforce business rules like preventing duplicate product SKUs within a vendor's inventory or ensuring email addresses are unique across users.

6.2 Core Tables

users

The users table stores account information for all platform users including customers, vendors, and administrators. Each record represents a unique user account with authentication credentials and contact information.

The id field is a big integer serving as the primary key with auto-increment. The name field stores the user's full name as a variable character string with a maximum of 255 characters. The email field stores the email address as a variable character string, also maximum 255 characters, with a unique constraint ensuring no duplicate email addresses exist. The email_verified_at field is a nullable timestamp indicating when the user verified their email address through the verification link, with null meaning unverified.

The password field stores the bcrypt hashed password as a string. The role field is an enumeration with possible values of customer, vendor, admin, or super_admin determining the user's access level and capabilities. The status field is an enumeration with values active, suspended, or banned controlling whether the user can access their account.

The last_login_at field records the timestamp of the user's most recent successful login, which is useful for identifying inactive accounts. The last_login_ip stores the IP address from which the last login occurred as a string. The remember_token field stores a token for remember me functionality allowing persistent login sessions.

Standard timestamp fields created_at and updated_at are automatically managed by the database framework tracking when records are created and last modified. The deleted_at field supports soft deletion where records are marked as deleted without physical removal from the database, allowing potential recovery.

vendors

The vendors table extends user accounts with vendor-specific business information. Each vendor record is linked to a user account through a foreign key relationship.

The id field is the primary key auto-incrementing big integer. The user_id field is a foreign key referencing the users table establishing the one-to-one relationship between vendor business information and user authentication. This field has a unique constraint ensuring each user can only have one vendor account.

The business_name field stores the legal business name as a variable character string maximum 255 characters. The business_type field is an enumeration with values such as sole_proprietorship, partnership, corporation, or llc. The tax_id field stores the tax identification number as a string, encrypted at rest for security. The business_registration_number field stores relevant business registration or license numbers.

The business_description field is a text type allowing lengthy descriptions of what the vendor sells and their business approach. The business_address field stores the physical business address as a text type. The business_phone stores the contact phone number as a string. The website field stores an optional business website URL as a string.

The commission_rate field is a decimal with precision 5 and scale 2 representing the percentage commission charged on this vendor's sales. This defaults to the platform-wide rate but can be customized per vendor. The status field is an enumeration with values pending, approved, suspended, rejected, or banned controlling the vendor's ability to sell on the platform.

The approved_at field is a nullable timestamp indicating when an administrator approved the vendor application. The approved_by field is a nullable foreign key referencing the user id of the administrator who approved the application. The rejected_at and rejection_reason fields capture information if the application was rejected.

Document fields including trade_license_document_url, tax_certificate_document_url, and address_proof_document_url store URLs pointing to uploaded verification documents in object storage. These documents support the application review process.

The total_products field is an integer tracking how many products this vendor has listed, maintained automatically through database triggers. The total_sales field is a decimal tracking lifetime revenue generated by this vendor. The average_rating field is a decimal tracking the vendor's average product rating across all their products.

Standard timestamp fields created_at, updated_at, and deleted_at provide record tracking and soft deletion support.

vendor_bank_details

The vendor_bank_details table stores banking information necessary for processing payouts to vendors. This information is encrypted at rest to protect sensitive financial data.

The id field serves as the primary key. The vendor_id field is a foreign key referencing the vendors table with unique constraint ensuring each vendor has only one bank account record. The bank_name field stores the name of the financial institution as a string.

The account_holder_name field stores the name exactly as it appears on the bank account, which must match the business name for validation purposes. The account_number field stores the bank account number as an encrypted string. The routing_number field stores the routing number, SWIFT code, or similar bank identification as a string. The account_type field is an enumeration with values checking or savings.

The is_verified field is a boolean indicating whether the bank account has been verified through micro-deposit validation or similar mechanism. Unverified accounts cannot receive payouts until verification completes. The verified_at field is a nullable timestamp indicating when verification was completed.

Standard created_at and updated_at timestamps track record management.

categories

The categories table organizes products into hierarchical groupings enabling customer browsing and filtering. Categories can be nested up to three levels deep providing flexibility in organization.

The id field is the primary key. The parent_id field is a nullable foreign key referencing the categories table itself, establishing the hierarchical relationship. A null parent_id indicates a top-level category, while a non-null value makes this category a subcategory of the referenced parent.
