The name field stores the category name as a string maximum 255 characters. The slug field stores a URL-friendly version of the name, automatically generated from the name with lowercase letters and hyphens replacing spaces. The slug has a unique constraint ensuring category URLs are unique.

The description field is a nullable text type providing detailed explanation of what products belong in this category. The image_url field stores an optional category image URL for visual representation in navigation.

The display_order field is an integer determining the sort order when displaying categories, with lower numbers appearing first. This allows administrators to prioritize certain categories. The status field is an enumeration with values active, inactive, or pending controlling whether the category is visible to customers.

The created_by field is a nullable foreign key referencing users table indicating which vendor created this category if it was vendor-initiated. The approved_by field is a nullable foreign key indicating which administrator approved a vendor-created category.

The product_count field is an integer tracking how many products are in this category, maintained automatically through database triggers. The is_featured field is a boolean indicating whether this category should be prominently displayed on the homepage or in featured category sections.

Standard timestamp fields created_at, updated_at, approved_at, and rejected_at provide temporal tracking.

attribute_templates

The attribute_templates table defines standardized product attributes that can be used across products within specific categories. These templates ensure consistency and enable reliable filtering.

The id field is the primary key. The category_id field is a foreign key referencing categories table indicating which category this template applies to. Multiple templates can exist for the same category representing different attributes like size, color, brand, and material.

The attribute_name field stores the attribute name as a string maximum 255 characters, such as "Size" or "Color". The attribute_type field is an enumeration with values text, number, select, multiselect, or boolean determining how the attribute is captured and displayed.

The is_required field is a boolean indicating whether vendors must provide a value for this attribute when creating products in this category. The is_filterable field is a boolean indicating whether customers can filter products by this attribute value. The is_variant field is a boolean indicating whether this attribute defines product variants, requiring separate SKU and inventory for each value.

The validation_rules field is a JSON type storing structured validation rules such as minimum and maximum values for numbers or regular expression patterns for text. The display_order field is an integer controlling the sequence in which attributes appear in product creation forms and filter interfaces.

The unit field is a nullable string storing the measurement unit for numeric attributes such as "inches" for dimensions or "pounds" for weight. This enhances clarity for customers.

Standard created_at and updated_at timestamps track record management.

attribute_template_options

The attribute_template_options table stores predefined values for select and multiselect type attributes. Vendors choose from these options rather than entering arbitrary values, ensuring consistency.

The id field is the primary key. The template_id field is a foreign key referencing attribute_templates table indicating which attribute this option belongs to. The option_value field stores the actual value as a string maximum 255 characters, such as "Red" for a color attribute or "Large" for a size attribute.

The display_label field stores an optional alternative label for display purposes if it should differ from the stored value. The display_order field is an integer controlling the order in which options appear in dropdown menus or checkbox lists. The is_active field is a boolean indicating whether this option is currently available for selection, allowing temporary removal of options without deletion.

Standard created_at and updated_at timestamps track record management.

products

The products table stores core product information for items listed by vendors. Each record represents either a simple product with single pricing and inventory or a variable product with multiple variants.

The id field is the primary key. The vendor_id field is a foreign key referencing vendors table indicating which vendor owns this product. The category_id field is a foreign key referencing categories table classifying the product.

The name field stores the product name as a string maximum 255 characters. The slug field stores the URL-friendly version with unique constraint ensuring product URLs are unique globally. The sku field stores the Stock Keeping Unit as a string, unique within the vendor's inventory for simple products.

The type field is an enumeration with values simple or variable. Simple products have one price and inventory quantity, while variable products have multiple variants each with their own details. The description field is a text type containing detailed product information including features, specifications, and usage instructions.

The brand field is a nullable string storing the brand or manufacturer name. The regular_price field is a decimal with precision 10 and scale 2 storing the standard price. The sale_price field is a nullable decimal storing a discounted price if on sale. The sale_start_date and sale_end_date fields are nullable timestamps defining when the sale price is active.

For simple products, the stock_quantity field is an integer storing available inventory. For variable products, this field is null and inventory is tracked at the variant level. The low_stock_threshold field is an integer defining when low stock alerts should trigger. The stock_status field is an enumeration with values in_stock, out_of_stock, or discontinued.

The weight and dimensions fields store physical product properties for shipping calculations. Weight is a decimal representing pounds or kilograms. Dimensions is a JSON field storing length, width, and height as structured data.

The status field is an enumeration with values active, inactive, or draft controlling product visibility. Active products appear in search and category listings, inactive products are hidden but not deleted, and draft products are works in progress not yet published. The is_featured field is a boolean that only administrators can set, highlighting select products in featured sections.

The reviews_enabled field is a boolean controlling whether customers can write reviews for this product. The average_rating field is a decimal tracking the average star rating from approved reviews. The total_reviews field is an integer counting approved reviews. These fields are maintained automatically through database triggers.

The seo_title, seo_description, and seo_keywords fields store search engine optimization metadata. The tags field is a JSON array storing additional classification terms for search and discovery.

The viewed_count field is an integer tracking how many times this product has been viewed, useful for popularity analysis. Standard timestamp fields created_at, updated_at, deleted_at, published_at support record tracking and soft deletion.

product_images

The product_images table stores multiple images for each product allowing detailed visual presentation. Each record represents one image with URLs for different sizes.

The id field is the primary key. The product_id field is a foreign key referencing products table indicating which product this image belongs to. The filename field stores the base filename of the uploaded image in object storage.

The original_url field stores the URL to the full-resolution uploaded image. The thumbnail_url field stores the URL to a 150x150 pixel thumbnail version. The small_url, medium_url, and large_url fields store URLs to progressively larger versions at 300px, 600px, and 1200px respectively.

The alt_text field is a nullable string storing alternative text for accessibility and SEO purposes. The sort_order field is an integer determining the sequence in which images are displayed, with the first image serving as the primary product image.

The is_primary field is a boolean explicitly marking which image is the primary one, with only one image per product allowed to be primary. Standard created_at and updated_at timestamps track record management.

product_attributes

The product_attributes table stores actual attribute values for specific products based on the attribute templates defined for their category. Each record links a product to an attribute template and stores the value.

The id field is the primary key. The product_id field is a foreign key referencing products table. The template_id field is a foreign key referencing attribute_templates table indicating which standardized attribute this represents.

The attribute_value field is a text type storing the actual value. For text attributes, this contains the entered text. For select attributes, this contains the selected option value. For multiselect attributes, this contains a JSON array of selected values. For numeric attributes, this contains the number as a string. For boolean attributes, this contains "true" or "false".

The is_variant field is a boolean copied from the attribute template indicating whether this attribute defines product variants. This denormalization improves query performance when determining which attributes create variants.

Standard created_at and updated_at timestamps track record management.

product_variants

The product_variants table stores specific configurations of variable products. Each variant represents a unique combination of variant-defining attributes with its own SKU, price, and inventory.

The id field is the primary key. The product_id field is a foreign key referencing products table indicating the parent variable product. The sku field stores the Stock Keeping Unit for this specific variant as a string, unique globally to prevent confusion.

The regular_price and sale_price fields are decimals storing pricing specific to this variant, allowing different sizes or colors to have different prices. The stock_quantity field is an integer storing available inventory for this specific variant. The low_stock_threshold field defines the alert threshold for this variant.

The variant_attributes field is a JSON object storing the attribute name-value pairs that define this variant, such as {"size": "Large", "color": "Red"}. This denormalization improves query performance and simplifies display logic.

The image_urls field is a JSON array storing URLs to variant-specific images showing the actual appearance of this variant, particularly important for variants defined by visual attributes like color. The is_active field is a boolean allowing vendors to temporarily disable specific variants without deleting them.

The status field is an enumeration with values in_stock, out_of_stock, or discontinued. Standard created_at and updated_at timestamps track record management.

inventory_movements

The inventory_movements table records all changes to product and variant inventory, creating an audit trail for inventory management. Each record represents a single inventory adjustment.

The id field is the primary key. The product_id field is a foreign key referencing products table. The variant_id field is a nullable foreign key referencing product_variants table, null for simple products and populated for variant inventory movements.

The movement_type field is an enumeration with values addition, subtraction, or set indicating the type of adjustment. Addition increases stock, subtraction decreases it, and set directly sets the quantity regardless of current value. The quantity_change field is an integer storing the amount added, subtracted, or set.

The previous_quantity field is an integer recording the inventory level before this movement. The new_quantity field records the inventory level after this movement. These fields enable reversal of accidental adjustments if needed.

The reason field is an enumeration with predefined options including restock, customer_return, damaged, lost, correction, order_placed, order_cancelled, or other. The notes field is a text type allowing free-form explanation of the adjustment, particularly for "other" reasons.

The performed_by field is a nullable foreign key referencing users table indicating which vendor user made the adjustment, null for system-automated adjustments like those from order placement. The reference_type and reference_id fields store polymorphic references to related records such as orders or returns that triggered this movement.

Standard created_at timestamp tracks when the movement occurred.

stock_reservations

The stock_reservations table temporarily holds inventory for items in active shopping carts, preventing overselling while customers complete checkout. Each reservation represents a quantity of a specific product or variant reserved for a particular cart.

The id field is the primary key. The cart_id field is a foreign key referencing carts table. The product_id field is a foreign key referencing products table. The variant_id field is a nullable foreign key referencing product_variants table, null for simple products.

The quantity field is an integer storing how many units are reserved. The reserved_at field is a timestamp recording when the reservation was created. The expires_at field is a timestamp indicating when the reservation will automatically expire, typically set to 24 hours after reserved_at.

The status field is an enumeration with values active, expired, or released. Active reservations are currently holding stock. Expired reservations have passed their expiration time and are awaiting cleanup. Released reservations were intentionally freed when items were removed from cart or checkout completed.

A scheduled task runs hourly to find reservations where expires_at is in the past and status is still active, updating their status to expired and releasing the stock back to available inventory.

Standard created_at and updated_at timestamps track record management.

carts

The carts table stores shopping cart information for customers accumulating items they intend to purchase. Each cart belongs to either a registered customer or a guest session.

The id field is the primary key. The user_id field is a nullable foreign key referencing users table, null for guest carts and populated for registered customer carts. The session_id field is a nullable string storing the browser session identifier for guest carts.

The status field is an enumeration with values active, abandoned, or converted. Active carts are currently being used. Abandoned carts have not been accessed in over 24 hours without checkout completion. Converted carts completed checkout and resulted in an order.

The coupon_code field is a nullable string storing an applied coupon code for this cart. The discount_amount field is a nullable decimal storing the calculated discount from the applied coupon. The notes field is a text type allowing customers to add notes about their order.

Standard created_at and updated_at timestamps track cart activity. Carts older than 30 days in abandoned status can be deleted to clean up the database.

cart_items

The cart_items table stores individual products or variants added to shopping carts. Each record represents a line item in a cart with specific quantity.

The id field is the primary key. The cart_id field is a foreign key referencing carts table. The product_id field is a foreign key referencing products table. The variant_id field is a nullable foreign key referencing product_variants table, null for simple products and populated when customers select specific variants.

The quantity field is an integer storing how many units of this item are in the cart. The unit_price field is a decimal capturing the price at the time the item was added to cart, protecting against price changes while the customer shops. The notes field is a nullable text allowing customers to add specific instructions about this item.

Standard created_at and updated_at timestamps track when items were added and last modified.

addresses

The addresses table stores shipping and billing addresses for customers. Each customer can have multiple saved addresses for convenience.

The id field is the primary key. The user_id field is a foreign key referencing users table indicating which customer owns this address. The address_type field is an enumeration with values shipping or billing, though addresses can be used for both purposes.

The full_name field stores the recipient name as a string. The phone field stores the contact phone number. The address_line1 field stores the street address with number and name. The address_line2 field is a nullable string for apartment or suite numbers.

The city, state_province, postal_code, and country fields store the location components as strings. The country field should use ISO country codes for standardization. The is_default field is a boolean indicating whether this is the customer's default address for its type, with only one default allowed per user and type.

Standard created_at and updated_at timestamps track record management.

orders

The orders table stores customer purchase requests containing one or more products from one or more vendors. Each order represents a single checkout transaction from the customer perspective, though it may split into multiple vendor fulfillments.

The id field is the primary key. The order_number field is a string storing a human-readable unique order identifier generated automatically, typically formatted like "ORD-20260206-0001" combining date and sequence number.

The customer_id field is a foreign key referencing users table indicating which customer placed the order. The shipping_address_id and billing_address_id fields are foreign keys referencing addresses table for delivery and billing locations.

The order_status field is an enumeration tracking fulfillment progress with values pending, processing, shipped, delivered, completed, cancelled, or refunded. The payment_status field is an enumeration tracking payment with values pending, authorized, paid, failed, or refunded.

The subtotal field is a decimal storing the sum of all item prices before tax, shipping, and discounts. The tax field is a decimal storing calculated sales tax. The shipping_charge field is a decimal storing shipping cost. The discount field is a decimal storing any coupon or promotional discounts applied. The total field is a decimal storing the final amount charged, calculated as subtotal plus tax plus shipping_charge minus discount.

The coupon_code field is a nullable string recording which coupon was applied if any. The payment_method field is an enumeration with values stripe_card, paypal, or cash_on_delivery. The transaction_id field is a nullable string storing the payment gateway's transaction reference for credit card or PayPal payments.

The shipping_method field is a string storing the selected shipping option. The tracking_number field is a nullable string storing the shipment tracking number once items ship. The notes field is a text type for customer notes or special instructions.

The cancelled_at field is a nullable timestamp recording when the order was cancelled if applicable. The admin_note field is a text type for administrator notes about the order visible only to admins. Standard timestamps created_at, updated_at, and deleted_at provide temporal tracking.

order_items

The order_items table stores individual products or variants within orders. Each record represents a line item with quantity, price captured at time of purchase, and vendor association.

The id field is the primary key. The order_id field is a foreign key referencing orders table. The product_id field is a foreign key referencing products table. The variant_id field is a nullable foreign key referencing product_variants table.

The vendor_id field is a foreign key referencing vendors table indicating which vendor is responsible for fulfilling this item. This enables multi-vendor order splitting where different items in the same order come from different vendors.

The product_name, product_sku, and variant_attributes fields store snapshot data at the time of purchase ensuring the order history remains accurate even if vendors later modify or delete products. The product_name is the product title, product_sku is the SKU, and variant_attributes is a JSON object with the variant details.

The quantity field is an integer storing how many units were ordered. The unit_price field is a decimal storing the price per unit at purchase time. The total_price field is a decimal calculated as unit_price times quantity. The tax_amount field is a decimal storing allocated tax for this item.

The status field is an enumeration with values pending, processing, shipped, delivered, cancelled, or refunded tracking this specific item's fulfillment state independent of other items in the order. The notes field is a text type for vendor notes about fulfilling this item.

Standard created_at and updated_at timestamps track record management.

payments

The payments table records payment transactions associated with orders. Each order typically has one payment record, though refunds create additional records.

The id field is the primary key. The order_id field is a foreign key referencing orders table. The payment_method field is an enumeration with values stripe_card, paypal, or cash_on_delivery matching the order's payment method.

The amount field is a decimal storing the payment amount. For initial payments, this equals the order total. For refunds, this stores the refunded amount. The currency field stores the three-letter ISO currency code.

The transaction_id field stores the payment gateway's transaction reference as a string. For Stripe, this is the charge ID. For PayPal, this is the PayPal transaction ID. For cash on delivery, this may be null or contain a reference number once cash is collected.

The status field is an enumeration with values pending, authorized, paid, failed, or refunded. Pending means payment is being processed. Authorized means funds are held but not yet captured. Paid means funds have been received. Failed means payment processing failed. Refunded means funds were returned to customer.

The gateway_response field is a JSON type storing the full response from the payment gateway for troubleshooting and audit purposes. The refund_amount field is a nullable decimal storing how much has been refunded if partial refunds occurred. The refunded_at field is a nullable timestamp recording when refund was processed.

The failure_reason field is a nullable text storing error messages if payment failed, useful for customer support. Standard created_at and updated_at timestamps track payment events.

commissions

The commissions table calculates and tracks platform earnings from vendor sales. Each order item generates a commission record capturing the platform fee and vendor payout breakdown.

The id field is the primary key. The order_id field is a foreign key referencing orders table. The order_item_id field is a foreign key referencing order_items table linking this commission to the specific item sold.

The vendor_id field is a foreign key referencing vendors table indicating which vendor owes this commission. The commission_rate field is a decimal storing the percentage rate applied, captured at transaction time so changes to vendor rates don't affect historical commissions.

The order_amount field is a decimal storing the item total price this commission is calculated from. The commission_amount field is a decimal calculated as order_amount times commission_rate divided by 100. The gateway_fee field is a decimal storing the payment processor's fee for this transaction, calculated proportionally if the order contains multiple vendors.

The vendor_payout field is a decimal calculated as order_amount minus commission_amount minus gateway_fee, representing what the vendor actually receives. The status field is an enumeration with values pending, released, or paid tracking the commission lifecycle.

Pending status applies when the order is new and might still be returned or cancelled. Released status applies once the order is delivered and the return window passes, making the commission available for payout. Paid status applies once the vendor receives payout including this commission.

The payout_id field is a nullable foreign key referencing payouts table, populated when this commission is included in a vendor payout. Standard created_at and updated_at timestamps track record evolution.

payouts

The payouts table records transfers of accumulated vendor earnings from the platform to vendor bank accounts. Each payout represents a batch of commission amounts being paid.

The id field is the primary key. The vendor_id field is a foreign key referencing vendors table. The amount field is a decimal storing the total payout amount. The payout_method field is an enumeration with values bank_transfer, ach, wire_transfer, or paypal.

The transaction_reference field is a nullable string storing the bank or payment processor's transaction ID for this payout once processed. The status field is an enumeration with values pending, processing, paid, or failed tracking payout progress.

Pending status means the payout request has been created but not yet processed by administrators. Processing means administrators have initiated the bank transfer but it has not completed. Paid means funds have successfully transferred to the vendor. Failed means the transfer failed due to invalid bank details or other errors.

The requested_at field is a timestamp recording when the vendor requested payout. The processed_at field is a nullable timestamp recording when an administrator began processing. The completed_at field is a nullable timestamp recording when the transfer completed successfully.

The processed_by field is a nullable foreign key referencing users table indicating which administrator processed the payout. The failure_reason field is a nullable text storing error messages if the transfer failed. The notes field is a text type for administrator notes about this payout.

Standard created_at and updated_at timestamps track record management.

reviews

The reviews table stores customer product reviews with star ratings and optional written feedback. Reviews help future customers make informed purchasing decisions.

The id field is the primary key. The product_id field is a foreign key referencing products table indicating which product is being reviewed. The user_id field is a foreign key referencing users table indicating which customer wrote the review.

The order_id field is a nullable foreign key referencing orders table verifying that this customer actually purchased this product. Only verified purchases can write reviews. The rating field is an integer storing the star rating from 1 to 5.

The title field is a nullable string storing a short summary of the review. The review_text field is a text type storing the detailed review content. The status field is an enumeration with values pending, approved, or rejected tracking moderation state.

The approved_at field is a nullable timestamp recording when a moderator approved the review. The approved_by field is a nullable foreign key referencing users table indicating which vendor or administrator approved the review. The rejection_reason field is a nullable text storing why the review was rejected if applicable.

The vendor_response field is a nullable text allowing vendors to respond to reviews. The vendor_responded_at field is a nullable timestamp recording when the vendor posted their response. The helpful_count field is an integer tracking how many customers marked this review as helpful.

Standard created_at, updated_at, and deleted_at timestamps support record tracking and soft deletion of inappropriate reviews.

review_images

The review_images table stores photos customers upload with their reviews showing the received product or demonstrating issues. Each record represents one image attached to a review.

The id field is the primary key. The review_id field is a foreign key referencing reviews table. The image_url field stores the URL to the uploaded image in object storage. The thumbnail_url field stores a smaller version for display in review listings.

The sort_order field is an integer determining display sequence if multiple images are attached. Standard created_at and updated_at timestamps track uploads.

wishlists

The wishlists table allows customers to save products they are interested in for future purchase. Each record represents one product on one customer's wishlist.

The id field is the primary key. The user_id field is a foreign key referencing users table. The product_id field is a foreign key referencing products table. The variant_id field is a nullable foreign key referencing product_variants table if the customer saved a specific variant.

The notify_on_sale field is a boolean indicating whether the customer wants notification when this product goes on sale. The notify_on_restock field is a boolean for out-of-stock items indicating the customer wants notification when inventory is replenished.

Standard created_at timestamp records when the item was added to wishlist.

coupons

The coupons table stores discount codes that customers can apply during checkout to reduce order totals. Each record defines a coupon's parameters and restrictions.

The id field is the primary key. The code field stores the alphanumeric coupon code as a string with unique constraint ensuring codes are unique. The discount_type field is an enumeration with values percentage, fixed_amount, or free_shipping.

The discount_value field is a decimal storing the discount amount. For percentage type, this is the percentage such as 20 for 20% off. For fixed_amount type, this is the dollar amount such as 10.00 for $10 off. For free_shipping type, this field is unused.

The min_order_amount field is a nullable decimal requiring order subtotal to exceed this threshold before the coupon applies. The max_discount_amount field is a nullable decimal capping the discount for percentage coupons, such as "20% off, maximum $50 discount".

The usage_limit field is a nullable integer defining how many total times the coupon can be used across all customers. The uses_per_customer field is a nullable integer limiting how many times one customer can use this coupon. The current_usage field is an integer tracking how many times the coupon has been used so far.

The start_date and end_date fields are timestamps defining the coupon's validity period. The is_active field is a boolean allowing manual activation and deactivation. The customer_eligibility field is an enumeration with values all, new_customers_only, or specific_customers.

The applicable_categories, applicable_products, and applicable_vendors fields are JSON arrays storing IDs of categories, products, or vendors this coupon applies to. Empty arrays mean no restrictions. Standard created_at and updated_at timestamps track record management.

coupon_usage

The coupon_usage table tracks individual uses of coupons enabling enforcement of usage limits and analysis of coupon effectiveness. Each record represents one application of a coupon to an order.

The id field is the primary key. The coupon_id field is a foreign key referencing coupons table. The order_id field is a foreign key referencing orders table. The user_id field is a foreign key referencing users table indicating which customer used the coupon.

The discount_amount field is a decimal storing the actual discount applied on this order. This may differ from the coupon's defined value due to maximum discount caps or order subtotal. Standard created_at timestamp records when the coupon was used.

notifications

The notifications table stores in-app notifications for users providing alerts about important events without requiring email. Each record represents one notification delivered to one user.

The id field is a primary key using UUID rather than auto-increment for better distribution and potential future scaling. The user_id field is a foreign key referencing users table indicating the notification recipient.

The type field is a string categorizing the notification such as "order_status_update", "review_posted", "low_stock_alert", or "vendor_approved". The title field is a string storing a brief notification heading.

The message field is a text type storing the complete notification text. The action_url field is a nullable string storing a URL the user can visit for more details, such as a link to the order page. The is_read field is a boolean tracking whether the user has viewed this notification.

The read_at field is a nullable timestamp recording when the notification was marked as read. The data field is a JSON type storing any additional structured data needed to render the notification or process actions.

Standard created_at timestamp records when the notification was generated.

activity_logs

The activity_logs table maintains a comprehensive audit trail of significant user actions for security monitoring and troubleshooting. Each record captures details about one action.

The id field is the primary key. The causer_id field is a nullable foreign key referencing users table indicating who performed the action. The causer_type field stores the model class of the actor for polymorphic relationships.

The subject_id field is a nullable foreign key storing the ID of the affected entity. The subject_type field stores the model class of the affected entity, such as "Product" or "Order". This polymorphic relationship allows logging actions on any entity type.

The action field is a string describing what happened such as "created", "updated", "deleted", "approved", or "rejected". The description field is a text type providing human-readable explanation of the action.

The properties field is a JSON type storing detailed information about the action including old and new values for updates. The ip_address field stores the IP address from which the action originated. The user_agent field stores the browser user agent string.

Standard created_at timestamp records when the action occurred.

platform_settings

The platform_settings table stores system-wide configuration values that administrators can modify without code changes. Each record represents one configuration setting.

The id field is the primary key. The key field is a string storing the setting identifier with unique constraint, such as "default_commission_rate" or "tax_rate". The value field is a text type storing the setting value as a string regardless of type.

The type field is an enumeration with values string, integer, decimal, boolean, or json indicating how the value should be parsed and validated. The group_name field is a string categorizing related settings, such as "commission", "tax", "shipping", or "features".

The description field is a nullable text explaining what the setting controls and valid value ranges. The is_public field is a boolean indicating whether this setting's value can be viewed by non-administrators.

Standard created_at and updated_at timestamps track configuration changes.

6.3 Indexes and Constraints

To ensure optimal query performance and data integrity, numerous indexes and constraints are implemented across the database schema.

Primary Key Indexes

Every table has a primary key constraint on its id field creating a unique index automatically. Primary keys use big integer auto-increment for sufficient capacity and fast lookups.

Foreign Key Constraints

All foreign key fields have foreign key constraints defined enforcing referential integrity. Constraints specify cascade rules determining behavior when referenced records are deleted. Most use restrict preventing deletion of referenced records while dependent records exist. Some use cascade automatically deleting dependent records, such as deleting order items when their parent order is deleted. A few use set null setting the foreign key to null rather than preventing deletion, appropriate for optional relationships.

Foreign key fields automatically receive indexes improving join performance.

Unique Constraints

Several fields require unique values across the table enforced through unique constraints. Examples include email in users table ensuring no duplicate accounts, slug in products and categories tables ensuring unique URLs, sku in products and product_variants tables within vendor scope, and code in coupons table ensuring unique coupon codes.

Unique constraints create indexes supporting fast lookups and duplicate detection during insertions.

Composite Indexes

Multi-column indexes optimize queries that filter or sort by multiple columns simultaneously. Key composite indexes include product_id and variant_id in stock_reservations for finding reservations on specific variants, product_id and created_at in reviews for fetching recent reviews of products, vendor_id and status in products for listing active products by vendor, and user_id and created_at in orders for order history queries.

Full-Text Search Indexes

PostgreSQL full-text search indexes support efficient searching within text fields. The products table has a GIN index on the concatenation of name and description fields enabling fast product searches by keyword. This index is automatically maintained when product content changes.

Partial Indexes

Partial indexes include only rows matching specified conditions, reducing index size and improving performance for filtered queries. Examples include an index on orders table where order_status equals 'pending' for quickly finding orders needing attention, and an index on commissions table where status equals 'released' for calculating available vendor balances.

Check Constraints

Check constraints enforce business rules at the database level preventing invalid data. Constraints include rating in reviews table must be between 1 and 5, commission_rate in vendors table must be between 0 and 100 representing valid percentages, price fields must be non-negative, and quantity fields must be non-negative.

These constraints provide defense in depth beyond application-level validation, protecting data integrity even if application bugs allow invalid data through.

6.4 Database Functions

Several PostgreSQL functions encapsulate frequently used logic as reusable database procedures.

get_available_stock Function

This function calculates available stock for a product or variant considering total stock, reserved stock from active carts, and pending stock from paid orders. The function accepts product_id and optional variant_id as parameters and returns an integer representing available quantity.

The calculation subtracts reserved quantity from stock_reservations where status equals active and expires_at is in the future, then subtracts pending quantity from order_items joined to orders where order_status is pending or processing and payment_status is paid. The result is total stock minus these deductions, with a minimum floor of zero preventing negative availability.

This function is used throughout the application wherever available stock needs displaying or validation, ensuring consistency in the calculation logic.

generate_order_number Function

This function generates unique human-readable order numbers following the format "ORD-YYYYMMDD-####" where YYYY is year, MM is month, DD is day, and #### is a zero-padded sequence number for that day.

The function queries the orders table to count existing orders placed on the current date, then increments that count by one to get the next sequence number. The components are concatenated with proper formatting and returned as a string.

This function is called automatically by a database trigger before inserting new order records, ensuring every order receives a unique number without requiring application logic to generate them.

calculate_commission Function

This function calculates platform commission for a given order amount and vendor, applying the vendor's commission rate or defaulting to the platform rate if not set. The function accepts vendor_id and order_amount as parameters and returns a decimal commission amount.

The function queries the vendors table to retrieve the commission_rate for the specified vendor. If the rate is null, it retrieves the default rate from platform_settings. It then multiplies the order amount by the rate divided by 100 to calculate the commission and returns the result rounded to two decimal places.

This function ensures commission calculations are consistent and can be easily adjusted by updating the commission rate without modifying application code.

6.5 Database Triggers

Database triggers automatically execute defined actions in response to data changes, maintaining derived fields and enforcing complex constraints.

Auto-Generate Order Number Trigger

A trigger on the orders table fires before insert operations to automatically populate the order_number field if it is null. The trigger calls the generate_order_number function and sets the order_number to the returned value. This ensures every order has a unique number without requiring explicit generation in application code.

Update Product Rating Trigger

A trigger on the reviews table fires after insert, update, or delete operations on approved reviews. The trigger recalculates the product's average_rating by averaging all approved review ratings and updates the total_reviews count. It then updates the products table setting these calculated values for the affected product.

This trigger keeps product ratings current without requiring separate application logic to update them whenever reviews change.

Update Category Product Count Trigger

A trigger on the products table fires after insert, update, or delete operations affecting the category_id field. The trigger increments the product_count for the new category when products are added or moved to a category, and decrements the product_count for the old category when products are removed or moved to a different category.

This trigger maintains accurate product counts in categories without manual maintenance.

Expire Stock Reservations Trigger

While this could be implemented as a trigger, it is more efficiently handled through a scheduled task that runs periodically. The task finds stock_reservations where expires_at is less than the current time and status equals active, then updates their status to expired. This releases reserved stock back to available inventory for other customers.

6.6 Database Views

Database views provide convenient access to frequently queried aggregated data without requiring complex joins in application code.

product_details_with_stock View

This view joins the products, categories, vendors, and product_images tables, calling the get_available_stock function to calculate real-time available inventory. The view selects all relevant product information along with category name, vendor name, primary image URL, average rating, and calculated stock status based on available quantity.

Application code queries this view to display product listings with complete information in a single query rather than fetching from multiple tables separately.

order_summary View

This view joins orders, users, and order_items tables to present comprehensive order information. It aggregates item count, vendor count, and includes customer name and contact information. Application code uses this view for displaying order lists in customer accounts and administrator dashboards.

vendor_earnings_summary View

This view aggregates commission data for vendors calculating total sales, total commission, total gateway fees, and total payout broken down by commission status. It provides available balance showing released but unpaid commission eligible for payout, and paid amount showing historical earnings already transferred.

Vendors query this view to display their earnings dashboard without complex aggregation queries in application code.

7. USER INTERFACE REQUIREMENTS

7.1 Design Principles

The platform's user interfaces across customer storefront, vendor dashboard, and admin panel adhere to consistent design principles ensuring usability, accessibility, and brand cohesion.

Consistency

Visual and interaction consistency reduces cognitive load enabling users to transfer knowledge between different parts of the interface. This is achieved through standardized components including consistent button styles with primary buttons using accent color and secondary buttons using neutral gray, unified form inputs with consistent padding, borders, and focus states, and standard navigation patterns with logos always linking to home and user menus in consistent locations.

Color usage follows established meanings with blue indicating informational content, green for success states and positive actions, yellow for warnings requiring caution, and red for errors or destructive actions. These color associations align with user expectations formed across web applications generally.

Typography uses a limited set of font families with clear hierarchy. Headings use a sans-serif font at progressively larger sizes for H1 through H6. Body text uses a highly readable sans-serif font at comfortable line height. Code and technical information uses monospace fonts for clarity.

Simplicity

Interfaces avoid unnecessary complexity presenting only information and controls relevant to the current task. Feature discovery follows progressive disclosure where advanced capabilities are accessible but not prominently displayed to avoid overwhelming users. Workflows guide users through multi-step processes one stage at a time, such as the checkout flow presenting shipping, payment, and review sequentially.

Clean layouts with appropriate whitespace prevent visual clutter. Generous padding around content blocks, adequate line spacing in text, and clear separation between distinct interface regions all contribute to comfortable reading and comprehension.

Feedback

Every user action receives immediate feedback confirming receipt and indicating processing state. Button clicks trigger visual changes like color shift or ripple effects. Form submissions show loading indicators while processing. Success and error states display through toast notifications or inline messages clearly communicating outcomes.

Progress indicators inform users during longer operations. Loading spinners appear for operations taking several seconds. Progress bars with percentage display for operations with measurable progress like file uploads. Skeleton screens provide content structure placeholders while data loads, maintaining perceived performance.

Accessibility

Interfaces are designed to be perceivable, operable, understandable, and robust for users with diverse abilities. Color is never the sole means of conveying information with shape, text, or icons supplementing color-based indicators. Contrast ratios meet WCAG AA standards with text and interactive elements having sufficient contrast against backgrounds.

Keyboard navigation supports all interactive elements without requiring mouse usage. Tab order follows logical reading sequence. Focus indicators clearly show which element has keyboard focus. Escape key dismisses modal dialogs and dropdown menus.

Screen reader support includes semantic HTML structure with proper heading hierarchy, descriptive alt text for images conveying meaning, form labels associated with inputs, and ARIA attributes clarifying complex interactions and dynamic content.

Responsive Design

All customer-facing interfaces adapt to various screen sizes from mobile phones to desktop monitors. Mobile-first design prioritizes essential content and functionality for small screens then progressively enhances for larger displays. Touch targets on mobile meet minimum 44x44 pixel size recommendations ensuring easy interaction. Hamburger menus on mobile expand to horizontal navigation on desktop.

Vendor and admin interfaces primarily target desktop usage given their complexity and data density but remain functional on tablets for occasional access.

7.2 Customer Storefront Interface

The customer-facing e-commerce storefront is designed for easy product discovery, informed decision-making, and smooth checkout completion.

Homepage

The homepage provides immediate orientation and multiple paths into the product catalog. A prominent header includes the platform logo linking to homepage, a search bar with autocomplete supporting immediate product search, navigation links to main product categories, a shopping cart icon with item count badge, and user account menu or sign in link.

A hero section features promotional banners highlighting current sales, new products, or featured categories with compelling imagery and calls to action. Featured product sections showcase popular or promoted items with product cards displaying image, name, price, and rating at a glance. Category tiles provide visual entry points into the product hierarchy with representative images and product counts.

The footer contains links to important pages including about us, contact support, shipping information, return policy, privacy policy, and terms of service. Social media links and newsletter signup encourage ongoing engagement.

Category and Search Pages

Product listing pages present search results or category contents in scannable grid layouts. A filters sidebar offers refinement options based on category attributes, price ranges, brands, ratings, and availability. Applied filters display as removable chips above results for easy modification.

Sorting controls allow organizing results by relevance for search, price low to high or high to low, newest products, highest rated, or most reviews. Pagination or infinite scroll enables browsing large result sets.

Each product card in the grid displays the primary product image as a clickable link to detail page, product name, current price with crossed-out regular price if on sale, average star rating with review count, and a quick add-to-cart button for simple products or a select options button for variable products.

Hover interactions on desktop show additional product images, wishlist heart icon for saving products, and quick view button for expanded information in a modal without navigating away.

Product Detail Page

The product detail page provides comprehensive information enabling purchase decisions. An image gallery shows multiple product images with thumbnails allowing selection and enlarged view on click. A primary image area displays the selected image large.

Product information includes the product name as a prominent heading, average rating and total review count with link to reviews section, current price and regular price if on sale, stock availability clearly indicating in stock, low stock, or out of stock, product description with formatting for readability, attribute selectors for variable products allowing size, color, or other variant selection, quantity selector with plus and minus buttons, and add to cart button prominently displayed.

Tabs or accordion sections organize additional information including detailed specifications with attribute names and values, shipping information explaining delivery timeframes and costs, return policy outlining return window and conditions, and seller information showing vendor name with link to their store.

A customer reviews section displays approved reviews sorted by helpfulness or recency. Each review shows star rating, review title, detailed text, customer name and verified purchase badge, review date, and helpful count with buttons for marking reviews helpful. Vendors' responses appear nested below reviews when present.

A related products section suggests similar or complementary items encouraging exploration and increased cart value.

Shopping Cart

The cart page lists all items currently in the customer's cart with product image and name, selected variant attributes if applicable, unit price and quantity selector, subtotal for each line item, and remove button for deleting items.

The cart summary shows subtotal summing all items, estimated tax if calculable, estimated shipping if calculable, applied coupon discount if any with code displayed, and estimated total. A proceed to checkout button advances to checkout when clicked.

Coupon application provides an input field for entering coupon codes and an apply button. Invalid codes display error messages explaining the issue such as expiration or minimum order requirements. Valid codes immediately update the cart total showing the discount.

Empty cart state displays a message indicating the cart is empty with a continue shopping button linking to product listings or homepage.

Checkout Flow

Checkout progresses through distinct steps ensuring all necessary information is collected methodically.

The customer information step prompts guests for email and full name or automatically populates for logged-in customers. The shipping address step presents saved addresses for selection or a form for entering new addresses with fields for recipient name, phone, street address, apartment or suite, city, state or province, postal code, and country. A save address checkbox allows adding the address to the customer's account.

The shipping method step displays available shipping options with delivery timeframes and costs, allowing the customer to select their preferred method. The review order step presents a comprehensive summary including each ordered item with image, name, variant, quantity, and price, selected shipping address, selected shipping method and cost, payment method selection pending next step, calculated tax, any applied discount, and final total.

The payment step offers available payment methods with Stripe card payment showing embedded card input fields that are PCI-compliant, PayPal showing a button to redirect to PayPal login and payment approval, or cash on delivery if enabled with explanation that payment occurs upon delivery.

A place order button finalizes the purchase, triggering payment processing and order creation. Processing displays a loading indicator preventing duplicate submissions. Success redirects to an order confirmation page with the order number, estimated delivery date, and link to track the order. Failure displays an error message explaining the issue such as payment declined, allowing retry.

Order Tracking

After placing an order, customers access order details through their account dashboard. The order detail page shows the order number and date, current order status with progress indicator, itemized list of products with images and quantities, shipping address, tracking information with carrier name and tracking number linked to carrier tracking page, payment information including method and amount, and order summary with subtotal, tax, shipping, discount, and total.

A timeline visualizes order progress with checkpoints for order placed, payment confirmed, processing started, shipped, and delivered. Completed checkpoints display with check marks while future checkpoints appear as unfilled circles.

Action buttons enable order cancellation if status allows, initiating return for delivered items, contacting support for questions, and downloading invoice as PDF.

7.3 Vendor Dashboard Interface

The vendor dashboard provides comprehensive tools for managing products, inventory, orders, and earnings within a focused business management environment.

Dashboard Overview

The main dashboard presents key metrics and quick access to common tasks. Summary cards display current month sales revenue, order count, active products count, pending orders requiring attention, available balance eligible for payout, and low stock alerts count. Line charts visualize sales trends over the past thirty days and order volume patterns.

Quick action buttons provide shortcuts to add new product, view pending orders, request payout if balance is sufficient, and manage inventory. A recent orders widget lists the five most recent orders with status for quick reference.

Product Management

The products page lists all vendor products in a searchable, filterable table with columns for product image thumbnail, product name with clickable link to detail, SKU, price, stock quantity and status, status whether active or inactive, and actions menu with edit, duplicate, and delete options.

Filters allow narrowing by category, status whether active or inactive, stock status whether in stock or out of stock, and date range for creation date. Bulk actions enable selecting multiple products for batch operations like activating, deactivating, or exporting.

The add product page presents a comprehensive form with basic information section for product name, category selection, description with rich text editor for formatting, brand name, and SKU. The pricing section captures regular price, optional sale price with active dates, and tax class if applicable.

For simple products, the inventory section includes stock quantity input, low stock threshold, and stock status selection. For variable products, the attributes section presents variant-defining attributes from category templates with value selection, generating a variants table where the vendor enters SKU, price, and stock for each combination.

The images section allows uploading multiple product images with drag-and-drop reordering to set the primary image. The SEO section provides optional meta title, meta description, and keywords for search optimization. Save as draft, save and continue editing, and publish buttons offer workflow flexibility.

The edit product page presents the same form pre-filled with current product data. An additional product performance section shows views count, cart additions, orders, and revenue generated providing insights into product success.

Inventory Management

The inventory page displays all products and variants with current stock levels in a table format. Columns show product name, SKU, current stock, low stock threshold, status, and quick adjustment controls. In-line editing allows typing new quantities directly in the table with automatic saving.

Bulk adjustment functionality enables uploading a CSV file with SKUs and new quantities for mass inventory updates after physical counts. The system validates the file, processes updates, and reports any errors or skipped lines.

The inventory movements history shows a log of all stock changes with date and time, product and SKU, movement type whether addition or subtraction, quantity changed, reason code, performed by user, and notes explaining the adjustment.

Low stock alerts prominently display at the top of the inventory page listing products currently below threshold with urgency indicated by color coding. Quick restock buttons allow adjusting inventory directly from the alerts.

Order Management

The orders page lists all orders containing the vendor's products in a table with order number, order date, customer name, items count and which items are the vendor's, order total, status, and actions. Since orders may contain items from multiple vendors, the vendor sees only their relevant items and their portion of commission.

Filters narrow orders by status, date range, or customer name. Clicking an order number opens the order detail page showing customer shipping address, customer contact information, order items belonging to this vendor with product names, quantities, and prices, current order status for these items, and action buttons to update status, add notes, and view full order details if needed.

Status update controls allow marking orders as processing when beginning fulfillment, shipped when dispatched with required tracking number entry, or requesting cancellation with reason if unable to fulfill. Changing to shipped triggers email notification to the customer with tracking information.

Order notes allow internal communication about the order or customer-visible messages that appear in the customer's order tracking page.

Earnings and Payouts

The earnings page displays financial summary showing total sales revenue lifetime, total platform commission charged, total gateway fees deducted, total vendor payout amount, available balance in released commission ready for payout, and pending balance in commission not yet released due to ongoing order fulfillment or return windows.

A sales breakdown table lists each completed order with order number and date, order total, commission charged, gateway fee, net payout amount for this vendor's items, commission status, and payout reference if included in a payout.

The request payout button becomes active when available balance exceeds the minimum payout threshold. Clicking it opens a dialog confirming the payout amount and bank account details showing last four digits, with proceed button submitting the request.

Payout history shows past payouts with payout date, amount, transfer method, status, transaction reference when available, and download receipt button for PDF payout confirmation documents.

Profile Settings

The vendor profile settings page allows updating business information including business name, description, address, phone, and website. Document uploads replace expired or updated verification documents. Banking information can be updated with new account details requiring re-verification before payouts can process.

Notification preferences control email and SMS alerts for new orders, low stock warnings, review postings, and payout confirmations. Password change requires current password confirmation before accepting a new password meeting security requirements.

7.4 Administrator Panel Interface

The administrator panel provides comprehensive platform management tools with deep visibility into all aspects of the marketplace.

Admin Dashboard

The admin dashboard presents platform-wide metrics and pending actions. Summary cards show total platform revenue, total commission earned by platform, active vendors count, total orders count, total customers count, and pending tasks count requiring admin attention.

Charts visualize revenue trends over time comparing current and previous periods, orders by status distribution, top vendors by sales volume or revenue, and top categories by product count or revenue.

A pending actions panel lists counts for vendor applications awaiting approval, category requests awaiting review, flagged reviews requiring moderation, payout requests awaiting processing, and disputed returns escalated to admin. Each count links directly to the relevant management queue.

Vendor Management

The vendors page lists all vendors in a searchable table with business name, owner name and email, registration date, status whether pending, approved, suspended, or rejected, total products count, and actions menu. Filters narrow by status, registration date range, or product count ranges.

The pending vendors queue shows only vendors awaiting approval with quick view of submitted information including business details, uploaded verification documents, and notes. Actions include approve with optional custom commission rate, reject with required reason, or request more information sending a message to the vendor.

Clicking a vendor opens their detail page showing complete business information, verification documents with download links, banking details with sensitive fields masked, statistics including total products, total orders, total sales revenue, average rating, and commission totals, product list showing all products from this vendor with links to edit, order history showing orders containing this vendor's items, and admin actions including suspend with reason, change commission rate with effective date, send message to vendor, or view activity log.

Category Management

The categories page shows the hierarchical category structure in a tree view allowing expansion and collapsing of subcategories. Each category node displays the category name, product count, status whether active or pending, and action buttons.

The pending categories queue lists categories created by vendors awaiting admin approval. Each pending category shows the vendor who created it, proposed category name and description, parent category if specified, how many products the vendor has already listed in this pending category, and actions to approve making it visible platform-wide, reject with reason and suggested alternative, or modify and approve allowing minor edits before approval.

Editing a category allows changing name, slug, description, parent category, display order, attribute templates assigned to this category, and status. Deactivating a category hides it from customers but retains products in that category for vendor management.

The attribute templates section within category management shows templates assigned to each category. Admins can add new templates, edit existing ones defining attribute name, type, requirements, and predefined options, or remove templates no longer needed. Removing a template does not delete existing product attributes using that template but prevents new products from using it.

Product Management

The products page lists all products across all vendors in a comprehensive table with product name and thumbnail, vendor name, category, price, stock, status, and actions. Filters include vendor selection, category selection, status, stock status, date range, and search by name or SKU.

Admins can edit any product making corrections or updates on behalf of vendors. The edit interface matches the vendor product form with all fields accessible. Changes are logged in the activity log with admin identity captured.

Featured product management allows admins to mark select products as featured, controlling which products appear in featured sections on the storefront. A dedicated featured products page shows all currently featured products with ability to add or remove featured status.

Product moderation tools allow administrators to deactivate products violating policies, contact vendors about policy concerns, or permanently delete products in severe cases of fraud or prohibited content. All moderation actions require reason entry and are logged.

Order Management

The orders page shows all orders across the platform with comprehensive filtering by order number, customer, vendor, status, payment status, date range, and total amount ranges. The table displays order number, customer name, order date, items count, vendors involved, total amount, order status, payment status, and actions.

Clicking an order opens full order details visible to administrators including all ordered items from all vendors with vendor assignment for each, complete customer information, shipping and billing addresses, payment details including gateway transaction ID, commission breakdown by vendor, order timeline showing status changes, and admin action buttons.

Admin actions on orders include processing refunds full or partial with automatic commission adjustment, forcing order cancellation overriding vendor fulfillment with reason entry, updating shipping information on behalf of vendors, adding administrator notes visible only to admins, and viewing activity log for this order showing all status changes and actions taken.

Disputed orders or returns escalated by customers appear in a dedicated disputes queue with customer complaint, vendor response, supporting documentation from both parties, and admin decision options to side with customer forcing refund, side with vendor denying refund, or propose compromise solution.

Customer Management

The customers page lists all registered customers with name, email, registration date, total orders count, total spending, and status whether active or suspended. Search and filter by name, email, registration date, or spending ranges.

Customer detail pages show full customer profile including contact information, order history, review history, wishlist items, addresses saved, and account activity. Admins can reset passwords for locked-out customers, suspend accounts for policy violations with reason, or permanently delete accounts at customer request per data protection regulations.

Commission and Payout Management

The commissions page provides comprehensive reporting on platform earnings with filters by vendor, date range, status, or payout status. The table shows order reference, vendor name, order amount, commission amount, gateway fee, vendor payout, commission status, and associated payout if paid.

Summary statistics aggregate total commission earned, total pending commission, total released commission, and total paid commission. Export options generate CSV or PDF reports for accounting purposes.

The payouts page lists all payout requests from vendors with requested date, vendor name, requested amount, status, and actions. Pending payouts await admin processing with approve and process action initiating bank transfer, or reject with reason if banking details are invalid.

Processing payouts involves verifying bank account information, initiating transfer through banking interface or payment processor, entering transaction reference number once transfer completes, and marking payout as completed which updates included commissions to paid status and sends confirmation to vendor.

Payout history shows all processed payouts with detailed records for audit and accounting purposes including transaction references, dates, amounts, and transfer methods used.

Reports and Analytics

The reports section provides comprehensive business intelligence. Sales reports show revenue trends over time with breakdown by product, category, vendor, or time period. Filters enable customizing date ranges, granularity whether daily, weekly, or monthly, and grouping dimensions.

Vendor performance reports rank vendors by sales volume, order count, average order value, customer ratings, cancellation rate, and refund rate. This identifies top-performing vendors and those requiring support or policy enforcement.

Customer analytics show acquisition trends tracking new customer registrations, retention metrics measuring repeat purchase rates, lifetime value calculations, and cohort analysis grouping customers by registration period and tracking their behavior over time.

Product analytics identify top-selling products, categories with highest revenue, products with highest cart abandonment rates suggesting pricing or description issues, and products with high return rates indicating quality concerns.

Conversion funnel reports track how customers progress through key flows measuring percentage of visitors who view products, add to cart, initiate checkout, and complete purchase. This identifies where customers drop off and opportunities for optimization.

Settings and Configuration

The platform settings section allows configuring global parameters affecting platform behavior. General settings include site name displayed in headers and emails, default currency for all transactions, time zone for timestamp display, and contact information for customer support.

Commission settings define default commission rate applied to new vendors, commission structure whether flat percentage, tiered based on sales volume, or category-based varying by product type, and minimum payout threshold determining when vendors can request payouts.

Tax settings configure tax calculation including tax rate percentage, whether prices are tax-inclusive or tax-exclusive, regions where tax applies if not global, and tax-exempt product categories if any.

Payment settings manage payment gateway configurations including Stripe API keys for card processing, PayPal credentials for PayPal payments, and cash on delivery availability and maximum order amount limits. Administrators can test gateway connections verifying credentials are valid.

Shipping settings define available shipping methods with names, descriptions, costs, and estimated delivery times. Shipping zones can restrict methods to specific geographic regions or set different rates by region.

Email settings configure SMTP server details for sending emails including host, port, authentication credentials, and from address. Email template management allows editing email content and design for various transactional emails sent by the platform.

Feature flags toggle optional functionality including whether product reviews are enabled, whether wishlist is available, whether vendor messaging is allowed, and whether auto-approval of products is active or manual moderation is required.

Notification preferences control which events trigger notifications and through which channels including email, SMS, or in-app notifications for different event types.

8. SECURITY REQUIREMENTS

8.1 Authentication Security

Authentication mechanisms must protect against unauthorized access while providing convenient user experience.

Password Requirements

User passwords must meet minimum complexity requirements ensuring resistance to brute force and dictionary attacks. Required criteria include minimum length of eight characters, at least one uppercase letter, at least one lowercase letter, and at least one digit. While special characters improve strength, they are not mandatory to balance security with user convenience.

Passwords are hashed using bcrypt with a cost factor of 12 before storage. Bcrypt's adaptive nature allows increasing the cost factor as computing power grows maintaining long-term security. Plain text passwords are never stored or logged, preventing exposure through data breaches or log files.

Password strength indicators provide real-time feedback during registration and password changes using visual bars showing weak, fair, good, or strong strength levels based on length, character diversity, and absence from common password dictionaries. This guides users toward stronger passwords without imposing overly complex requirements.

Account Lockout

Brute force password guessing is mitigated through account lockout after multiple failed authentication attempts. After five consecutive failed login attempts from the same IP address within a fifteen-minute window, that IP is temporarily blocked for one hour. This prevents automated password guessing tools from systematically trying passwords.

After three failed login attempts for a specific user account regardless of IP address, additional authentication is required using email verification where a one-time code is sent to the registered email and must be entered to proceed with login attempt. This protects accounts even if attackers use distributed IP addresses.

Account lockout status is stored with timestamps enabling automatic unlock after timeout periods. Administrators can manually unlock accounts if legitimate users are locked out. Lockout events are logged with IP addresses and timestamps for security monitoring.

Session Management

User sessions maintain authenticated state between requests without requiring re-authentication. Sessions are implemented using secure, httpOnly cookies containing session IDs. The httpOnly flag prevents JavaScript access protecting against XSS-based session theft. The secure flag ensures cookies are only transmitted over HTTPS.

Session IDs are generated using cryptographically strong random number generators ensuring unpredictability. Session fixation attacks are prevented by generating new session IDs after successful authentication invalidating any pre-authentication session ID an attacker might have obtained.

Sessions expire after thirty minutes of inactivity requiring re-authentication to continue. This limits the window for session hijacking if a user leaves their device unattended. Users can optionally enable remember me functionality extending session duration to thirty days for convenience on trusted devices.

Concurrent session detection allows users to view active sessions across different devices and browsers through account settings with options to terminate specific sessions. This enables users to revoke access if they suspect unauthorized session usage.

Two-Factor Authentication

Optional two-factor authentication provides an additional security layer beyond passwords. Users can enable 2FA through account settings by registering an authenticator app such as Google Authenticator or Authy. The system generates a QR code containing the 2FA secret which the user scans with their app.

After scanning, the user must provide a current code from their authenticator app to confirm successful setup. Once enabled, login requires both the password and a current time-based one-time password from the authenticator app. Incorrect codes increment failed attempt counters with temporary lockout after multiple failures.

Backup codes are generated during 2FA setup allowing account recovery if the authenticator device is lost. These single-use codes are displayed once and should be saved securely. Using a backup code displays a warning to reset 2FA with a new device.

Disabling 2FA requires current password plus a current 2FA code ensuring attackers cannot disable 2FA even if they compromise the password alone.

Password Reset Security

Password reset functionality allows users to regain access to accounts when passwords are forgotten. Requests are initiated by entering the registered email address which triggers sending a password reset email. The email contains a unique reset token that is valid for one hour.

Reset tokens are generated using cryptographic random generation and stored hashed in the database preventing offline attacks if the database is compromised. Tokens are single-use with invalidation upon usage or expiration.

Reset links direct users to a password reset form where they enter a new password meeting complexity requirements. Old passwords cannot be reused immediately preventing users from simply resetting to the same compromised password.

Password reset requests are rate-limited to five per email address per day preventing abuse for harassment or denial of service. All password resets are logged with IP addresses and timestamps for security auditing.

8.2 Authorization and Access Control

Authorization determines what authenticated users are permitted to do, enforcing appropriate access restrictions.

Role-Based Access Control

The platform implements role-based access control where permissions are granted to roles and users are assigned roles. The defined roles are customer having access to shopping features, product browsing, cart and checkout, order tracking, and review writing, vendor having access to product management, inventory control, order fulfillment, earnings tracking, and payout requests, admin having access to vendor approval, category management, order oversight, commission management, customer support, and platform configuration, and super admin having all administrator capabilities plus user management, critical settings modification, and direct database access for emergencies.

Users are assigned exactly one role during account creation or vendor approval determining their access level.
