Integration Layer connects to external services including Stripe and PayPal for payment processing, AWS S3 for file storage, SendGrid for email delivery, and Twilio for SMS notifications. Integrations are abstracted behind interfaces allowing swapping implementations without affecting core business logic.

Infrastructure Layer runs on containerized services orchestrated by Docker and deployed to cloud infrastructure. Load balancers distribute traffic, auto-scaling adds capacity dynamically, and monitoring systems track health and performance. Infrastructure as Code using Docker Compose and potentially Kubernetes manages environment configuration.

1.4 Key Architectural Decisions

Several critical architectural decisions shape the platform's design:

Monolithic Laravel Application - Despite the popularity of microservices, we've chosen a well-structured monolithic Laravel application for initial development. This decision is based on team expertise, faster initial development, easier deployment and debugging, and simpler data consistency. The modular internal structure allows future extraction of services if scale demands.

Separate Frontend Applications - While the backend is monolithic, frontend applications are separate codebases. This enables independent deployment, technology choice appropriate to each interface's needs, and parallel development by specialized teams. API-first design ensures frontends remain loosely coupled.

PostgreSQL as Primary Database - PostgreSQL was selected over MySQL due to advanced features including better JSON support, full-text search capabilities, robust transaction handling, and superior query optimizer. The platform leverages PostgreSQL-specific features like array types, generated columns, and materialized views.

Redis for Caching and Sessions - Redis provides sub-millisecond data access making it ideal for caching frequently accessed data and storing user sessions. Its pub/sub capabilities support real-time features, and it serves as the queue backend for background jobs.

Meilisearch for Product Search - Rather than PostgreSQL full-text search or Elasticsearch, Meilisearch was chosen for its simplicity, instant search speed, typo tolerance, and lower resource requirements. It's specifically designed for customer-facing search experiences.

Object Storage for Files - AWS S3 or compatible services store uploaded files rather than local filesystems. This enables horizontal scaling without shared filesystem requirements, provides built-in redundancy, and integrates with CDN for global distribution.

Queue-Based Background Processing - Time-consuming operations like sending emails, processing images, and updating search indexes execute asynchronously through Laravel's queue system. This keeps API responses fast and improves perceived performance.

2. SYSTEM ARCHITECTURE OVERVIEW

2.1 Architectural Diagram

2.2 Component Interaction Flow

Customer Product Search Flow

Customer Browser

      ‚îÇ
      ‚îÇ (1) Enter search query "laptop"
      ‚ñº
Next.js Frontend
      ‚îÇ
      ‚îÇ (2) API Request: GET /api/v1/products/search?q=laptop
      ‚ñº
Nginx (API Gateway)
      ‚îÇ
      ‚îÇ (3) Route to Laravel, Check rate limits
      ‚ñº
Laravel Application
      ‚îÇ
      ‚îÇ (4) Validate request, Extract parameters
      ‚ñº
ProductSearchService
      ‚îÇ
      ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ(5)‚îÄ‚ñ∫ Meilisearch
      ‚îÇ        ‚îÇ Query: "laptop"
      ‚îÇ        ‚îÇ Return: Product IDs [1,2,3,4,5]
      ‚îÇ        ‚ñº
      ‚îÇ        Search Results
      ‚îÇ
      ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ(6)‚îÄ‚ñ∫ Redis Cache
      ‚îÇ        ‚îÇ Check: products:1,2,3,4,5
      ‚îÇ        ‚îÇ Result: Hit for products 1,3,5
      ‚îÇ        ‚ñº
      ‚îÇ        Cached Products
      ‚îÇ
      ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ(7)‚îÄ‚ñ∫ PostgreSQL
      ‚îÇ        ‚îÇ Query: Products WHERE id IN (2,4)
      ‚îÇ        ‚îÇ Return: Full product details
      ‚îÇ        ‚ñº
      ‚îÇ        Database Results
      ‚îÇ
      ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ(8)‚îÄ‚ñ∫ Cache products 2,4 in Redis
      ‚îÇ
      ‚îÇ (9) Format results through ProductResource
      ‚ñº
JSON Response
      ‚îÇ
      ‚îÇ (10) HTTP 200 with product data
      ‚ñº
Next.js Frontend
      ‚îÇ
      ‚îÇ (11) Render product grid
      ‚ñº
Customer Browser
1. Customer browser ‡¶•‡ßá‡¶ï‡ßá "laptop" search query ‡¶™‡¶æ‡¶†‡¶æ‡¶®‡ßã ‡¶π‡¶Ø‡¶º
2. Next.js frontend API call ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡ßá Laravel backend ‡¶è
3. Nginx gateway request receive ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡ßá, rate limit check ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡ßá
4. Laravel application request validate ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡ßá
5. Meilisearch ‡¶•‡ßá‡¶ï‡ßá matching product IDs ‡¶™‡¶æ‡¶Ø‡¶º
6. Redis cache check ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡ßá - ‡¶ï‡¶ø‡¶õ‡ßÅ products cache ‡¶è ‡¶Ü‡¶õ‡ßá (1,3,5)
7. ‡¶Ø‡ßá products cache ‡¶è ‡¶®‡ßá‡¶á (2,4) ‡¶∏‡ßá‡¶ó‡ßÅ‡¶≤‡ßã PostgreSQL ‡¶•‡ßá‡¶ï‡ßá fetch ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡ßá

11. Customer browser ‡¶è product grid display ‡¶π‡¶Ø‡¶º
Order Placement Flow
Customer (Checkout Page)
      ‚îÇ
      ‚îÇ (1) Click "Place Order" button
      ‚ñº
React Frontend
      ‚îÇ
      ‚îÇ (2) Collect order data (items, address, payment)
      ‚îÇ (3) Create Stripe Payment Intent
      ‚ñº
Stripe.js (Client-side)
      ‚îÇ
      ‚îÇ (4) Collect card details securely
      ‚îÇ (5) Confirm payment with Stripe
      ‚ñº
Stripe Servers
      ‚îÇ
      ‚îÇ (6) Process payment, return status
      ‚ñº
React Frontend
      ‚îÇ
      ‚îÇ (7) POST /api/v1/orders
      ‚îÇ     Body: { items, address, payment_intent_id }
      ‚ñº
Laravel Application
      ‚îÇ
      ‚îÇ (8) Validate request
      ‚îÇ (9) Begin Database Transaction
      ‚îÇ
      ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ(10)‚îÄ‚ñ∫ Check Stock Availability
      ‚îÇ         ‚îÇ Query: get_available_stock(products)
      ‚îÇ         ‚îÇ Validate: quantity <= available
      ‚îÇ         ‚ñº
      ‚îÇ         Stock OK
      ‚îÇ
      ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ(11)‚îÄ‚ñ∫ Create Order Record
      ‚îÇ         ‚îÇ INSERT INTO orders (...)
      ‚îÇ         ‚îÇ Generate order_number
      ‚îÇ         ‚ñº
      ‚îÇ         Order Created
      ‚îÇ
      ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ(12)‚îÄ‚ñ∫ Create Order Items
      ‚îÇ         ‚îÇ INSERT INTO order_items (...)
      ‚îÇ         ‚îÇ Capture prices at purchase time
      ‚îÇ         ‚ñº
      ‚îÇ         Items Created
      ‚îÇ
      ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ(13)‚îÄ‚ñ∫ Update Stock Reservations
      ‚îÇ         ‚îÇ UPDATE stock_reservations
      ‚îÇ         ‚îÇ Convert cart reservations to committed
      ‚îÇ         ‚ñº
      ‚îÇ         Stock Committed
      ‚îÇ
      ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ(14)‚îÄ‚ñ∫ Create Commission Records
      ‚îÇ         ‚îÇ Calculate: order_amount * commission_rate
      ‚îÇ         ‚îÇ INSERT INTO commissions (...)
      ‚îÇ         ‚ñº
      ‚îÇ         Commission Tracked
      ‚îÇ
      ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ(15)‚îÄ‚ñ∫ Create Payment Record
      ‚îÇ         ‚îÇ INSERT INTO payments (...)
      ‚îÇ         ‚îÇ Store transaction_id
      ‚îÇ         ‚ñº
      ‚îÇ         Payment Recorded
      ‚îÇ
      ‚îÇ (16) Commit Transaction
      ‚îÇ
      ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ(17)‚îÄ‚ñ∫ Dispatch Jobs to Queue
      ‚îÇ         ‚îÇ SendOrderConfirmationEmail
      ‚îÇ         ‚îÇ NotifyVendorsNewOrder
      ‚îÇ         ‚îÇ UpdateSearchIndex
      ‚îÇ         ‚ñº
      ‚îÇ         Jobs Queued
      ‚îÇ
      ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ(18)‚îÄ‚ñ∫ Clear Customer Cart
      ‚îÇ         ‚îÇ DELETE FROM cart_items
      ‚îÇ         ‚îÇ UPDATE cart status = 'converted'
      ‚îÇ         ‚ñº
      ‚îÇ         Cart Cleared
      ‚îÇ
      ‚îÇ (19) Return success response
      ‚ñº
JSON Response
      ‚îÇ
      ‚îÇ (20) { order_number, status, total }
      ‚ñº
React Frontend
      ‚îÇ
      ‚îÇ (21) Redirect to order confirmation page
      ‚ñº
Customer (Order Confirmed)
1. Customer checkout page ‡¶•‡ßá‡¶ï‡ßá "Place Order" click ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡ßá
2. React frontend ‡¶∏‡¶¨ order data collect ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡ßá
3. Stripe ‡¶è‡¶∞ ‡¶∏‡¶æ‡¶•‡ßá payment intent create ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡ßá
4. Stripe.js securely card details collect ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡ßá
5. Payment confirm ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡ßá Stripe servers ‡¶è
6. Stripe payment process ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡ßá status return ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡ßá
7. Frontend order data Laravel ‡¶è POST ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡ßá
8. Laravel request validate ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡ßá
9. Database transaction ‡¶∂‡ßÅ‡¶∞‡ßÅ ‡¶π‡¶Ø‡¶º
10. Stock availability check ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡ßá - ‡¶Ø‡¶•‡ßá‡¶∑‡ßç‡¶ü stock ‡¶Ü‡¶õ‡ßá ‡¶ï‡¶ø‡¶®‡¶æ
11. Orders table ‡¶è new order create ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡ßá
12. Order items create ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡ßá current prices capture ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡ßá
13. Cart reservations order ‡¶è convert ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡ßá
14. Commission records create ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡ßá vendor payouts track ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡¶æ‡¶∞ ‡¶ú‡¶®‡ßç‡¶Ø
15. Payment record create ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡ßá transaction details ‡¶∏‡¶π
16. ‡¶∏‡¶¨ ‡¶ï‡¶ø‡¶õ‡ßÅ ‡¶†‡¶ø‡¶ï ‡¶•‡¶æ‡¶ï‡¶≤‡ßá transaction commit ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡ßá
17. Background jobs queue ‡¶§‡ßá dispatch ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡ßá (emails, notifications)
18. Customer ‡¶è‡¶∞ cart clear ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡ßá
19. Success response return ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡ßá
20. Order number ‡¶è‡¶¨‡¶Ç details frontend ‡¶è ‡¶™‡¶æ‡¶†‡¶æ‡¶Ø‡¶º
21. Customer confirmation page ‡¶¶‡ßá‡¶ñ‡¶§‡ßá ‡¶™‡¶æ‡¶Ø‡¶º
Background Job Processing Flow
Laravel Application
      ‚îÇ
      ‚îÇ (1) Dispatch Job: SendOrderConfirmationEmail
      ‚îÇ     Job payload: { order_id: 123 }
      ‚ñº
Redis Queue
      ‚îÇ
      ‚îÇ (2) Job stored in queue: "queues:default"
      ‚îÇ     With retry count, timeout settings
      ‚ñº
Queue Stored


[Meanwhile, Queue Worker is running...]


Supervisor Process
      ‚îÇ
      ‚îÇ (3) Maintains queue worker processes
      ‚îÇ     Restarts if they crash
      ‚ñº
Laravel Queue Worker
      ‚îÇ
      ‚îÇ (4) Poll Redis queue for new jobs
      ‚îÇ     GET job from "queues:default"
      ‚ñº
Retrieve Job
      ‚îÇ
      ‚îÇ (5) Deserialize job payload
      ‚îÇ     Instantiate SendOrderConfirmationEmail
      ‚ñº
Execute Job Handle Method
      ‚îÇ
      ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ(6)‚îÄ‚ñ∫ Fetch Order Details
      ‚îÇ         ‚îÇ Query: SELECT * FROM orders WHERE id = 123
      ‚îÇ         ‚îÇ Include items, customer, vendor info
      ‚îÇ         ‚ñº
      ‚îÇ         Order Data
      ‚îÇ
      ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ(7)‚îÄ‚ñ∫ Render Email Template
      ‚îÇ         ‚îÇ Blade template: emails.order-confirmation
      ‚îÇ         ‚îÇ Pass order data to view
      ‚îÇ         ‚ñº
      ‚îÇ         HTML Email
      ‚îÇ
      ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ(8)‚îÄ‚ñ∫ Send via SendGrid API
      ‚îÇ         ‚îÇ POST to SendGrid
      ‚îÇ         ‚îÇ From: noreply@platform.com
      ‚îÇ         ‚îÇ To: customer@email.com
      ‚îÇ         ‚ñº
      ‚îÇ         Email Sent
      ‚îÇ
      ‚îÇ (9) Job completed successfully
      ‚îÇ
      ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ(10)‚îÄ‚ñ∫ Delete job from queue
                ‚îÇ Mark as processed
                ‚ñº
                Job Done


[If job fails...]


Job Failed
      ‚îÇ
      ‚îÇ (11) Increment retry count
      ‚îÇ (12) Delay with exponential backoff
      ‚îÇ      First retry: 10 seconds
      ‚îÇ      Second retry: 60 seconds
      ‚îÇ      Third retry: 600 seconds
      ‚ñº
Re-queue Job
      ‚îÇ
      ‚îÇ If max retries exceeded (3 attempts)
      ‚ñº
Failed Jobs Table
      ‚îÇ
      ‚îÇ (13) Store in failed_jobs for manual review
      ‚îÇ      { id, payload, exception, failed_at }
      ‚ñº
Administrator Review
1. Laravel application job dispatch ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡ßá (email ‡¶™‡¶æ‡¶†‡¶æ‡¶®‡ßã‡¶∞ ‡¶ú‡¶®‡ßç‡¶Ø)
2. Job Redis queue ‡¶§‡ßá store ‡¶π‡¶Ø‡¶º
3. Supervisor process worker alive ‡¶∞‡¶æ‡¶ñ‡ßá
4. Queue worker Redis ‡¶•‡ßá‡¶ï‡ßá jobs poll ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡ßá
5. Job payload deserialize ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡ßá
6. Order details database ‡¶•‡ßá‡¶ï‡ßá fetch ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡ßá
7. Email template render ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡ßá order data ‡¶¶‡¶ø‡¶Ø‡¶º‡ßá
8. SendGrid API use ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡ßá email send ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡ßá
9. Job successfully complete ‡¶π‡¶≤‡ßá queue ‡¶•‡ßá‡¶ï‡ßá delete ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡ßá 10-12. Job fail ‡¶π‡¶≤‡ßá retry logic ‡¶ö‡¶≤‡ßá (exponential backoff ‡¶∏‡¶π)
10. Max retries ‡¶è‡¶∞ ‡¶™‡¶∞‡¶ì fail ‡¶π‡¶≤‡ßá failed_jobs table ‡¶è store ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡ßá administrator review ‡¶è‡¶∞ ‡¶ú‡¶®‡ßç‡¶Ø
________________


3. APPLICATION ARCHITECTURE
3.1 Layered Architecture
The Laravel application follows a layered architecture separating concerns into distinct tiers with clear responsibilities and dependencies flowing downward.
Layer Structure
  

Presentation Layer Components
Controllers receive HTTP requests, delegate business logic to services, and return formatted responses. Controllers should be thin, containing minimal logic.
<?php
// app/Http/Controllers/API/V1/OrderController.php


namespace App\Http\Controllers\API\V1;


use App\Http\Controllers\Controller;
use App\Http\Requests\Order\CreateOrderRequest;
use App\Http\Resources\OrderResource;
use App\Services\Order\OrderService;
use App\Traits\ApiResponseTrait;


class OrderController extends Controller
{
    use ApiResponseTrait;
    
    private OrderService $orderService;
    
    public function __construct(OrderService $orderService)
    {
        $this->orderService = $orderService;
    }
    
    /**
     * Create a new order
     * 
     * ‡¶ï‡ßá‡¶®: Customer checkout complete ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡¶æ‡¶∞ ‡¶™‡¶∞ order create ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡¶æ
     * Flow: Request validation ‚Üí Service call ‚Üí Response formatting
     */
    public function store(CreateOrderRequest $request)
    {
        try {
            // Service layer ‡¶è business logic delegate ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡¶æ
            $order = $this->orderService->createOrder(
                customerId: auth()->id(),
                cartItems: $request->input('items'),
                shippingAddressId: $request->input('shipping_address_id'),
                paymentIntentId: $request->input('payment_intent_id'),
                couponCode: $request->input('coupon_code')
            );
            
            // Response resource ‡¶¶‡¶ø‡¶Ø‡¶º‡ßá format ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡¶æ
            return $this->successResponse(
                data: new OrderResource($order),
                message: 'Order placed successfully',
                code: 201
            );
            
        } catch (\Exception $e) {
            // Exception handling centralized
            return $this->errorResponse(
                message: 'Failed to create order: ' . $e->getMessage(),
                code: 500
            );
        }
    }
}
Requests validate incoming data before it reaches controllers using Laravel's form request validation
<?php
// app/Http/Requests/Order/CreateOrderRequest.php


namespace App\Http\Requests\Order;


use Illuminate\Foundation\Http\FormRequest;


class CreateOrderRequest extends FormRequest
{
    /**
     * Authorization check
     * ‡¶ï‡ßá‡¶®: ‡¶∂‡ßÅ‡¶ß‡ßÅ authenticated users order create ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡¶§‡ßá ‡¶™‡¶æ‡¶∞‡¶¨‡ßá
     */
    public function authorize(): bool
    {
        return auth()->check();
    }
    
    /**
     * Validation rules
     * ‡¶ï‡ßá‡¶®: Invalid data database ‡¶è ‡¶Ø‡¶æ‡¶ì‡¶Ø‡¶º‡¶æ‡¶∞ ‡¶Ü‡¶ó‡ßá‡¶á reject ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡¶æ
     */
    public function rules(): array
    {
        return [
            'items' => ['required', 'array', 'min:1'],
            'items.*.product_id' => ['required', 'exists:products,id'],
            'items.*.variant_id' => ['nullable', 'exists:product_variants,id'],
            'items.*.quantity' => ['required', 'integer', 'min:1', 'max:100'],
            
            'shipping_address_id' => ['required', 'exists:addresses,id'],
            'payment_intent_id' => ['required', 'string'],
            'coupon_code' => ['nullable', 'string', 'exists:coupons,code'],
        ];
    }
    
    /**
     * Custom error messages
     * ‡¶ï‡ßá‡¶®: User-friendly Bengali/English messages
     */
    public function messages(): array
    {
        return [
            'items.required' => 'Cart must contain at least one item',
            'items.*.product_id.exists' => 'Selected product does not exist',
            'items.*.quantity.min' => 'Quantity must be at least 1',
            'shipping_address_id.required' => 'Shipping address is required',
        ];
    }
}
Resources transform Eloquent models into API responses controlling what data is exposed and how it's formatted.


<?php
// app/Http/Resources/OrderResource.php


namespace App\Http\Resources;


use Illuminate\Http\Resources\Json\JsonResource;


class OrderResource extends JsonResource
{
    /**
     * Transform order model to array
     * ‡¶ï‡ßá‡¶®: Consistent API response format, sensitive data hiding
     */
    public function toArray($request): array
    {
        return [
            'id' => $this->id,
            'order_number' => $this->order_number,
            'status' => $this->order_status,
            'payment_status' => $this->payment_status,
            
            // Nested resources for related data
            'items' => OrderItemResource::collection($this->whenLoaded('items')),
            'customer' => new UserResource($this->whenLoaded('customer')),
            
            // Calculated fields
            'subtotal' => number_format($this->subtotal, 2),
            'tax' => number_format($this->tax, 2),
            'shipping' => number_format($this->shipping_charge, 2),
            'discount' => number_format($this->discount, 2),
            'total' => number_format($this->total, 2),
            
            // Shipping information
            'shipping_address' => new AddressResource(
                $this->whenLoaded('shippingAddress')
            ),
            'tracking_number' => $this->tracking_number,
            
            // Timestamps
            'created_at' => $this->created_at->toISOString(),
            'updated_at' => $this->updated_at->toISOString(),
            
            // Conditional fields (‡¶∂‡ßÅ‡¶ß‡ßÅ admin ‡¶¶‡ßá‡¶ñ‡¶¨‡ßá)
            'admin_notes' => $this->when(
                $request->user()?->isAdmin(),
                $this->admin_notes
            ),
        ];
    }
}
Service Layer Components
Service classes encapsulate business logic and complex workflows coordinating multiple repositories and models
<?php
// app/Services/Order/OrderService.php


namespace App\Services\Order;


use App\Models\Order;
use App\Models\OrderItem;
use App\Repositories\ProductRepository;
use App\Repositories\OrderRepository;
use App\Services\Payment\PaymentService;
use App\Services\Inventory\StockReservationService;
use App\Services\Commission\CommissionService;
use App\Jobs\SendOrderConfirmationEmail;
use App\Jobs\NotifyVendorsNewOrder;
use Illuminate\Support\Facades\DB;
use Illuminate\Support\Facades\Log;


class OrderService
{
    public function __construct(
        private ProductRepository $productRepo,
        private OrderRepository $orderRepo,
        private PaymentService $paymentService,
        private StockReservationService $stockService,
        private CommissionService $commissionService,
        private OrderCalculator $calculator
    ) {}
    
    /**
     * Create a new order
     * 
     * ‡¶ï‡ßá‡¶®: Order creation ‡¶è‡¶∞ complete workflow handle ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡¶æ
     * ‡¶®‡¶æ ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡¶≤‡ßá: Controller ‡¶è ‡¶Ö‡¶®‡ßá‡¶ï complex code ‡¶•‡¶æ‡¶ï‡¶§
     * ‡¶¨‡ßá‡¶®‡¶ø‡¶´‡¶ø‡¶ü: Reusable, testable, maintainable
     */
    public function createOrder(
        int $customerId,
        array $cartItems,
        int $shippingAddressId,
        string $paymentIntentId,
        ?string $couponCode = null
    ): Order {
        
        // Database transaction ‡¶∂‡ßÅ‡¶∞‡ßÅ ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡¶æ
        // ‡¶ï‡ßá‡¶®: ‡¶∏‡¶¨ operations atomically ‡¶π‡¶¨‡ßá - fail ‡¶π‡¶≤‡ßá rollback
        return DB::transaction(function () use (
            $customerId, $cartItems, $shippingAddressId, 
            $paymentIntentId, $couponCode
        ) {
            
            // Step 1: Validate stock availability
            // ‡¶ï‡ßá‡¶®: Order ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡¶æ‡¶∞ ‡¶Ü‡¶ó‡ßá stock check ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡¶æ must
            $this->validateStockAvailability($cartItems);
            
            // Step 2: Calculate order totals
            // ‡¶ï‡ßá‡¶®: Tax, shipping, discount calculate ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡¶æ
            $totals = $this->calculator->calculateOrderTotals(
                items: $cartItems,
                couponCode: $couponCode,
                shippingAddressId: $shippingAddressId
            );
            
            // Step 3: Verify payment
            // ‡¶ï‡ßá‡¶®: Payment successful ‡¶π‡¶Ø‡¶º‡ßá‡¶õ‡ßá ‡¶ï‡¶ø‡¶®‡¶æ confirm ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡¶æ
            $payment = $this->paymentService->verifyPaymentIntent(
                $paymentIntentId
            );
            
            if ($payment['status'] !== 'succeeded') {
                throw new \Exception('Payment verification failed');
            }
            
            // Step 4: Create order record
            $order = $this->orderRepo->create([
                'customer_id' => $customerId,
                'order_number' => $this->generateOrderNumber(),
                'shipping_address_id' => $shippingAddressId,
                'order_status' => 'pending',
                'payment_status' => 'paid',
                'payment_method' => 'stripe_card',
                'transaction_id' => $payment['transaction_id'],
                'subtotal' => $totals['subtotal'],
                'tax' => $totals['tax'],
                'shipping_charge' => $totals['shipping'],
                'discount' => $totals['discount'],
                'total' => $totals['total'],
                'coupon_code' => $couponCode,
            ]);
            
            // Step 5: Create order items
            // ‡¶ï‡ßá‡¶®: ‡¶™‡ßç‡¶∞‡¶§‡¶ø‡¶ü‡¶æ product ‡¶è‡¶∞ details save ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡¶æ
            foreach ($cartItems as $item) {
                $product = $this->productRepo->findById($item['product_id']);
                
                $orderItem = OrderItem::create([
                    'order_id' => $order->id,
                    'product_id' => $product->id,
                    'variant_id' => $item['variant_id'] ?? null,
                    'vendor_id' => $product->vendor_id,
                    'product_name' => $product->name,
                    'product_sku' => $product->sku,
                    'quantity' => $item['quantity'],
                    'unit_price' => $product->current_price,
                    'total_price' => $product->current_price * $item['quantity'],
                    'status' => 'pending',
                ]);
                
                // Step 6: Convert stock reservations to committed
                $this->stockService->commitReservation(
                    productId: $product->id,
                    variantId: $item['variant_id'] ?? null,
                    quantity: $item['quantity'],
                    orderId: $order->id
                );
                
                // Step 7: Create commission record
                $this->commissionService->createCommission(
                    orderItem: $orderItem,
                    vendor: $product->vendor
                );
            }
            
            // Step 8: Create payment record
            $this->paymentService->recordPayment(
                order: $order,
                transactionId: $payment['transaction_id'],
                amount: $totals['total']
            );
            
            // Step 9: Dispatch background jobs
            // ‡¶ï‡ßá‡¶®: Email sending asynchronous ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡¶æ - response fast ‡¶∞‡¶æ‡¶ñ‡¶æ
            SendOrderConfirmationEmail::dispatch($order);
            NotifyVendorsNewOrder::dispatch($order);
            
            // Step 10: Clear customer cart
            $this->clearCustomerCart($customerId);
            
            // Step 11: Log order creation
            Log::info('Order created successfully', [
                'order_id' => $order->id,
                'order_number' => $order->order_number,
                'customer_id' => $customerId,
                'total' => $totals['total'],
            ]);
            
            return $order->load(['items', 'customer', 'shippingAddress']);
        });
    }
    
    /**
     * Validate stock availability
     * ‡¶ï‡ßá‡¶®: Overselling prevent ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡¶æ
     */
    private function validateStockAvailability(array $cartItems): void
    {
        foreach ($cartItems as $item) {
            $available = $this->stockService->getAvailableStock(
                productId: $item['product_id'],
                variantId: $item['variant_id'] ?? null
            );
            
            if ($available < $item['quantity']) {
                throw new \Exception(
                    "Insufficient stock for product ID {$item['product_id']}"
                );
            }
        }
    }
    
    /**
     * Generate unique order number
     * ‡¶ï‡ßá‡¶®: Human-readable unique identifier
     */
    private function generateOrderNumber(): string
    {
        return 'ORD-' . date('Ymd') . '-' . str_pad(
            Order::whereDate('created_at', today())->count() + 1,
            4,
            '0',
            STR_PAD_LEFT
        );
    }
}
Repository Layer Components
Repositories abstract data access providing a consistent interface for querying and persisting domain models
<?php
// app/Repositories/ProductRepository.php


namespace App\Repositories;


use App\Models\Product;
use Illuminate\Support\Facades\Cache;
use Illuminate\Database\Eloquent\Collection;


class ProductRepository extends BaseRepository
{
    public function __construct(Product $model)
    {
        parent::__construct($model);
    }
    
    /**
     * Find product by ID with caching
     * 
     * ‡¶ï‡ßá‡¶®: Frequently accessed products cache ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡¶æ
     * ‡¶¨‡ßá‡¶®‡¶ø‡¶´‡¶ø‡¶ü: Database queries ‡¶ï‡¶Æ, faster response
     */
    public function findById(int $id, array $relations = []): ?Product
    {
        $cacheKey = "products:{$id}:" . implode(',', $relations);
        
        return Cache::remember($cacheKey, 3600, function () use ($id, $relations) {
            return $this->model
                ->with($relations)
                ->find($id);
        });
    }
    
    /**
     * Find active products by vendor
     * ‡¶ï‡ßá‡¶®: Vendor ‡¶è‡¶∞ active products list ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡¶æ
     */
    public function findByVendor(
        int $vendorId,
        array $filters = [],
        int $perPage = 15
    ) {
        $query = $this->model
            ->where('vendor_id', $vendorId)
            ->where('status', 'active');
        
        // Apply filters
        if (isset($filters['category_id'])) {
            $query->where('category_id', $filters['category_id']);
        }
        
        if (isset($filters['stock_status'])) {
            $query->where('stock_status', $filters['stock_status']);
        }
        
        if (isset($filters['search'])) {
            $query->where(function ($q) use ($filters) {
                $q->where('name', 'LIKE', "%{$filters['search']}%")
                  ->orWhere('sku', 'LIKE', "%{$filters['search']}%");
            });
        }
        
        return $query->paginate($perPage);
    }
    
    /**
     * Update product and invalidate cache
     * ‡¶ï‡ßá‡¶®: Update ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡¶æ‡¶∞ ‡¶™‡¶∞ cache clear ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡¶æ must
     */
    public function update(int $id, array $data): Product
    {
        $product = $this->model->findOrFail($id);
        $product->update($data);
        
        // Cache invalidation
        $this->clearProductCache($id);
        
        return $product->fresh();
    }
    
    /**
     * Clear product cache
     * ‡¶ï‡ßá‡¶®: Stale data serve ‡¶®‡¶æ ‡¶π‡¶ì‡¶Ø‡¶º‡¶æ‡¶∞ ‡¶ú‡¶®‡ßç‡¶Ø
     */
    private function clearProductCache(int $productId): void
    {
        $patterns = [
            "products:{$productId}*",
            "product_details_with_stock:{$productId}",
        ];
        
        foreach ($patterns as $pattern) {
            Cache::forget($pattern);
        }
    }
}

## 3.2 Domain-Driven Design Concepts

The application incorporates Domain-Driven Design principles organizing code around business domains.

### Bounded Contexts

E-commerce Platform
    ‚îÇ
    ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ Product Catalog Context
    ‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ Entities: Product, Category, Attribute
    ‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ Value Objects: Price, SKU, Stock
    ‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ Services: ProductService, CategoryService
    ‚îÇ
    ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ Order Management Context
    ‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ Entities: Order, OrderItem, Payment
    ‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ Value Objects: OrderNumber, OrderStatus
    ‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ Services: OrderService, OrderCalculator
    ‚îÇ
    ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ Inventory Context
    ‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ Entities: StockReservation, InventoryMovement
    ‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ Value Objects: Quantity, ReservationStatus
    ‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ Services: StockReservationService, InventoryService
    ‚îÇ
    ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ Vendor Management Context
    ‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ Entities: Vendor, VendorBankDetails
    ‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ Value Objects: CommissionRate, PayoutStatus
    ‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ Services: VendorService, PayoutService
    ‚îÇ
    ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ Customer Context
        ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ Entities: Customer, Address, Wishlist
        ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ Value Objects: Email, PhoneNumber
        ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ Services: CustomerService, WishlistService
Entities and Value Objects
Entities have identity and lifecycle, tracked through database IDs.
<?php
// app/Models/Order.php - Entity


namespace App\Models;


use Illuminate\Database\Eloquent\Model;


class Order extends Model
{
    // Entity identity
    protected $primaryKey = 'id';
    
    // Entity behavior methods
    public function markAsProcessing(): void
    {
        $this->update(['order_status' => 'processing']);
        event(new OrderStatusChanged($this, 'processing'));
    }
    
    public function canBeCancelled(): bool
    {
        return in_array($this->order_status, ['pending', 'processing']);
    }
    
    // Entity relationships
    public function items()
    {
        return $this->hasMany(OrderItem::class);
    }
}
Value Objects have no identity, defined by their attributes
<?php
// app/ValueObjects/Money.php - Value Object


namespace App\ValueObjects;


class Money
{
    public function __construct(
        private float $amount,
        private string $currency = 'USD'
    ) {
        if ($amount < 0) {
            throw new \InvalidArgumentException('Amount cannot be negative');
        }
    }
    
    public function add(Money $other): Money
    {
        $this->ensureSameCurrency($other);
        return new Money($this->amount + $other->amount, $this->currency);
    }
    
    public function subtract(Money $other): Money
    {
        $this->ensureSameCurrency($other);
        return new Money($this->amount - $other->amount, $this->currency);
    }
    
    public function multiply(float $multiplier): Money
    {
        return new Money($this->amount * $multiplier, $this->currency);
    }
    
    public function format(): string
    {
        return '$' . number_format($this->amount, 2);
    }
    
    private function ensureSameCurrency(Money $other): void
    {
        if ($this->currency !== $other->currency) {
            throw new \InvalidArgumentException('Currency mismatch');
        }
    }
}
Domain Events
Events represent something significant that happened in the domain.
<?php
// app/Events/OrderPlaced.php


namespace App\Events;


use App\Models\Order;
use Illuminate\Foundation\Events\Dispatchable;
use Illuminate\Queue\SerializesModels;


class OrderPlaced
{
    use Dispatchable, SerializesModels;
    
    public function __construct(
        public Order $order
    ) {}
}


// app/Listeners/SendOrderConfirmation.php


namespace App\Listeners;


use App\Events\OrderPlaced;
use App\Mail\OrderConfirmationMail;
use Illuminate\Support\Facades\Mail;


class SendOrderConfirmation
{
    public function handle(OrderPlaced $event): void
    {
        Mail::to($event->order->customer->email)
            ->send(new OrderConfirmationMail($event->order));
    }
}
4. DATABASE ARCHITECTURE
4.1 Database Design Philosophy
The database architecture follows relational database best practices emphasizing data integrity, normalization, and query performance.
Design Principles
Normalization - The schema is normalized to Third Normal Form (3NF) eliminating redundancy and update anomalies. Each table represents a single entity type with atomic attributes. Relationships are expressed through foreign keys maintaining referential integrity.
Denormalization for Performance - Strategic denormalization is applied where read performance is critical. Examples include storing calculated product ratings directly in the products table rather than computing on every query, caching vendor product counts in the vendors table for dashboard displays, and duplicating product names and SKUs in order_items for historical record keeping even if products are later deleted or renamed.
Soft Deletes - Critical tables use soft deletion preserving data for audit trails and historical reporting. Soft-deleted records have a deleted_at timestamp set rather than being physically removed. Queries automatically exclude soft-deleted records unless explicitly included.
Audit Trailing - All tables include created_at and updated_at timestamps automatically managed by the ORM. Critical operations are additionally logged in the activity_logs table with complete context including actor identity, affected resources, and changes made.
4.2 Schema Diagrams
Core Entities ERD
  

ERD diagram ‡¶ü‡¶æ ‡¶™‡ßÅ‡¶∞‡ßã database structure visualize ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡ßá‡•§ ‡¶™‡ßç‡¶∞‡¶§‡¶ø‡¶ü‡¶æ box ‡¶è‡¶ï‡¶ü‡¶æ table represent ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡ßá‡•§ Lines/arrows relationship ‡¶¶‡ßá‡¶ñ‡¶æ‡¶Ø‡¶º:
* PK = Primary Key (unique identifier)
* FK = Foreign Key (‡¶Ö‡¶®‡ßç‡¶Ø table ‡¶è‡¶∞ reference)
* UK = Unique Key (duplicate ‡¶π‡¶§‡ßá ‡¶™‡¶æ‡¶∞‡¶¨‡ßá ‡¶®‡¶æ)
* (Enc) = Encrypted field (security ‡¶ú‡¶®‡ßç‡¶Ø)
* ‚óÑ‚îÄ = Relationship arrow (one-to-many)
Main relationships:
* Users ‚Üí Vendors (one user can be one vendor)
* Vendors ‚Üí Products (one vendor can have many products)
* Products ‚Üí Variants/Images (one product can have many variants/images)
* Users ‚Üí Orders (one customer can place many orders)
* Orders ‚Üí OrderItems (one order can have many items)
* Orders ‚Üí Payments (one order has one payment)
4.3 Indexing Strategy
Indexes dramatically improve query performance but add overhead to write operations. Our indexing strategy balances read and write performance.
Primary Indexes
Every table has a primary key index on the id column. Primary keys use BIGINT auto-increment providing 9.2 quintillion possible IDs ensuring we never run out.
-- Primary key automatically creates clustered index
CREATE TABLE products (
    id BIGSERIAL PRIMARY KEY,
    -- ... other columns
);


-- Bangla: BIGSERIAL ‡¶Æ‡¶æ‡¶®‡ßá auto-increment big integer
-- Primary key automatically index create ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡ßá
Foreign Key Indexes
All foreign key columns have indexes enabling fast joins and relationship queries.
-- Foreign key indexes for products table
CREATE INDEX idx_products_vendor_id ON products(vendor_id);
CREATE INDEX idx_products_category_id ON products(category_id);


-- Bangla: Foreign key ‡¶§‡ßá index ‡¶®‡¶æ ‡¶•‡¶æ‡¶ï‡¶≤‡ßá join queries ‡¶ñ‡ßÅ‡¶¨ slow ‡¶π‡¶Ø‡¶º
-- Example query: SELECT * FROM products WHERE vendor_id = 123
-- Index ‡¶¶‡¶ø‡¶Ø‡¶º‡ßá milliseconds ‡¶è result ‡¶™‡¶æ‡¶Ø‡¶º, without index seconds ‡¶≤‡¶æ‡¶ó‡¶§‡ßá ‡¶™‡¶æ‡¶∞‡ßá
Unique Indexes
Unique constraints automatically create indexes while enforcing uniqueness.
-- Unique indexes
CREATE UNIQUE INDEX idx_users_email ON users(email);
CREATE UNIQUE INDEX idx_products_slug ON products(slug);
CREATE UNIQUE INDEX idx_product_variants_sku ON product_variants(sku);


-- Bangla: Unique index ‡¶¶‡ßÅ‡¶ü‡ßã ‡¶ï‡¶æ‡¶ú ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡ßá:
-- 1. Duplicate entry prevent ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡ßá
-- 2. Fast lookup provide ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡ßá
Composite Indexes
Multi-column indexes optimize queries filtering or sorting by multiple columns.


-- Composite index for order queries
CREATE INDEX idx_orders_customer_status 
ON orders(customer_id, order_status);


-- Bangla: ‡¶è‡¶á index optimize ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡¶¨‡ßá queries like:
-- SELECT * FROM orders WHERE customer_id = 10 AND order_status = 'pending'
-- Column order important: most selective column first


-- Composite index for commission queries
CREATE INDEX idx_commissions_vendor_status 
ON commissions(vendor_id, status);


-- Useful for: SELECT * FROM commissions 
-- WHERE vendor_id = 5 AND status = 'released'
Partial Indexes
Partial indexes include only rows matching a condition, reducing index size and improving performance.
-- Partial index for pending orders only
CREATE INDEX idx_orders_pending 
ON orders(created_at) 
WHERE order_status = 'pending';


-- Bangla: ‡¶∂‡ßÅ‡¶ß‡ßÅ pending orders ‡¶è‡¶∞ ‡¶â‡¶™‡¶∞ index
-- ‡¶ï‡ßá‡¶®: Pending orders frequently query ‡¶π‡¶Ø‡¶º
-- ‡¶¨‡ßá‡¶®‡¶ø‡¶´‡¶ø‡¶ü: Smaller index, faster queries


-- Partial index for active products
CREATE INDEX idx_products_active 
ON products(category_id, created_at) 
WHERE status = 'active' AND deleted_at IS NULL;


-- ‡¶ï‡ßá‡¶®: Customer facing queries ‡¶∂‡ßÅ‡¶ß‡ßÅ active products ‡¶¶‡ßá‡¶ñ‡ßá
Full-Text Search Indexes
PostgreSQL's GIN indexes support full-text search on text columns.
-- Full-text search index on products
CREATE INDEX idx_products_fulltext 
ON products USING gin(
    to_tsvector('english', 
        name || ' ' || COALESCE(description, '')
    )
);


-- Bangla: Product search optimize ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡¶æ‡¶∞ ‡¶ú‡¶®‡ßç‡¶Ø
-- GIN = Generalized Inverted Index (full-text search ‡¶è‡¶∞ ‡¶ú‡¶®‡ßç‡¶Ø special)
-- Usage: SELECT * FROM products 
-- WHERE to_tsvector('english', name || ' ' || description) 
-- @@ to_tsquery('english', 'laptop');
JSON Indexes
GIN inde-- Index on JSON attributes
CREATE INDEX idx_product_variants_attributes 
ON product_variants USING gin(variant_attributes);


-- Bangla: JSON field ‡¶è search ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡¶æ‡¶∞ ‡¶ú‡¶®‡ßç‡¶Ø
-- Usage: SELECT * FROM product_variants 
-- WHERE variant_attributes @> '{"color": "red"}';
-- @> operator means "contains"


Expression Indexes
Indexes on computed expressions optimize queries using those expressions.
-- Index on lowercase email for case-insensitive search
CREATE INDEX idx_users_email_lower 
ON users(LOWER(email));


-- Bangla: Case-insensitive email search optimize ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡¶æ
-- Usage: SELECT * FROM users WHERE LOWER(email) = LOWER('User@Example.COM')


-- Index on date part of created_at
CREATE INDEX idx_orders_created_date 
ON orders(DATE(created_at));


-- ‡¶ï‡ßá‡¶®: Daily order reports fast ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡¶æ‡¶∞ ‡¶ú‡¶®‡ßç‡¶Ø
-- Usage: SELECT * FROM orders WHERE DATE(created_at) = '2026-02-06'
Index Maintenance


-- Analyze tables to update statistics (PostgreSQL optimizer ‡¶è‡¶∞ ‡¶ú‡¶®‡ßç‡¶Ø)
-- ‡¶ï‡ßá‡¶®: Query planner accurate decisions ‡¶®‡¶ø‡¶§‡ßá ‡¶™‡¶æ‡¶∞‡ßá
ANALYZE products;
ANALYZE orders;


-- Reindex to rebuild indexes (fragmentation reduce ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡¶æ)
-- ‡¶ï‡ßá‡¶®: Long running database ‡¶è index fragmented ‡¶π‡¶Ø‡¶º
REINDEX TABLE products;


-- Vacuum to reclaim storage and update statistics
-- ‡¶ï‡ßá‡¶®: Deleted rows ‡¶è‡¶∞ space reclaim ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡¶æ
VACUUM ANALYZE products;
4.4 Database Functions and Stored Procedures
Complex calculations and reusable logic are encapsulated in database functions.
get_available_stock Function
-- Function: Calculate real-time available stock
-- ‡¶ï‡ßá‡¶®: Stock calculation ‡¶¨‡¶æ‡¶∞ ‡¶¨‡¶æ‡¶∞ ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡¶æ ‡¶≤‡¶æ‡¶ó‡ßá, function reusable ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡ßá


CREATE OR REPLACE FUNCTION get_available_stock(
    product_id_param BIGINT,
    variant_id_param BIGINT DEFAULT NULL
)
RETURNS INTEGER AS $$
DECLARE
    total_stock INTEGER;
    reserved INTEGER;
    pending INTEGER;
BEGIN
    -- Step 1: Get total stock from product or variant
    -- ‡¶ï‡ßá‡¶®: Simple vs Variable product ‡¶è‡¶∞ ‡¶ú‡¶®‡ßç‡¶Ø ‡¶Ü‡¶≤‡¶æ‡¶¶‡¶æ logic
    IF variant_id_param IS NULL THEN
        -- Simple product: stock products table ‡¶è
        SELECT stock_quantity INTO total_stock
        FROM products
        WHERE id = product_id_param;
    ELSE
        -- Variable product: stock variant table ‡¶è
        SELECT stock_quantity INTO total_stock
        FROM product_variants
        WHERE id = variant_id_param;
    END IF;
    
    -- Step 2: Get reserved stock from active cart reservations
    -- ‡¶ï‡ßá‡¶®: Cart ‡¶è ‡¶Ø‡¶æ ‡¶Ü‡¶õ‡ßá ‡¶∏‡ßá‡¶ü‡¶æ available stock ‡¶•‡ßá‡¶ï‡ßá deduct ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡¶æ
    SELECT COALESCE(SUM(quantity), 0) INTO reserved
    FROM stock_reservations
    WHERE product_id = product_id_param
      AND (variant_id_param IS NULL OR variant_id = variant_id_param)
      AND expires_at > NOW()  -- ‡¶∂‡ßÅ‡¶ß‡ßÅ active reservations
      AND status = 'active';
    
    -- Step 3: Get pending order stock
    -- ‡¶ï‡ßá‡¶®: Paid orders ‡¶Ø‡¶æ ‡¶è‡¶ñ‡¶®‡ßã fulfill ‡¶π‡¶Ø‡¶º‡¶®‡¶ø
    SELECT COALESCE(SUM(oi.quantity), 0) INTO pending
    FROM order_items oi
    INNER JOIN orders o ON oi.order_id = o.id
    WHERE oi.product_id = product_id_param
      AND (variant_id_param IS NULL OR oi.variant_id = variant_id_param)
      AND o.order_status IN ('pending', 'processing')
      AND o.payment_status = 'paid';
    
    -- Step 4: Calculate available stock
    -- Formula: Total - Reserved - Pending, minimum 0
    RETURN GREATEST(total_stock - reserved - pending, 0);
END;
$$ LANGUAGE plpgsql;


-- Usage example:
-- SELECT get_available_stock(1);        -- Simple product ID 1
-- SELECT get_available_stock(1, 5);     -- Product 1, Variant 5


-- Bangla explanation:
-- ‡¶è‡¶á function three types of stock consider ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡ßá:
-- 1. Total stock (vendor ‡¶Ø‡¶æ add ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡ßá‡¶õ‡ßá)
-- 2. Reserved stock (customer carts ‡¶è ‡¶Ø‡¶æ ‡¶Ü‡¶õ‡ßá)
-- 3. Pending stock (orders ‡¶Ø‡¶æ paid ‡¶ï‡¶ø‡¶®‡ßç‡¶§‡ßÅ shipped ‡¶®‡¶æ)
-- Final available = Total - Reserved - Pending
generate_order_number Function
-- Function: Generate unique sequential order numbers
-- Format: ORD-YYYYMMDD-####


CREATE OR REPLACE FUNCTION generate_order_number()
RETURNS TEXT AS $$
DECLARE
    date_part TEXT;
    sequence_part INTEGER;
    order_number TEXT;
BEGIN
    -- Get today's date in YYYYMMDD format
    -- ‡¶ï‡ßá‡¶®: Date ‡¶¶‡¶ø‡¶Ø‡¶º‡ßá order group ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡¶æ easy
    date_part := TO_CHAR(NOW(), 'YYYYMMDD');
    
    -- Count today's orders and add 1 for next sequence
    -- ‡¶ï‡ßá‡¶®: Today ‡¶è‡¶∞ orders count ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡ßá next number ‡¶™‡¶æ‡¶ì‡¶Ø‡¶º‡¶æ
    SELECT COUNT(*) + 1 INTO sequence_part
    FROM orders
    WHERE DATE(created_at) = CURRENT_DATE;
    
    -- Format: ORD-20260206-0001
    -- LPAD = Left pad with zeros (0001, 0002, etc.)
    order_number := 'ORD-' || date_part || '-' || 
                    LPAD(sequence_part::TEXT, 4, '0');
    
    RETURN order_number;
END;
$$ LANGUAGE plpgsql;


-- Usage:
-- SELECT generate_order_number();
-- Output: ORD-20260206-0001


-- Bangla: Automatic unique order number generate ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡ßá
-- Format: ORD-[Date]-[Sequence]
-- Same date ‡¶è 0001, 0002, 0003... increment ‡¶π‡¶Ø‡¶º


calculate_commission Function
-- Function: Calculate platform commission for an order
-- ‡¶ï‡ßá‡¶®: Commission calculation centralized ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡¶æ


CREATE OR REPLACE FUNCTION calculate_commission(
    vendor_id_param BIGINT,
    order_total DECIMAL(10,2)
)
RETURNS DECIMAL(10,2) AS $$
DECLARE
    commission_rate DECIMAL(5,2);
    commission_amount DECIMAL(10,2);
    default_rate DECIMAL(5,2);
BEGIN
    -- Step 1: Get vendor's custom commission rate
    -- ‡¶ï‡ßá‡¶®: ‡¶™‡ßç‡¶∞‡¶§‡¶ø vendor ‡¶Ü‡¶≤‡¶æ‡¶¶‡¶æ rate ‡¶•‡¶æ‡¶ï‡¶§‡ßá ‡¶™‡¶æ‡¶∞‡ßá
    SELECT v.commission_rate INTO commission_rate
    FROM vendors v
    WHERE v.id = vendor_id_param;
    
    -- Step 2: If no custom rate, use platform default
    -- ‡¶ï‡ßá‡¶®: New vendors default rate ‡¶™‡¶æ‡¶Ø‡¶º
    IF commission_rate IS NULL THEN
        SELECT value::DECIMAL INTO default_rate
        FROM platform_settings
        WHERE key = 'default_commission_rate';
        
        commission_rate := COALESCE(default_rate, 10.00);
    END IF;
    
    -- Step 3: Calculate commission
    -- Formula: order_total √ó (rate / 100)
    commission_amount := order_total * (commission_rate / 100);
    
    -- Round to 2 decimal places
    RETURN ROUND(commission_amount, 2);
END;
$$ LANGUAGE plpgsql;


-- Usage:
-- SELECT calculate_commission(1, 1000.00);
-- If vendor 1 has 15% rate: Returns 150.00
-- If no rate set and default is 10%: Returns 100.00


-- Bangla: Vendor ‡¶è‡¶∞ commission automatically calculate ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡ßá
-- Custom rate ‡¶•‡¶æ‡¶ï‡¶≤‡ßá ‡¶∏‡ßá‡¶ü‡¶æ use ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡ßá, ‡¶®‡¶æ ‡¶π‡¶≤‡ßá default rate use ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡ßá
update_product_rating Function
-- Function: Update product average rating
-- Called by trigger when reviews change


CREATE OR REPLACE FUNCTION update_product_rating()
RETURNS TRIGGER AS $$
DECLARE
    product_id_var BIGINT;
    avg_rating DECIMAL(3,2);
    review_count INTEGER;
BEGIN
    -- Determine product_id from trigger context
    -- ‡¶ï‡ßá‡¶®: INSERT/UPDATE/DELETE ‡¶§‡¶ø‡¶®‡¶ü‡¶æ case handle ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡¶æ
    IF TG_OP = 'DELETE' THEN
        product_id_var := OLD.product_id;
    ELSE
        product_id_var := NEW.product_id;
    END IF;
    
    -- Calculate new average rating from approved reviews
    -- ‡¶ï‡ßá‡¶®: ‡¶∂‡ßÅ‡¶ß‡ßÅ approved reviews count ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡¶æ
    SELECT 
        COALESCE(AVG(rating), 0),
        COUNT(*)
    INTO avg_rating, review_count
    FROM reviews
    WHERE product_id = product_id_var
      AND status = 'approved';
    
    -- Update product table
    -- ‡¶ï‡ßá‡¶®: Denormalized data fast queries ‡¶è‡¶∞ ‡¶ú‡¶®‡ßç‡¶Ø
    UPDATE products
    SET 
        average_rating = avg_rating,
        total_reviews = review_count,
        updated_at = NOW()
    WHERE id = product_id_var;
    
    RETURN NULL;  -- Trigger doesn't need return value
END;
$$ LANGUAGE plpgsql;


-- Bangla: Product ‡¶è‡¶∞ rating automatically update ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡ßá
-- Review add/update/delete ‡¶π‡¶≤‡ßá ‡¶è‡¶á function call ‡¶π‡¶Ø‡¶º
-- Approved reviews ‡¶•‡ßá‡¶ï‡ßá average calculate ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡ßá products table ‡¶è store ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡ßá
4.5 Database Triggers
Triggers automatically execute functions in response to data changes maintaining derived data and enforcing complex constraints.
Auto-Generate Order Number Trigger
-- Trigger: Automatically generate order_number before insert
-- ‡¶ï‡ßá‡¶®: Manual order number generation error-prone


CREATE OR REPLACE FUNCTION trigger_generate_order_number()
RETURNS TRIGGER AS $$
BEGIN
    -- Check if order_number is not already set
    -- ‡¶ï‡ßá‡¶®: Manual override allow ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡¶æ (rare cases ‡¶è‡¶∞ ‡¶ú‡¶®‡ßç‡¶Ø)
    IF NEW.order_number IS NULL OR NEW.order_number = '' THEN
        NEW.order_number := generate_order_number();
    END IF;
    
    RETURN NEW;
END;
$$ LANGUAGE plpgsql;


CREATE TRIGGER before_insert_order_number
BEFORE INSERT ON orders
FOR EACH ROW
EXECUTE FUNCTION trigger_generate_order_number();


-- Bangla: Order insert ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡¶æ‡¶∞ ‡¶∏‡¶Æ‡¶Ø‡¶º automatic order_number assign ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡ßá
-- Developer ‡¶ï‡ßá manually generate ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡¶§‡ßá ‡¶π‡¶Ø‡¶º ‡¶®‡¶æ
-- Example: INSERT INTO orders (customer_id, total) VALUES (1, 100);
-- Result: order_number automatically "ORD-20260206-0001" ‡¶π‡¶¨‡ßá
Update Product Rating Trigger
-- Trigger: Update product rating when reviews change


CREATE TRIGGER after_review_change
AFTER INSERT OR UPDATE OR DELETE ON reviews
FOR EACH ROW
EXECUTE FUNCTION update_product_rating();


-- Bangla: Review add/edit/delete ‡¶π‡¶≤‡ßá automatic product rating update ‡¶π‡¶Ø‡¶º
-- Example:
-- INSERT INTO reviews (product_id, rating, ...) VALUES (1, 5, ...);
-- Automatically products.average_rating recalculate ‡¶π‡¶¨‡ßá


Update Category Product Count Trigger


-- Trigger: Maintain category product counts


CREATE OR REPLACE FUNCTION trigger_update_category_count()
RETURNS TRIGGER AS $$
DECLARE
    old_category_id BIGINT;
    new_category_id BIGINT;
BEGIN
    -- Handle different trigger operations
    IF TG_OP = 'DELETE' THEN
        old_category_id := OLD.category_id;
    ELSIF TG_OP = 'INSERT' THEN
        new_category_id := NEW.category_id;
    ELSIF TG_OP = 'UPDATE' THEN
        old_category_id := OLD.category_id;
        new_category_id := NEW.category_id;
    END IF;
    
    -- Decrease old category count
    -- ‡¶ï‡ßá‡¶®: Product remove ‡¶π‡¶≤‡ßá ‡¶¨‡¶æ category change ‡¶π‡¶≤‡ßá old category count ‡¶ï‡¶Æ‡¶æ‡¶®‡ßã
    IF old_category_id IS NOT NULL THEN
        UPDATE categories
        SET product_count = product_count - 1
        WHERE id = old_category_id;
    END IF;
    
    -- Increase new category count
    -- ‡¶ï‡ßá‡¶®: New product add ‡¶π‡¶≤‡ßá ‡¶¨‡¶æ category change ‡¶π‡¶≤‡ßá new category count ‡¶¨‡¶æ‡¶°‡¶º‡¶æ‡¶®‡ßã
    IF new_category_id IS NOT NULL THEN
        UPDATE categories
        SET product_count = product_count + 1
        WHERE id = new_category_id;
    END IF;
    
    RETURN NULL;
END;
$$ LANGUAGE plpgsql;


CREATE TRIGGER after_product_category_change
AFTER INSERT OR UPDATE OR DELETE ON products
FOR EACH ROW
EXECUTE FUNCTION trigger_update_category_count();


-- Bangla: Category ‡¶è‡¶∞ product count automatic maintain ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡ßá
-- Product add/remove/category change - ‡¶∏‡¶¨ case handle ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡ßá
-- Manual count ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡¶æ‡¶∞ ‡¶¶‡¶∞‡¶ï‡¶æ‡¶∞ ‡¶®‡ßá‡¶á, always accurate ‡¶•‡¶æ‡¶ï‡ßá


Stock Movement Logging Trigger


-- Trigger: Log all inventory changes automatically


CREATE OR REPLACE FUNCTION trigger_log_stock_movement()
RETURNS TRIGGER AS $$
BEGIN
    -- Only log when stock quantity changes
    IF TG_OP = 'UPDATE' AND OLD.stock_quantity != NEW.stock_quantity THEN
        INSERT INTO inventory_movements (
            product_id,
            variant_id,
            movement_type,
            quantity_change,
            previous_quantity,
            new_quantity,
            reason,
            performed_by,
            created_at
        ) VALUES (
            NEW.id,
            NULL,  -- This trigger is for products, not variants
            CASE 
                WHEN NEW.stock_quantity > OLD.stock_quantity THEN 'addition'
                ELSE 'subtraction'
            END,
            ABS(NEW.stock_quantity - OLD.stock_quantity),
            OLD.stock_quantity,
            NEW.stock_quantity,
            'automatic_log',  -- Reason code
            NULL,  -- System generated, no user
            NOW()
        );
    END IF;
    
    RETURN NEW;
END;
$$ LANGUAGE plpgsql;


CREATE TRIGGER after_product_stock_change
AFTER UPDATE ON products
FOR EACH ROW
EXECUTE FUNCTION trigger_log_stock_movement();


-- Similar trigger for product_variants table
-- CREATE TRIGGER after_variant_stock_change...


-- Bangla: Stock quantity change ‡¶π‡¶≤‡ßá automatic inventory_movements table ‡¶è log ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡ßá
-- Audit trail ‡¶§‡ßà‡¶∞‡ßÄ ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡ßá - ‡¶ï‡¶ñ‡¶®, ‡¶ï‡ßÄ ‡¶™‡¶∞‡¶ø‡¶Æ‡¶æ‡¶£ change ‡¶π‡¶Ø‡¶º‡ßá‡¶õ‡ßá
-- Later analysis ‡¶è‡¶∞ ‡¶ú‡¶®‡ßç‡¶Ø helpful (stock discrepancy investigate ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡¶æ)


4.6 Database Views
Views provide convenient access to complex queries encapsulating joins and calculations.
product_details_with_stock View
-- View: Product details with calculated available stock
-- ‡¶ï‡ßá‡¶®: Frontend frequently ‡¶è‡¶á data need ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡ßá, complex join avoid ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡¶æ


CREATE OR REPLACE VIEW product_details_with_stock AS
SELECT 
    p.id,
    p.vendor_id,
    p.category_id,
    p.name,
    p.slug,
    p.sku,
    p.type,
    p.status,
    p.regular_price,
    p.sale_price,
    
    -- Stock information
    p.stock_quantity AS total_stock,
    get_available_stock(p.id) AS available_stock,
    
    -- Stock status calculation
    CASE 
        WHEN get_available_stock(p.id) = 0 THEN 'out_of_stock'
        WHEN get_available_stock(p.id) < p.low_stock_threshold THEN 'low_stock'
        ELSE 'in_stock'
    END AS stock_status,
    
    -- Category information
    c.name AS category_name,
    c.slug AS category_slug,
    
    -- Vendor information
    v.business_name AS vendor_name,
    v.average_rating AS vendor_rating,
    
    -- Primary product image
    (
        SELECT pi.medium_url 
        FROM product_images pi 
        WHERE pi.product_id = p.id 
        ORDER BY pi.sort_order 
        LIMIT 1
    ) AS primary_image,
    
    -- Rating information
    p.average_rating,
    p.total_reviews,
    
    -- Timestamps
    p.created_at,
    p.updated_at
    
FROM products p
LEFT JOIN categories c ON p.category_id = c.id
LEFT JOIN vendors v ON p.vendor_id = v.id
WHERE p.deleted_at IS NULL;  -- Exclude soft-deleted products


-- Usage:
-- SELECT * FROM product_details_with_stock 
-- WHERE category_id = 5 AND stock_status = 'in_stock'
-- ORDER BY average_rating DESC;


-- Bangla: Product listing ‡¶è‡¶∞ ‡¶ú‡¶®‡ßç‡¶Ø ‡¶∏‡¶¨ data ‡¶è‡¶ï query ‡¶§‡ßá ‡¶™‡¶æ‡¶ì‡¶Ø‡¶º‡¶æ ‡¶Ø‡¶æ‡¶Ø‡¶º
-- Multiple join ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡¶æ‡¶∞ ‡¶¶‡¶∞‡¶ï‡¶æ‡¶∞ ‡¶®‡ßá‡¶á
-- Available stock real-time calculate ‡¶π‡¶Ø‡¶º


order_summary View


-- View: Order summary with customer and item counts
-- ‡¶ï‡ßá‡¶®: Order lists display ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡¶æ‡¶∞ ‡¶∏‡¶Æ‡¶Ø‡¶º convenient


CREATE OR REPLACE VIEW order_summary AS
SELECT 
    o.id,
    o.order_number,
    o.order_status,
    o.payment_status,
    
    -- Customer information
    u.id AS customer_id,
    u.name AS customer_name,
    u.email AS customer_email,
    
    -- Order totals
    o.subtotal,
    o.tax,
    o.shipping_charge,
    o.discount,
    o.total,
    
    -- Item and vendor counts
    COUNT(DISTINCT oi.id) AS total_items,
    SUM(oi.quantity) AS total_quantity,
    COUNT(DISTINCT oi.vendor_id) AS total_vendors,
    
    -- Timestamps
    o.created_at,
    o.updated_at
    
FROM orders o
LEFT JOIN users u ON o.customer_id = u.id
LEFT JOIN order_items oi ON o.id = oi.order_id
WHERE o.deleted_at IS NULL
GROUP BY o.id, u.id, u.name, u.email;


-- Usage:
-- SELECT * FROM order_summary 
-- WHERE customer_id = 10 
-- ORDER BY created_at DESC;


-- Bangla: Order list ‡¶¶‡ßá‡¶ñ‡¶æ‡¶®‡ßã‡¶∞ ‡¶∏‡¶Æ‡¶Ø‡¶º ‡¶è‡¶ï query ‡¶§‡ßá summary ‡¶™‡¶æ‡¶ì‡¶Ø‡¶º‡¶æ
-- ‡¶ï‡¶§‡¶ó‡ßÅ‡¶≤‡ßã items, total vendors - ‡¶∏‡¶¨ automatically calculate ‡¶π‡¶Ø‡¶º


vendor_earnings_summary View


-- View: Vendor earnings breakdown by status
-- ‡¶ï‡ßá‡¶®: Vendor dashboard ‡¶è earnings display ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡¶æ‡¶∞ ‡¶ú‡¶®‡ßç‡¶Ø


CREATE OR REPLACE VIEW vendor_earnings_summary AS
SELECT 
    v.id AS vendor_id,
    v.business_name,
    
    -- Order counts
    COUNT(DISTINCT o.id) AS total_orders,
    COUNT(DISTINCT CASE 
        WHEN o.order_status = 'completed' 
        THEN o.id 
    END) AS completed_orders,
    
    -- Sales totals
    COALESCE(SUM(oi.total_price), 0) AS total_sales,
    
    -- Commission breakdown
    COALESCE(SUM(c.commission_amount), 0) AS total_commission,
    COALESCE(SUM(c.gateway_fee), 0) AS total_gateway_fee,
    COALESCE(SUM(c.vendor_payout), 0) AS total_payout,
    
    -- Payout status breakdown
    COALESCE(SUM(CASE 
        WHEN c.status = 'pending' 
        THEN c.vendor_payout 
        ELSE 0 
    END), 0) AS pending_balance,
    
    COALESCE(SUM(CASE 
        WHEN c.status = 'released' 
        THEN c.vendor_payout 
        ELSE 0 
    END), 0) AS available_balance,
    
    COALESCE(SUM(CASE 
        WHEN c.status = 'paid' 
        THEN c.vendor_payout 
        ELSE 0 
    END), 0) AS paid_amount,
    
    -- Last payout date
    MAX(p.completed_at) AS last_payout_date
    
FROM vendors v
LEFT JOIN order_items oi ON v.id = oi.vendor_id
LEFT JOIN orders o ON oi.order_id = o.id 
    AND o.payment_status = 'paid'
LEFT JOIN commissions c ON oi.id = c.order_item_id
LEFT JOIN payouts p ON v.id = p.vendor_id 
    AND p.status = 'paid'
GROUP BY v.id, v.business_name;


-- Usage:
-- SELECT * FROM vendor_earnings_summary WHERE vendor_id = 5;


-- Bangla: Vendor dashboard ‡¶è‡¶∞ ‡¶ú‡¶®‡ßç‡¶Ø complete earnings summary
-- Pending, Available, Paid - ‡¶§‡¶ø‡¶®‡¶ü‡¶æ balance ‡¶Ü‡¶≤‡¶æ‡¶¶‡¶æ ‡¶¶‡ßá‡¶ñ‡¶æ‡¶Ø‡¶º
-- Last payout date ‡¶ì include ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡¶æ
5. INFRASTRUCTURE ARCHITECTURE
5.1 Infrastructure Overview
The platform infrastructure is designed for high availability, scalability, and ease of deployment using containerization and cloud-native technologies.
Infrastructure Diagram
  

‡¶è‡¶á infrastructure ‡¶ü‡¶æ multiple layers ‡¶è organized:
1. CDN Layer - Static files (images, CSS, JS) globally distribute ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡ßá, fast loading
2. Load Balancer - Traffic multiple servers ‡¶è distribute ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡ßá, single point of failure ‡¶®‡ßá‡¶á
3. Web Servers - PHP application run ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡ßá, horizontally scale ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡¶æ ‡¶Ø‡¶æ‡¶Ø‡¶º
4. Database Layer - Master-Replica setup: writes master ‡¶è, reads replica ‡¶•‡ßá‡¶ï‡ßá
5. Cache Layer - Redis frequently accessed data store ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡ßá, database load ‡¶ï‡¶Æ
6. Background Services - Queue workers, search engine, scheduled tasks
7. External Services - Payment, email, storage cloud services ‡¶•‡ßá‡¶ï‡ßá ‡¶®‡ßá‡¶ì‡¶Ø‡¶º‡¶æ
5.2 Docker Architecture
The platform uses Docker containers for consistent environments across development, staging, and production.
Container Structure
ecommerce-platform/
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ docker-compose.yml              # Development environment
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ docker-compose.prod.yml         # Production environment
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ docker/
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ nginx/
‚îÇ   ‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ Dockerfile
‚îÇ   ‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ nginx.conf
‚îÇ   ‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ default.conf
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ php/
‚îÇ   ‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ Dockerfile
‚îÇ   ‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ php.ini
‚îÇ   ‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ www.conf
‚îÇ   ‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ supervisord.conf
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ postgres/
‚îÇ       ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ Dockerfile
‚îÇ       ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ init.sql
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ backend/                        # Laravel application
docker-compose.yml (Development)


version: '3.8'


# ‡¶ï‡ßá‡¶® Docker Compose use ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡¶õ‡¶ø:
# - Multiple services ‡¶è‡¶ï‡¶∏‡¶æ‡¶•‡ßá manage ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡¶æ easy
# - Consistent development environment ‡¶∏‡¶¨‡¶æ‡¶∞ ‡¶ú‡¶®‡ßç‡¶Ø
# - One command ‡¶è ‡¶™‡ßÅ‡¶∞‡ßã stack up/down ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡¶æ ‡¶Ø‡¶æ‡¶Ø‡¶º


services:
  # ==========================================
  # NGINX WEB SERVER
  # ==========================================
  nginx:
    # Image: nginx:alpine (lightweight version)
    image: nginx:alpine
    container_name: ecommerce-nginx
    
    # Ports: Host:Container mapping
    # ‡¶ï‡ßá‡¶®: localhost:80 ‡¶•‡ßá‡¶ï‡ßá access ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡¶æ‡¶∞ ‡¶ú‡¶®‡ßç‡¶Ø
    ports:
      - "80:80"
      - "443:443"
    
    # Volumes: Bind mount ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡¶æ
    # ‡¶ï‡ßá‡¶®: Code change ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡¶≤‡ßá instant reflect ‡¶π‡¶Ø‡¶º
    volumes:
      - ./backend:/var/www/html
      - ./docker/nginx/nginx.conf:/etc/nginx/nginx.conf:ro
      - ./docker/nginx/default.conf:/etc/nginx/conf.d/default.conf:ro
    
    # Dependencies: PHP ready ‡¶π‡¶ì‡¶Ø‡¶º‡¶æ‡¶∞ ‡¶™‡¶∞ start ‡¶π‡¶¨‡ßá
    depends_on:
      - php
    
    # Networks: ‡¶∏‡¶¨ container ‡¶è‡¶ï‡¶á network ‡¶è
    networks:
      - ecommerce-network
    
    # Health check: Container healthy ‡¶ï‡¶ø‡¶®‡¶æ check ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡¶æ
    healthcheck:
      test: ["CMD", "wget", "--quiet", "--tries=1", "--spider", "http://localhost/health"]
      interval: 30s
      timeout: 10s
      retries: 3
      start_period: 40s


  # ==========================================
  # PHP-FPM APPLICATION
  # ==========================================
  php:
    # Custom build from Dockerfile
    # ‡¶ï‡ßá‡¶®: PHP extensions install ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡¶§‡ßá ‡¶π‡¶¨‡ßá
    build:
      context: ./docker/php
      dockerfile: Dockerfile
      args:
        - PHP_VERSION=8.2
    container_name: ecommerce-php
    
    # Volumes: Code ‡¶è‡¶¨‡¶Ç config mount
    volumes:
      - ./backend:/var/www/html
      - ./docker/php/php.ini:/usr/local/etc/php/conf.d/custom.ini:ro
      - ./docker/php/www.conf:/usr/local/etc/php-fpm.d/www.conf:ro
    
    # Environment variables
    environment:
      - APP_ENV=local
      - APP_DEBUG=true
      - DB_HOST=postgres
      - DB_PORT=5432
      - DB_DATABASE=ecommerce
      - DB_USERNAME=postgres
      - DB_PASSWORD=secret
      - REDIS_HOST=redis
      - REDIS_PORT=6379
      - MEILISEARCH_HOST=http://meilisearch:7700
      - MEILISEARCH_KEY=masterKey
    
    depends_on:
      postgres:
        condition: service_healthy
      redis:
        condition: service_started
    
    networks:
      - ecommerce-network
    
    # Health check: PHP-FPM running ‡¶ï‡¶ø‡¶®‡¶æ
    healthcheck:
      test: ["CMD-SHELL", "php-fpm -t"]
      interval: 30s
      timeout: 10s
      retries: 3


  # ==========================================
  # POSTGRESQL DATABASE
  # ==========================================
  postgres:
    image: postgres:15-alpine
    container_name: ecommerce-postgres
    
    ports:
      - "5432:5432"
    
    environment:
      POSTGRES_DB: ecommerce
      POSTGRES_USER: postgres
      POSTGRES_PASSWORD: secret
      POSTGRES_INITDB_ARGS: "-E UTF8"
    
    # Volume: Data persistence
    # ‡¶ï‡ßá‡¶®: Container restart ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡¶≤‡ßá‡¶ì data ‡¶•‡¶æ‡¶ï‡¶¨‡ßá
    volumes:
      - postgres-data:/var/lib/postgresql/data
      - ./docker/postgres/init.sql:/docker-entrypoint-initdb.d/init.sql:ro
    
    # Shared memory for PostgreSQL
    # ‡¶ï‡ßá‡¶®: Better performance ‡¶è‡¶∞ ‡¶ú‡¶®‡ßç‡¶Ø
    shm_size: 256mb
    
    # Custom command with tuning
    command: 
      - "postgres"
      - "-c"
      - "max_connections=200"
      - "-c"
      - "shared_buffers=256MB"
      - "-c"
      - "effective_cache_size=1GB"
      - "-c"
      - "work_mem=16MB"
    
    networks:
      - ecommerce-network
    
    # Health check: Database ready ‡¶ï‡¶ø‡¶®‡¶æ
    healthcheck:
      test: ["CMD-SHELL", "pg_isready -U postgres"]
      interval: 10s
      timeout: 5s
      retries: 5


  # ==========================================
  # REDIS CACHE & QUEUE
  # ==========================================
  redis:
    image: redis:7-alpine
    container_name: ecommerce-redis
    
    ports:
      - "6379:6379"
    
    # Command: Persistence enable ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡¶æ
    # ‡¶ï‡ßá‡¶®: Restart ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡¶≤‡ßá‡¶ì cache data ‡¶•‡¶æ‡¶ï‡¶¨‡ßá
    command: redis-server --appendonly yes --requirepass secret
    
    volumes:
      - redis-data:/data
    
    networks:
      - ecommerce-network
    
    healthcheck:
      test: ["CMD", "redis-cli", "--raw", "incr", "ping"]
      interval: 10s
      timeout: 5s
      retries: 5


  # ==========================================
  # MEILISEARCH
  # ==========================================
  meilisearch:
    image: getmeili/meilisearch:v1.5
    container_name: ecommerce-meilisearch
    
    ports:
      - "7700:7700"
    
    environment:
      MEILI_MASTER_KEY: masterKey
      MEILI_ENV: development
      MEILI_NO_ANALYTICS: true
    
    volumes:
      - meilisearch-data:/meili_data
    
    networks:
      - ecommerce-network
    
    healthcheck:
      test: ["CMD", "wget", "--no-verbose", "--spider", "http://localhost:7700/health"]
      interval: 10s
      timeout: 5s
      retries: 5


  # ==========================================
  # MAILHOG (Email Testing)
  # ==========================================
  mailhog:
    image: mailhog/mailhog:latest
    container_name: ecommerce-mailhog
    
    ports:
      - "1025:1025"   # SMTP
      - "8025:8025"   # Web UI
    
    networks:
      - ecommerce-network


  # ==========================================
  # ADMINER (Database UI)
  # ==========================================
  adminer:
    image: adminer:latest
    container_name: ecommerce-adminer
    
    ports:
      - "8080:8080"
    
    environment:
      ADMINER_DEFAULT_SERVER: postgres
    
    depends_on:
      - postgres
    
    networks:
      - ecommerce-network


  # ==========================================
  # QUEUE WORKER
  # ==========================================
  queue-worker:
    build:
      context: ./docker/php
      dockerfile: Dockerfile
    container_name: ecommerce-queue-worker
    
    # Command: Run queue worker
    # ‡¶ï‡ßá‡¶®: Background jobs process ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡¶æ‡¶∞ ‡¶ú‡¶®‡ßç‡¶Ø
    command: php artisan queue:work --sleep=3 --tries=3 --max-time=3600
    
    volumes:
      - ./backend:/var/www/html
    
    environment:
      - APP_ENV=local
      - DB_HOST=postgres
      - REDIS_HOST=redis
    
    depends_on:
      - php
      - redis
    
    networks:
      - ecommerce-network
    
    # Restart policy: Always restart if failed
    # ‡¶ï‡ßá‡¶®: Queue worker crash ‡¶π‡¶≤‡ßá automatic restart
    restart: unless-stopped


  # ==========================================
  # SCHEDULER (Cron Jobs)
  # ==========================================
  scheduler:
    build:
      context: ./docker/php
      dockerfile: Dockerfile
    container_name: ecommerce-scheduler
    
    # Command: Run Laravel scheduler every minute
    command: /bin/sh -c "while true; do php artisan schedule:run --verbose --no-interaction & sleep 60; done"
    
    volumes:
      - ./backend:/var/www/html
    
    environment:
      - APP_ENV=local
      - DB_HOST=postgres
      - REDIS_HOST=redis
    
    depends_on:
      - php
    
    networks:
      - ecommerce-network
    
    restart: unless-stopped


# ==========================================
# NETWORKS
# ==========================================
networks:
  ecommerce-network:
    driver: bridge
    # ‡¶ï‡ßá‡¶®: Custom network ‡¶è ‡¶∏‡¶¨ containers communicate ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡¶§‡ßá ‡¶™‡¶æ‡¶∞‡ßá
    # ‡¶¨‡ßá‡¶®‡¶ø‡¶´‡¶ø‡¶ü: Container name ‡¶¶‡¶ø‡¶Ø‡¶º‡ßá access ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡¶æ ‡¶Ø‡¶æ‡¶Ø‡¶º (postgres, redis)


# ==========================================
# VOLUMES (Persistent Data)
# ==========================================
volumes:
  postgres-data:
    # ‡¶ï‡ßá‡¶®: Database data permanently store ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡¶æ
    # ‡¶®‡¶æ ‡¶π‡¶≤‡ßá: Container delete ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡¶≤‡ßá data ‡¶π‡¶æ‡¶∞‡¶ø‡¶Ø‡¶º‡ßá ‡¶Ø‡ßá‡¶§
    driver: local
  
  redis-data:
    driver: local
  
  meilisearch-data:
    driver: local


PHP Dockerfile


# docker/php/Dockerfile


# Base image: PHP 8.2 with FPM
# ‡¶ï‡ßá‡¶®: Laravel 10 minimum PHP 8.1 ‡¶ö‡¶æ‡¶Ø‡¶º, 8.2 use ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡¶õ‡¶ø latest features ‡¶è‡¶∞ ‡¶ú‡¶®‡ßç‡¶Ø
FROM php:8.2-fpm-alpine


# Maintainer information
LABEL maintainer="DevOps Team <devops@platform.com>"


# Install system dependencies
# ‡¶ï‡ßá‡¶®: PHP extensions compile ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡¶æ‡¶∞ ‡¶ú‡¶®‡ßç‡¶Ø ‡¶è‡¶á packages ‡¶≤‡¶æ‡¶ó‡ßá
RUN apk update && apk add --no-cache \
    # Build tools
    build-base \
    autoconf \
    # Image processing (GD extension)
    libpng-dev \
    libjpeg-turbo-dev \
    freetype-dev \
    # PostgreSQL client
    postgresql-dev \
    # ZIP support
    libzip-dev \
    zip \
    unzip \
    # Git (Composer ‡¶è‡¶∞ ‡¶ú‡¶®‡ßç‡¶Ø)
    git \
    # Process management
    supervisor \
    # Utilities
    curl \
    nano \
    # Node.js ‡¶è‡¶¨‡¶Ç npm (frontend build ‡¶è‡¶∞ ‡¶ú‡¶®‡ßç‡¶Ø)
    nodejs \
    npm


# Configure GD extension
# ‡¶ï‡ßá‡¶®: Image processing ‡¶è JPEG, PNG, FreeType support enable ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡¶æ
RUN docker-php-ext-configure gd \
    --with-freetype \
    --with-jpeg


# Install PHP extensions
# ‡¶ï‡ßá‡¶®: Laravel ‡¶è‡¶∞ ‡¶ú‡¶®‡ßç‡¶Ø necessary extensions
RUN docker-php-ext-install -j$(nproc) \
    pdo_pgsql \     # PostgreSQL PDO driver
    pgsql \         # PostgreSQL native functions
    gd \            # Image processing
    zip \           # ZIP archive handling
    bcmath \        # Arbitrary precision math (money calculations)
    opcache \       # PHP bytecode caching (performance)
    pcntl           # Process control (queue workers)


# Install Redis extension via PECL
# ‡¶ï‡ßá‡¶®: Laravel cache/session/queue Redis use ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡¶¨‡ßá
RUN pecl install redis-5.3.7 && \
    docker-php-ext-enable redis


# Install Composer
# ‡¶ï‡ßá‡¶®: PHP dependency management
COPY --from=composer:latest /usr/bin/composer /usr/bin/composer


# Set working directory
WORKDIR /var/www/html


# Copy PHP configuration
# ‡¶ï‡ßá‡¶®: Custom PHP settings (memory, upload limits)
COPY php.ini /usr/local/etc/php/conf.d/custom.ini
COPY www.conf /usr/local/etc/php-fpm.d/www.conf


# Copy Supervisor configuration
# ‡¶ï‡ßá‡¶®: Queue workers background ‡¶è ‡¶ö‡¶æ‡¶≤‡¶æ‡¶®‡ßã‡¶∞ ‡¶ú‡¶®‡ßç‡¶Ø
COPY supervisord.conf /etc/supervisor/conf.d/supervisord.conf


# Create necessary directories
# ‡¶ï‡ßá‡¶®: Laravel ‡¶è‡¶∞ storage directories writable ‡¶π‡¶§‡ßá ‡¶π‡¶¨‡ßá
RUN mkdir -p /var/www/html/storage/framework/cache \
    /var/www/html/storage/framework/sessions \
    /var/www/html/storage/framework/views \
    /var/www/html/storage/logs \
    /var/www/html/bootstrap/cache


# Set permissions
# ‡¶ï‡ßá‡¶®: www-data user (PHP-FPM) files access ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡¶§‡ßá ‡¶™‡¶æ‡¶∞‡¶¨‡ßá
RUN chown -R www-data:www-data /var/www/html && \
    chmod -R 755 /var/www/html/storage && \
    chmod -R 755 /var/www/html/bootstrap/cache


# Health check script
# ‡¶ï‡ßá‡¶®: Container healthy ‡¶ï‡¶ø‡¶®‡¶æ check ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡¶æ
RUN echo '#!/bin/sh' > /healthcheck.sh && \
    echo 'php-fpm -t' >> /healthcheck.sh && \
    chmod +x /healthcheck.sh


HEALTHCHECK --interval=30s --timeout=3s --start-period=40s \
    CMD /healthcheck.sh


# Expose PHP-FPM port
EXPOSE 9000


# Start PHP-FPM
# ‡¶ï‡ßá‡¶®: Container start ‡¶π‡¶≤‡ßá PHP-FPM run ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡¶¨‡ßá
CMD ["php-fpm"]
‡¶è‡¶á Dockerfile PHP container build ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡ßá ‡¶Ø‡ßá‡¶ü‡¶æ‡¶Ø‡¶º:
1. PHP 8.2 FPM install ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡¶æ ‡¶π‡¶Ø‡¶º
2. PostgreSQL, Redis, Image processing extensions add ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡¶æ ‡¶π‡¶Ø‡¶º
3. Composer install ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡¶æ (dependencies ‡¶è‡¶∞ ‡¶ú‡¶®‡ßç‡¶Ø)
4. Custom PHP configuration apply ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡¶æ (memory, upload limits)
5. Storage directories create ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡¶æ ‡¶è‡¶¨‡¶Ç permissions set ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡¶æ
6. Health check setup ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡¶æ (container alive ‡¶Ü‡¶õ‡ßá ‡¶ï‡¶ø‡¶®‡¶æ)
Nginx Configuration
# docker/nginx/default.conf


# Laravel application configuration
# ‡¶ï‡ßá‡¶®: Laravel ‡¶è‡¶∞ ‡¶ú‡¶®‡ßç‡¶Ø specific server setup


server {
    # Listen on port 80
    listen 80;
    listen [::]:80;
    
    # Server name (domain)
    # Development ‡¶è localhost, production ‡¶è actual domain
    server_name localhost;


    # Document root: Laravel ‡¶è‡¶∞ public folder
    # ‡¶ï‡ßá‡¶®: Laravel index.php ‡¶è‡¶ñ‡¶æ‡¶®‡ßá ‡¶Ü‡¶õ‡ßá
    root /var/www/html/public;
    
    # Index file
    index index.php index.html;


    # Character set
    charset utf-8;


    # Disable access log for performance (optional)
    # access_log off;
    
    # Error log location
    error_log /var/log/nginx/error.log;


    # ==========================================
    # MAIN LOCATION BLOCK
    # ==========================================
    location / {
        # try_files directive
        # ‡¶ï‡ßá‡¶®: Laravel routing ‡¶ï‡¶æ‡¶ú ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡¶æ‡¶∞ ‡¶ú‡¶®‡ßç‡¶Ø
        # Flow: File exist ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡ßá? ‡¶®‡¶æ ‡¶•‡¶æ‡¶ï‡¶≤‡ßá directory? ‡¶®‡¶æ ‡¶•‡¶æ‡¶ï‡¶≤‡ßá index.php ‡¶§‡ßá ‡¶™‡¶æ‡¶†‡¶æ‡¶ì
        try_files $uri $uri/ /index.php?$query_string;
    }


    # ==========================================
    # PHP FILE HANDLING
    # ==========================================
    location ~ \.php$ {
        # FastCGI pass to PHP-FPM container
        # ‡¶ï‡ßá‡¶®: PHP code execute ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡¶æ‡¶∞ ‡¶ú‡¶®‡ßç‡¶Ø PHP-FPM ‡¶≤‡¶æ‡¶ó‡ßá
        # php:9000 = container_name:port
        fastcgi_pass php:9000;
        
        # Default index file
        fastcgi_index index.php;
        
        # Script filename parameter
        # ‡¶ï‡ßá‡¶®: PHP-FPM ‡¶ï‡ßá ‡¶¨‡¶≤‡¶æ ‡¶ï‡ßã‡¶® file run ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡¶§‡ßá ‡¶π‡¶¨‡ßá
        fastcgi_param SCRIPT_FILENAME $document_root$fastcgi_script_name;
        
        # Include default FastCGI parameters
        include fastcgi_params;
        
        # Timeouts for long-running requests
        # ‡¶ï‡ßá‡¶®: Image upload, report generation timeout ‡¶®‡¶æ ‡¶π‡¶ì‡¶Ø‡¶º‡¶æ‡¶∞ ‡¶ú‡¶®‡ßç‡¶Ø
        fastcgi_read_timeout 300;
        fastcgi_send_timeout 300;
        
        # Buffer settings
        fastcgi_buffer_size 128k;
        fastcgi_buffers 256 16k;
        fastcgi_busy_buffers_size 256k;
    }


    # ==========================================
    # STATIC FILES CACHING
    # ==========================================
    location ~* \.(jpg|jpeg|png|gif|ico|css|js|svg|woff|woff2|ttf|eot)$ {
        # Cache static files for 1 year
        # ‡¶ï‡ßá‡¶®: Browser cache ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡¶¨‡ßá, repeated downloads ‡¶ï‡¶Æ
        expires 1y;
        add_header Cache-Control "public, immutable";
        
        # Access log disable ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡¶æ (performance)
        access_log off;
    }


    # ==========================================
    # HIDDEN FILES PROTECTION
    # ==========================================
    location ~ /\. {
        # Deny access to hidden files (.env, .git, etc.)
        # ‡¶ï‡ßá‡¶®: Security - sensitive files expose ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡¶æ ‡¶Ø‡¶æ‡¶¨‡ßá ‡¶®‡¶æ
        deny all;
        access_log off;
        log_not_found off;
    }


    # ==========================================
    # DENY ACCESS TO SENSITIVE FILES
    # ==========================================
    location ~ /(composer\.json|composer\.lock|package\.json|\.env.*) {
        # ‡¶ï‡ßá‡¶®: Configuration files browser ‡¶•‡ßá‡¶ï‡ßá accessible ‡¶®‡¶æ
        deny all;
        return 404;
    }


    # ==========================================
    # SECURITY HEADERS
    # ==========================================
    # X-Frame-Options: Clickjacking prevent ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡¶æ
    add_header X-Frame-Options "SAMEORIGIN" always;
    
    # X-Content-Type-Options: MIME sniffing attacks prevent ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡¶æ
    add_header X-Content-Type-Options "nosniff" always;
    
    # X-XSS-Protection: Browser XSS filter enable ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡¶æ
    add_header X-XSS-Protection "1; mode=block" always;
    
    # Referrer Policy
    add_header Referrer-Policy "strict-origin-when-cross-origin" always;


    # ==========================================
    # CLIENT LIMITS
    # ==========================================
    # Maximum upload size
    # ‡¶ï‡ßá‡¶®: Large images upload ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡¶§‡ßá ‡¶™‡¶æ‡¶∞‡¶¨‡ßá
    client_max_body_size 20M;
    
    # Client body buffer
    client_body_buffer_size 128k;


    # ==========================================
    # GZIP COMPRESSION
    # ==========================================
    gzip on;
    gzip_vary on;
    gzip_proxied any;
    gzip_comp_level 6;
    gzip_types text/plain text/css text/xml text/javascript 
               application/json application/javascript application/xml+rss 
               application/rss+xml font/truetype font/opentype 
               application/vnd.ms-fontobject image/svg+xml;
}
‡¶è‡¶á Nginx configuration Laravel application properly serve ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡¶æ‡¶∞ ‡¶ú‡¶®‡ßç‡¶Ø:
1. Root directory - Laravel ‡¶è‡¶∞ public folder point ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡¶æ
2. try_files - Laravel routing enable ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡¶æ (‡¶∏‡¶¨ requests index.php ‡¶§‡ßá ‡¶Ø‡¶æ‡¶Ø‡¶º)
3. PHP processing - .php files PHP-FPM container ‡¶è ‡¶™‡¶æ‡¶†‡¶æ‡¶®‡ßã
4. Static caching - CSS, JS, images browser cache ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡¶æ (fast loading)
5. Security - Hidden files (.env, .git) access deny ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡¶æ
6. Headers - XSS, Clickjacking protect ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡¶æ
7. Compression - Response gzip ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡¶æ (bandwidth save)
5.3 Production Infrastructure
Production environment additional considerations ‡¶è‡¶∞ ‡¶∏‡¶æ‡¶•‡ßá configured:
Production docker-compose.prod.yml
version: '3.8'


# Production environment configuration
# Development ‡¶•‡ßá‡¶ï‡ßá key differences:
# 1. No bind mounts (code image ‡¶è‡¶∞ ‡¶Æ‡¶ß‡ßç‡¶Ø‡ßá)
# 2. Resource limits set ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡¶æ
# 3. Restart policies configured
# 4. Health checks stricter
# 5. Logging configured


services:
  nginx:
    image: registry.gitlab.com/platform/nginx:${VERSION}
    container_name: ecommerce-nginx-prod
    
    ports:
      - "80:80"
      - "443:443"
    
    # Volumes: ‡¶∂‡ßÅ‡¶ß‡ßÅ SSL certificates ‡¶è‡¶¨‡¶Ç logs
    volumes:
      - ./ssl:/etc/nginx/ssl:ro
      - nginx-logs:/var/log/nginx
    
    # Resource limits
    # ‡¶ï‡ßá‡¶®: ‡¶è‡¶ï‡¶ü‡¶æ container ‡¶∏‡¶¨ resources consume ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡¶§‡ßá ‡¶™‡¶æ‡¶∞‡¶¨‡ßá ‡¶®‡¶æ
    deploy:
      resources:
        limits:
          cpus: '1.0'
          memory: 512M
        reservations:
          cpus: '0.5'
          memory: 256M
    
    # Restart policy: Always restart unless stopped manually
    restart: unless-stopped
    
    depends_on:
      - php
    
    networks:
      - ecommerce-network
    
    # Logging configuration
    logging:
      driver: "json-file"
      options:
        max-size: "10m"
        max-file: "3"


  php:
    image: registry.gitlab.com/platform/php-fpm:${VERSION}
    container_name: ecommerce-php-prod
    
    # Environment from .env file
    # ‡¶ï‡ßá‡¶®: Sensitive credentials code ‡¶è ‡¶®‡¶æ ‡¶∞‡¶æ‡¶ñ‡¶æ
    env_file:
      - .env.production
    
    # Resource limits
    deploy:
      resources:
        limits:
          cpus: '2.0'
          memory: 1G
        reservations:
          cpus: '1.0'
          memory: 512M
      
      # Replicas: Multiple PHP containers for load balancing
      # ‡¶ï‡ßá‡¶®: High availability ‡¶è‡¶¨‡¶Ç performance
      replicas: 3
    
    restart: unless-stopped
    
    depends_on:
      postgres:
        condition: service_healthy
      redis:
        condition: service_healthy
    
    networks:
      - ecommerce-network
    
    logging:
      driver: "json-file"
      options:
        max-size: "10m"
        max-file: "5"


  postgres:
    image: postgres:15-alpine
    container_name: ecommerce-postgres-prod
    
    # Environment from secrets
    environment:
      POSTGRES_DB: ${DB_DATABASE}
      POSTGRES_USER: ${DB_USERNAME}
      POSTGRES_PASSWORD_FILE: /run/secrets/db_password
    
    # Secrets: Sensitive data secure way
    # ‡¶ï‡ßá‡¶®: Passwords plain text ‡¶è ‡¶®‡¶æ ‡¶∞‡¶æ‡¶ñ‡¶æ
    secrets:
      - db_password
    
    # Volume: Named volume for data
    volumes:
      - postgres-data-prod:/var/lib/postgresql/data
    
    # Shared memory increased for production
    shm_size: 512mb
    
    # Production tuning
    command:
      - "postgres"
      - "-c"
      - "max_connections=300"
      - "-c"
      - "shared_buffers=512MB"
      - "-c"
      - "effective_cache_size=2GB"
      - "-c"
      - "maintenance_work_mem=128MB"
      - "-c"
      - "checkpoint_completion_target=0.9"
      - "-c"
      - "wal_buffers=16MB"
      - "-c"
      - "default_statistics_target=100"
    
    deploy:
      resources:
        limits:
          cpus: '4.0'
          memory: 4G
        reservations:
          cpus: '2.0'
          memory: 2G
    
    restart: unless-stopped
    
    networks:
      - ecommerce-network
    
    healthcheck:
      test: ["CMD-SHELL", "pg_isready -U ${DB_USERNAME}"]
      interval: 10s
      timeout: 5s
      retries: 5
      start_period: 60s
    
    logging:
      driver: "json-file"
      options:
        max-size: "10m"
        max-file: "5"


  redis:
    image: redis:7-alpine
    container_name: ecommerce-redis-prod
    
    command: redis-server --appendonly yes --requirepass ${REDIS_PASSWORD}
    
    volumes:
      - redis-data-prod:/data
    
    deploy:
      resources:
        limits:
          cpus: '1.0'
          memory: 512M
        reservations:
          cpus: '0.5'
          memory: 256M
    
    restart: unless-stopped
    
    networks:
      - ecommerce-network
    
    healthcheck:
      test: ["CMD", "redis-cli", "--raw", "incr", "ping"]
      interval: 10s
      timeout: 5s
      retries: 5


  queue-worker:
    image: registry.gitlab.com/platform/php-fpm:${VERSION}
    
    command: php artisan queue:work --sleep=3 --tries=3 --max-time=3600
    
    env_file:
      - .env.production
    
    # Multiple workers for parallel processing
    # ‡¶ï‡ßá‡¶®: Background jobs fast process ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡¶æ‡¶∞ ‡¶ú‡¶®‡ßç‡¶Ø
    deploy:
      replicas: 5
      resources:
        limits:
          cpus: '1.0'
          memory: 512M
        reservations:
          cpus: '0.5'
          memory: 256M
    
    restart: unless-stopped
    
    depends_on:
      - php
      - redis
    
    networks:
      - ecommerce-network


# Secrets definition
# ‡¶ï‡ßá‡¶®: Sensitive credentials secure ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡¶æ
secrets:
  db_password:
    file: ./secrets/db_password.txt


networks:
  ecommerce-network:
    driver: bridge


volumes:
  postgres-data-prod:
    driver: local
  redis-data-prod:
    driver: local
  nginx-logs:
    driver: local

Bangla Explanation of Production Config:

Production configuration ‡¶è extra features:

  • Resource Limits - ‡¶™‡ßç‡¶∞‡¶§‡¶ø‡¶ü‡¶æ container ‡¶ï‡¶§ CPU/Memory use ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡¶§‡ßá ‡¶™‡¶æ‡¶∞‡¶¨‡ßá define ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡¶æ
  • Replicas - PHP ‡¶è‡¶¨‡¶Ç Queue workers ‡¶è‡¶∞ multiple copies (load distribute ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡¶æ‡¶∞ ‡¶ú‡¶®‡ßç‡¶Ø)
  • Secrets - Database passwords secure way ‡¶§‡ßá manage ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡¶æ
  • Restart Policies - Crash ‡¶π‡¶≤‡ßá automatic restart
  • Logging - Log rotation configure ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡¶æ (disk full ‡¶®‡¶æ ‡¶π‡¶ì‡¶Ø‡¶º‡¶æ‡¶∞ ‡¶ú‡¶®‡ßç‡¶Ø)
  • Health Checks - Stricter checks production ‡¶è
  • No Bind Mounts - Code image ‡¶è‡¶∞ ‡¶Æ‡¶ß‡ßç‡¶Ø‡ßá build ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡¶æ (security)

## 5.4 Cloud Infrastructure

### AWS Architecture

  

AWS infrastructure ‡¶è:
1. Route 53 - DNS management, domain routing
